An amazing concept done beautifully

The plot is not too linear or dramatic but that is not the point. What in other movies is constrained, here develops naturally, with a disconcerting lived quality. Superficially the film is about growing up, or about barely functional American families in the last decade. More deeply, it is about how time permeates life. Unique.
Very relatable film. superb acting on the parts of Patricia and Ethan. A bit long but completely worth watching

What an AMAZING film! Richard Linklater has really out done himself this time with this touching drama about the life of a young boy, growing from year to year. 12 years to be exact-which was how long it took to film the movie. From year to year, we see young Mason (Ellar Coltrane) grow up with a single mom, an older sister and in Texas. This movie reminded me so much of my life (growing up with a single mom and in Texas) my only difference was that I was the older sister to my younger brother. This is a realistic film about the relationships we have with our parents, the one's they have with us, those silly fights we have with our siblings that ultimately lead to unbreakable bonds, and to put is plainly, just getting through the years of being a "kid." From the suburbs of Houston and the city lights of Austin, this is Linklater's homage to not only Texas, but Texas life. He captured how I have felt and for all intensive purposes, this movie could have been called "Girlhood"
A great idea to film actors over multiple years - but the plot/story line was dull.  I kept waiting for something that never happened.

"Nostalgic Innovation"
Boyhood has been on my list of movies to watch for a long time, due to its love received last Oscar season by critics and fans alike. With a run time of 2 hours and 45 minutes I will admit, I was a little scared of putting that amount of time into a movie that seemed so simple and possibly boring. What really could of been a poor decision, even though it truly is a good movie, was starting this movie at around 11:30 at night...

Richard Linklater's Boyhood watches Mason (and the actor who portrays him Ellar Coltrane) grow up. It really is that simple which shows how truly brilliant Linklater (Dazed and Confused, School of Rock) is as a film maker that I watched this film by myself so late and never got bored. Boyhood depicts many realistic circumstances that many boys go through while going through boy hood. Everything nostalgically glorious from playing Halo 2 on the original Xbox, riding around on your bike with friends, to not so fun things like peer pressure to drink and do drugs and dealing with divorced parents. Mason's biological parents are played by Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, which both do a tremendous job at being superbly believable. It never shows the two while they are married but the movie uses both the maternal and paternal scope to analysis the parental role in shaping their kids. Arquette is the single mom who has been beaten down by life but dearly loves her kids even as a disciplinarian. Hawke, as the father, is a nomadic father at first who lives up in Alaska and is painted in poor light at the beginning of the film. But throughout Boyhood, Hawke deals as a vital lense into the purpose of this movie: the meaning of life. In one conversation young Mason asks the younger (probably around 2004) Hawke What the point of life, and Hawke replies, "What's the point? I mean, I sure as S*** don't know. Neither does anybody else, okay? We're all just winging it, you know? The good news is your feeling stuff, you got to hold on to that." Most of the meaningful take away quotes are similar to this, in asking what is the meaning of life or what should or am I doing with it?

The achievement of filming a movie over 12 years and it ending up so smooth and fluid is an innovation we have never seen before and the most impressive part of Boyhood. The transitions when Mason would get a little older and older were refreshing and breathed so much life into this movie. There were no big jumps, which makes it amazing Linklater got through 12 years in less than 3 hours. Another real strength, which I mentioned a little earlier, was the cinematic relationship Mason had with Hawke and Arquette's characters as his parents. It felt so real and never did anything in Boyhood feel forced. Arquette won the Oscar for best supporting female role, which I didn't fully understand why until the next morning when I woke up (which was late because I started the movie so late). She seemed a 100% capable of being one of my friends parents, and she made a severely interesting character, same with Hawke. These really are normal people that the actors make you root for them so bad because of the realism in their performances. The only thing I didn't really like (used like for a reason, liked but didn't love the film like most people) was Linklater's grimness of life that he over emphasized. Let me explain...not with the circumstances because I know stuff like that happens all the time, but with the characters. Mason and his sister Samantha aren't what I would call a normal boy or girl. I think Linklater did this to be able to put a more philosophical touch and narrative on the movie, so I completely understand, but I think he used kind of a cliched cast of kids that didn't go with the realistic older characters. Very minor critique because I completely understand why he did it and still was drawn and invested into mason and Samantha. Boyhood has language throughout, sexually suggestive scenes and drug use.

Although I was lucky enough to see this film earlier at the Sydney Film Festival, it has taken me a while to take enough time out to write a proper review for this movie. Looking at the review aggregates it's obvious that this is definitely a film worth seeing. I have only see a few of Linklater's movies but each one has managed to become some of my favourite movies. (Sidenote Jim and Pam from The Office US choose Dazed and Confused, one of Linklater's first movies, as their top 5 in season 2 episode 4.) 
After watching this film it feels like finishing a superbly filmed home video of a friend you haven't seen in a while. You feel a connection with the characters as you watch them progress from year to year, suffering through the problems that we have all been through or can relate to. Everyone associated with the film has done an excellent job being dedicated to this project for 12 years. Ellar Coltrane, the main actor who we see grow up through the film, is interesting because he is very relatable, someone you could meet down the street. Patricia Arquette is also excellent as the mother who makes many terrible decisions but is able to persevere, and Ethan Hawke as the fun father, popping in randomly throughout the film. The film starts off stronger than it finishes but this may be due to Ellar Coltrane being very cute as a kid and then growing up to be just pretty good. It also feels like the film could've ended at a few points near the end but it decides to go on which isn't a totally bad thing but does make it feel a little long even though the end is great.
Beyond showing you the family problems and encapsulating growing up in a film, an excellent feat in its own respect, Boyhood is like a time capsule. Especially for those who grew up in the last decade, this film will be a nostalgia trip that will revive memories from the very start when Yellow - Coldplay begins to play. Other highlights included Dragon Ball Z, Halo 2 on Xbox and many others. The film perfectly captures the growing influence of technology in our lifestyles, as you see it progress from brick phones to constantly checking Facebook for updates. 
There is a lot to say about Boyhood but the most important thing is you should watch it as soon as you get the opportunity, it is an excellent film unlike anything else that has ever been attempted. It's beyond being just emotional or just a film that makes you think, it is PHAMTASTIC. I hope it goes on to the Oscars because it definitely deserves to.

Have you ever thought about the idea of shooting a film for over more than a decade? How could it be done? Who will want to fund this idea? What actor would be insane enough to sign on for it? Can a director be that perseverant and ambitious? Is there a story so big and ambitious to make this happen? All of those questions are resolved in one of the most daring, groundbreaking and ambitious films in cinematic history: Richard Linklater´s masterpiece "Boyhood". 
We follow a broken family composed of a single mother named Olivia, her young boy named Mason Jr and her slightly older daughter named Samantha. We witness their struggles throughout the span of twelve years/Mason Jr´s childhood (2002-2014).
Perhaps this will be the shortest review I have written so far but one of the longest texts I have posted on this site yet. "Boyhood" is a film that's filled with emotion, the characters are relatable, you will definitely project yourself into one of them and you will care about them from beginning to end; the acting and the dialog feels natural with the standouts being -obviously- Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, the music is appropriate and well used, Linklater´s directing is so personal that it makes you feel like you are a member of this family and the editing is so perfect as it tells the necessary/appropriate moments of this family and leaves some of them out for storytelling reasons and it works marvelously. The only issues this film suffers from are a couple: It has no replay value and it is stretched in the second half. 
"Boyhood" is a film that it is either hailed as a masterpiece or an "overrated" gimmicky art film, due to the fact that this narrative is nothing new and could have been shot as a regular film -over the span of a year- and only because of the fact that it took twelve years to make it is hailed. This film is not about story but the experience, the choice of shooting this over that long time is everything; you are able to see a study about people´s lifestyle in the new millennium and how people struggle with life and manage to endure throughout life´s toughest moments, sure it may not be something new and capturing life onscreen has been done before but the way Linklater did it is what makes this film. I want to say that despite the fact I am didn't grow up in the USA- thus making this film an educational experience as I learned about USA´s society and educational system- this film really got me because I´m the same age as Mason Jr and this film shows a little of my generation, it reflects some experiences I had lived through, and things I grew up with (Star Wars, Dragon Ball Z, Harry Potter, Game Boy, etc.) thus making this a nostalgic experience for me and making this film something a small amount of movies have accomplished for me: Become a personal journey. Regardless of your age, you will definitely experience some nostalgia for your childhood. 
"Boyhood" is colossally ambitious experiment in cinema that will stand the test of time and be remembered as a landmark in the art of cinema. It will provoke a different reaction/feeling on people and some will struggle with it due to the lack of plot but regardless, this is a must see film not only for lovers of the seventh art and the millennials, but for everyone.  The most ambitious and memorable film of 2014 and it ties with "Whiplash" for the spot of my second favorite film of said year.
The strength of this movie is how the viewer can relate to various aspects of a kid growing up and through all the different experiences.

The performances are completely human, the script feels like words from real people, and the story, while considered by some to be uneventful, is basically the life of a boy summed up into a film. This realism is what makes Boyhood a landmark in filmmaking, even if it isn't quite a masterpiece.

After his parents divorce, a boy grows up in Texas.
I really wanted to love this film; going into it, I was prepared to call it the best film of the year and maybe even the best film of the decade. After all, Richard Linklater accomplished a technical feat - making a major motion picture over twelve years - that has never been achieved in American cinema. And this kind of film is right up Linklater's alley, small-scale, human interest drama. 
However, the film never gets going. I kept wondering what the primary conflict was. Is it just growing up? Could that carry a three-hour film? Not really. And when Mason grows up to become an anti-establishment hipster, we see that Linklater returns to his familiar character types. In Linklater films, there are two characters: the sell-outs and the anti-establishment types, and when Mason starts spouting the normal Linklater speeches about the "over-determinedness" of modern life, I knew that the film was only an achievement of the technical variety, not a real expansion of his artistic palette. And while "anachronistic" is not the right word, there are numerous references to the flavor of the times in which the scenes were shot - Britney Spears songs and Harry Potter book signings - that work as the filmmakers winking at the audience and saying, "Look at what was hot during this time."
The best performance in the film belongs to Patricia Arquette whose final moment is chillingly heart-breaking.
Overall, if you know the backstory, Boyhood is a heck of a film, but if we just ignored that the film was shot over twelve years, it wouldn't be that much to write home about.
12 years to make. i am not sure if it was worth it.

One thing that film hasn't really done yet is capturing the subtleties and often unseen beauty of life that constantly surrounds us. It's the little things that we often take for granted that mainly get left by the wayside when they are approached and are only realized for what they are long after its been put out of mind. Boyhood contains and reveals all those little things as well as some big things to show an intricate portrayal of life from a young kid's perspective. With intimate detail and truthful honesty, it's unlike any film before and possibly won't be another film like it. Boyhood isn't simply just about a kid growing up, but how all life is seamless and interconnected as one. You could call it the film about nothing, which would be a fair assumption but much like the classic sitcom Seinfeld that held that unique distinction, it contains everything.
It is 2002 and six year old Mason Evans, Jr. (Ellar Coltrane) is looking up at the sky full of clouds in wonderment as Coldplay's Yellow plays. He is a precocious child who often daydreams with a unique perspective. His mother Olivia (Patricia Arquette) is divorced and pretty unlucky when it comes to love. She raises Mason as well as her daughter Samantha (Lorelei Linklater), a hyperactive girl who often teases her brother Mason. Mason Evans Sr. (Ethan Hawke) is their father who pops up sometimes to take away the kids for the weekend and is somewhat of a slacker who imbibes in pot, plays in a band and drives a classic Pontiac GTO. Over the course of twelve years, Mason's life is formulated and his identity is revealed to the man that he will eventually be, from first grade all the way to the very first day of college.
Director and screenwriter Richard Linklater is well known for his great casts and puts together a great mixture of young unknowns and well respected screen veterans. Coltrane was amazing as Mason and was just as good as and mainly better than most child actors. His growth into an adult actor was downright believable and you can see a clear progression of his talents that looked really natural. Over the course of twelve years, he showed amazing empathy, fear, confusion, anger and compassion that didn't feel overdone. Every emotion shown felt just like it should have and there wasn't one that was left out. Coltrane went over the entire composite of feelings and then went back again. The journey on seeing him grow up was out of this world and you forget you are watching the same kid from a few years ago. It's easy to see a bit of yourself in him, not entirely but we all have been in the same social situations as him in some degree with much of the same reactions. 
After a while, you share his distorted view of the world, or at least I did. I often get involved in my thoughts of conspiracies and government control like him while also being a sort of cynic in many ways. He was a character I could easily relate too based on his taste in music like Paul McCartney and Bright Eyes and his favorite movies of 2008, The Dark Knight, Tropic Thunder and Pineapple Express. I already want to be his best friend on some of his favorite movies alone. Coltrane played him with likability and an easiness that made him easy to root for and get behind. Lorelei Linklater, who is the daughter of Richard, was more outspoken in her role as the somewhat bratty sister. She made for a great dynamic against the more soulful Coltrane and they showed great chemistry as sister and brother. Funny and often brash, she says what no one thinks to say. 
Hawke was somewhat low key but that's just how his character is handled. He has a way about himself that is just so chilled and cool which made his role as weekend paternal dad all the more perfect. He isn't around all the time but is there when he is needed, giving out advice to his kids when they don't want to hear it like safe sex, bumpers on bowling lanes and the ultimate CD mix of The Beatles singles career post breakup titled The Black Album. This may be the coolest gift of all time and possibly the greatest collection of music ever put together. The wisdom he disposes is often very dad like, helpful and he never seems to be out of that role even if he isn't married to their mother anymore. 
Arquette stole much of the movie as many of the dramatic elements contained her in the center. As a single mother raising two kids by herself who is struggling for work, she portrays a view of motherhood like no other film has, where tough decisions and hard choices have to be made for her and her family. It got to be rather alarming seeing her go through these issues but continuing to go on, mainly because she can't really stop for the sake of her children. She pines for order and discipline of some kind but reaches out too far when she lands some domineering, drunk assholes as husbands. Mason Sr. was too nonchalant about being a husband and father, causing her to seek out a stronger father figure but it caused more damage than it was worth. Arquette was strong, human, and infallible and like most mothers easy to disagree and find fault with the things she sometimes says. But in the end, you know deep down that she always had the best intentions and was right for the most part. She was equal parts loving and warm while being stern and forceful with a lot of things getting out of her control causing her to become more and more harried by everything around her.
Linklater's films usually go by the beat of their own drum and don't really adhere to the norms of many 21st century films and styles. Even then it's shocking to know that he filmed a single movie over the course of 12 years, getting the cast back together every year for a few weeks. It's original in every way and still something that fits exactly with Linklater's style. I couldn't picture him doing this any other way afterwards but would easily see many other directors failing at such a revolutionary concept. He simply knows how to stretch a simple idea into something more, giving you something you never expected.
This isn't his first foray into creating something unique as A Scanner Darkly showed a visual delight for the mind and eyes. He burst upon the scene with his classic Slacker but His magnum opus will remain Dazed And Confused, but Boyhood may be his masterpiece. He is surely in the top running for best picture, director and screenplay when the Oscar nominations come out and I'd be surprised if he doesn't win all three come February. The style he uses is unlike any other director as he gets to know every main character intimately, getting to know their desires, dreams and fears. He paints a great image of who these people are, unique in their own way but just a regular person you see every day on the street. His direction was subtle and incredibly nuanced with seemingly minor details being a much bigger part of the whole picture. There were some moments with the step fathers where it got downright frightening and really pulled you out of the movie for a bit. It was hard to see where it was going to go and you hoped it wouldn't go down an ugly road.
There wasn't much character development from the children as there really didn't need to be since they are continually growing. The parents on the other hand go through a litany of changes that jump through time so you don't get that build up that you would see in other films. How they develop isn't as important as the kids and it makes the idea of life changings in an instant in their lives more palpable. Olivia struggles to gain a balance of normalcy by going back to school to be a professor to better provide for her children and as she does so, she attaches herself to men to provide her with emotional as well as monetary support. It doesn't always work out the way she hopes and she bounces from house to house, placing her kids in new schools and homes. Mason Sr. just wants to be a better father for his kids and give them a feeling of normalcy that they otherwise wouldn't have gotten anywhere else. 
He starts off rather irresponsible but eventually becomes the father and husband that he always wanted to with his girlfriend and son. Bit by bit he morphs into a responsible adult, getting a job as an insurance salesman and losing his cool slacker dad status but only after long having children and being married. Olivia seems to be going downward while Mason Sr. is in a slight upswing, it's pretty sad seeing her struggle but getting no admiration for it and you wait to see everything get a little bit better for her. But you can't help but feel good that Mason Sr. is being the wife and dad that he was originally supposed to be and forming a sense of normalcy. The ending may be the most disheartening of the movie as it has Olivia trying to make sense of her life; really powerful and truthful scene with a great performance by Arquette.
Linklater is also a masterful storyteller who excels in bringing out the angst of people of all ages, no matter who they are. He knows how to bring real life situations out in the forefront and portraying them in a way that is unbelievably realistic. Boyhood may be the most beautiful story that I have seen from a film all year. It's so encompassing and inclusive that it would be impossible for none of it to touch you emotionally. The simplicity it showed and the dedication it showed to portray it to the fullest makes it one of the most developed and comprehensive stories in a long while. From moving to a new house, new school, starting over, divorce, schmuck bosses, graduation, the opposite sex, creative expression, getting a terrible haircut and so on. It reaches for everything all at once and comes down with all of them in hand. 
I easily found more than one aspect of the story to be relatable to me which touched me more so than any other film has this year. I myself hate getting haircuts but had it nowhere near as bad as Mason who was forced by an authoritative jerk step dad. It's hard to find another film like  that where it transports your feelings and emotions from a particular event and have it play out in a similar manner more or less on screen. The ups and downs including all the middles in the film makes them even more awkward, funny, heartfelt and introspective watching them from one who has experienced them. He captures what makes up the human spirit and what it means to be alive, in the moment. Like many of his films, he praises individuality while still being a part of society and being mindful not to include overly political and religious stances. It lets them happen and come about naturally and doesn't make too big a deal about it when it is brought up. 
It packs in as much drama, heart, humor, resonance, ethos, pathos and logos as humanly possible while covering everything that a young kid would go through from drugs, alcohol and staying out late but approached in a relaxed manner or intentionally left off screen so the mom would deal with it. Everything that is happening to these characters effects them and molds them to whom they eventually will be, not forgetting that a certain thing happened. There was much immense care taken to make sure that the lives that are shaped don't feel thrown together or without reason. Linklater wrote the script as he went along every year and made adjustments to the characters based on what happened to the actors they portrayed. With a film such as this, changes are simply inevitable and warranted. The story perfectly executed and built up to highlight the monumental moments of one's young life. With every year being full of superheroes, wild action, sappy rom-coms and goofy comedies, it's refreshing to see some normal people portrayed on screen and not have the story build up to something grand and epic. 
It was fun going back in time and revisiting some of the biggest pop culture moments of the last decade. It was like a three hour time capsule of all that America has seen and experienced. It's similar to those stupid but addicting I Love The (insert decade here) anthologies from VH1. With every year being a new chapter in Mason's life, I found out what year it was by what event was going on. Whether it was the Obama election, midnight sale of Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince and seeing Roger Clemens pitch for the Huston Astros. The soundtrack was also excellent, taking in some of the best indie bands and some of my favorites of the last decade like The Flaming Lips, Arcade Fire and Yo La Tengo. Knowing that it's nearly three hours, it really didn't feel like it as soon as I got into it. I happened to pause it exactly near the middle at around eighty minutes or so, took a break and went right back into it. I honestly couldn't get enough of it and wouldn't mind if it went longer.
Few films offer an experience while watching it, but that is exactly what Boyhood is. It is simply something that cannot easily be put to words and has to be seen to realize its extensive vision and grandiose scope. One should not judge it by a short viewing and must allow it to fully encapsulate you so you see it for what it truly is. There has to be ample time for it to sink in and you are allowed to process everything that you have seen. While there is a lot, once you see the big picture, you see how enthralling it is. Mason Sr. puts life in great perspective when he breaks down a track list for The Black Album, going from partying, faith, love and pain to appreciating what we have. He stresses the balance that is needed for greatness, saying that's what made The Beatles the greatest band in the world, and it's something that everyone should utilize to achieve whatever they wanted. Mason bookends with a perspective of his own on how it's not about seizing the moment but letting the moment seize you. It's not about collecting moments that are supposedly required by others to succeed but not being so obsessed by attaining these goals that you miss out on other possibly more important things like happiness. In a film full of theologies, it doesn't stress one over the other and allows the viewer to believe what the best course is. By seeing Mason's perspective shift and mold with time, he appears to achieve what he has always wanted in life and in turn what we all want to achieve. For a film that has no plot or theme, it's the most eye opening and revelatory that movies have been in ages. Five classic Pontiac GTO's out of five.

There's something quite special about Richard Linklater's Boyhood. This isn't like anything else you've seen in the cinema. And I know what you might be thinking - is this like a documentary? No, this is not filmed like a documentary. No, this is not a mockumentary. You're not going to see a Modern Family-like camera setting, you're simply not. This is simply a story about a boy, or rather a story about one kid growing up. Now, this movie throws you some curveballs. Some might be led to believe this film is about parents splitting up - it's not. Some might be led to believe this film is about a violent stepfather - it's not really. Sure there are elements of the aforementioned plotpoints. With that having been said, this film is simply about life. It's about a single-mother, her disobedient daughter, sibling-rivalries, learning to allow your parents to move on from eachother. This is life.

For the full review, go here: http://imjeffreyrex.com/television-literature-and-film/reviews/2014-2/review-boyhood-2014/

Richard Linklater's '12 years in the making' film is relatable, and depicts real life characters and problems.

Yes, 'Boyhood' is scattered and as natural as life itself.  The actors play people that are tangibly real, and we see them grow and change.  My problem with the movie is not about plausibility or reality.  Both of these traits are saturated in the movie in spades.  What I object to is that a movie should resonate more:  It should be profound or poignant or entertaining.  'Boyhood' is too mundane.  I feel as though I just watched a two-and-three-quarter-hour home video, and to a degree I had some empathy for the characters, but I felt they could have tightened the proceedings in a more judicious way.  I admire how 'Boyhood' reflects real life, and its observations are spot on, but they needed to do more to keep me wanting to politely tell the intimate host of this home movie that I really needed to get back home.  The soundtrack is the epitome of good taste, but the proceedings are often tedious.
A really powerful movie about growing up

Boyhood is, obviously, a very personal film for director Richard Linklater. A moving epic filmed over the course of 12 years, sprawling with human emotion and capturing life, Boyhood is a flawless masterpiece with a stellar cast, including an Oscar-winning performance by Patricia Arquette.

Boring, over-long, and lacking in plot. A boy ages from age 6 to 18, and over the course of 165 minutes, very little happens that is interesting or engaging.  Filming over 12 years with the same actors ends up being just a gimmick.  Should not have even been nominated for best picture.
Cool concept, mundane story.

Initially Boyhood may come across as a bit underwhelming, as people may go in expecting hard-hitting drama with several emotionally explosive plot points, but it offers none of that. What it does offer is one of the most naturalistic and humanist pieces of cinema to be seen in many years. Richard Linklater wants to present life in its purest cinematic form - abstract, slight, and coherent, it gives you this little boy and lets you watch his life as he grows up. It doesn't offer a viewpoint, a perspective, or toned up Hollywood powerhouse drama, and upon reflection, you will really come to respect that. Supporting performances from Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke are staggeringly nuanced, with all interactions feeling genuine, no questions asked. It's the kind of film where less is more, by not offering a viewpoint, not rushing to heartbreaking dramas, being patient and filming over 12 years to simply portray a child growing up, Linklater proves himself as one of the most thoughtful and nourishing directors in the history of cinema.

Though it's an outstanding work of film, full of outstanding performances, and a one-of-a-kind 12 year production, I must say that in the end I was unsatisfied by the second half. The film takes all it has going for it and sort of slows to a boring stop without much of a "coming of age" actualization. Not only that, but it takes a weird turn with how our main character turns out. He gets into a weird and unwelcoming personality and that just made it hard to enjoy at the credits began to roll. Even still, I won't deny Linklater's art along with the outstanding performances from Arquette and Hawk. (74%)
"The moment seizes us."

Boyhood is, by far, my favorite film of 2014. It's similar to movies like "Stand By Me" in the sense that everyone can relate to it. And while its about 20 minutes too long (Mason Sr.'s speech at the bar or Mason's drive to college would have made for a much better ending) and it can be boring at times, it uses it to its advantage. If it had big, outlandish moments, it wouldn't feel as relateble, thus losing its premise all together. Boyhood is the story of the every-kid. And I couldn't be happier to see a movie like this, a movie that tells a real, natural story, to finally become a reality.

Almost three hours of boredom and absolute brilliance. So understated you completely forget there is any acting going on. Like watching a documentary. One of the more original flicks I've seen in ages. I loved Birdman but this movie deserved best picture.
In a world of fast food films Boyhood is as satisfying and nourishing as a three course meal
A mopey six year old grows up to be a mopey 18 year old.  This film is a plot-less, unremarkable slice of life.  It's got a cringe worthy ending, to boot.  Ehh!
Phenomenal absolutely phenomenal what a great movie I hope they make another one like this what a creative artistic film
Boring. Boring. Boring. It was made for 12 years, okay but it is really boring. Forgettable characters mixed with dramatic acting. Overhyped mess.

I know I'm going to catch a lot of hate for this, but I just couldn't seem to find anything special about Boyhood. The idea is simple: Follow a kid as he grows up. But the execution is very unique, which is following the same actor through his life. I get what everyone went for, I just didn't get all wrapped up in it. To me, Ellar Coltrane was a much better kid actor in the beginning than he was as a teenager/adult towards the end. There never seemed to be any smooth transition from who he was as a kid to who he became. The same for the mother, and especially the sister, who seemed to really get the short end of the stick on character development. The real standout, in my opinion, was Ethan Hawke. Watching his natural progression from wild and free dad who is still trying to be involved in the lives of his kids to a more settled down and almost world weary father was a nice transition. Other than that, I give credit to those involved for sticking with the unique filming plan, but I didn't find much special with the film.

When I heard about Boyhood and the actor grown up on film I  was not impressed, but then I watched and my jawed dropped. Boyhood is a well crafted roller coaster ride were you get to see them grow up on the fun journey. Grade A

The whole 12 years of shooting is very cool.  Yet, the movie itself is a boring and very clichéd plot with very little to be remembered.  Besides growing older Mason does not change very much.  Plus, his sister could be removed from the entire plot and nothing would change much.  Its an interesting look into a family life that seems to be plagued by drunk dads.  Ethan Hawk does a good job in his role and his character does develop and become better throughout.  Yet, everybody else just felt like they were just there and I just did not care about them at all.  Personally I didn't like Mason that much to be honest and felt he got more boring the older he got.  Ethan Hawk was kind of cool but nobody else, even himself a little is interesting, this lies in a problem of a cast of characters I just did not care about.  The development is very little besides them just getting older.  Overall not a bad movie, just a boring one, even writing this a day after watching the film I struggle to describe what actually happened to these characters.  Its like watching somebody's life, but just throw some drunk dads in there to spice it up and besides that most peoples lives are boring, just like this flick.

Boyhood is another exercise in pretending something is better than just an experiment. While a story might not be that important to some of you, it's the primary reason we watch movies in the first place. It may not mean as much to us as we get older, but it's probably because of our inherent need for something that feels fresh. However, trying something new (documentaries like Hoop Dreams have done this before) doesn't make it good. A story usually helps, but Linklater would rather have his characters spew philosophical musings and never actually go anywhere.

In the end, the movie might be interesting on some level in watching to see how the children turn out. On the other hand, you can have children yourself, and it'll probably be far more fulfilling.

A movie that is better in it's concept than it's execution.  It is interesting from a movie making stand point, but in terms of the quality of the plot, I simply did not find myself engaged.  One positive is that it is very much a love letter to the state of Texas and those who live in the state might be fascinated as the character essentially criss-crosses many areas within it.
No plot to speak of, boring as paint drying.

Perhaps more so for to the younger 20's or upper teenage years, the films is easy to relate for the audience.  The viewer can easily see themselves in character of the protagonist.  While the supporting casts seems to be in and out of the film, each main supporting actor or actress plays their role brilliantly.  Along with a very appealing soundtrack, the movie is exceptionally well done for all the years it took to make.
Original and natural, it has a good scope.

Sure, it's cool that it was filmed over a span of 12 years and you get to see the cast grow up/older. I also liked Ethan Hawke, he did a great job and so did the drunk guy. It's also awkward and amusing that the main kid doesn't move his arms when he walks. Other than that there was no plot to this movie and nothing happens in it either. They sure could have picked more interesting kids to film!

Utterly groundbreaking in the filmmaking front but surprisingly enthralling in its examination of real-life complexities, Boyhood is a harrowing study of human development that sets an impossible standard for future coming-of-age films to follow.
One of those movies that will make you all 'feely' inside long after you've left the theater.
This is the best film of 2014.  a masterpiece and groundbreaking in a unique approach of filmmaking.
this is officially the saddest movie i have ever seen.
Never saw a movie like this.  He grows up before your eyes.
A very lengthy movie but surprisingly there was no dull moment

A film shot for 12 years made me sit and watch the film. The film captured the moments very well telling about the slice of life. However, no story in the film was the drawback. The growth of the boy and the girl and the change in the character was lovely. A feel good film to watch.
I was always thinking something was going to happen but it never did.  Kind of made me sad.
A movie that took 12 years to bore me to death.

I can understand the hype because (to my knowledge at least -- I'm no movie connoisseur), this sort of coming of age movie has never been done before. I think the concept is great, however, I found the story kind of disjointed... much like life, really. I think this is part of the appeal.. it doesn't follow a set path, there's no rigid storyline that follows, and the lives of the characters change about as unpredictably as our own. I just found that there was nothing really noteworthy about the lives of these people...  besides the fact that they are gun toting (I suppose this is a Texan thing), raging alcoholic lovers but it almost seemed like that part of the plot was forced so that the viewers would maintain interest. I think what resonated most for me was when Patricia Arquette sends Mason to college and she says something along the lines of, is this all there is?? Is this all life is... a series of events and then you die? (not at all a direct quote). Her words were kind of haunting in their own way because it's kind of true...  and interestingly that's what I got out of the movie... this is life... just a series of events... I don't think that's what the director was trying to make out of it but that's what I got. The half star is brownie points for filming for 12 years straight.

This film managed to make me feel as though I was one of the characters going through the varied moments of my life. I identified with the boy growing up in this film as well as the single mother just trying to "get it right."
an amazing journey through lives and from all angles. where there is no good and bad and right and wrong - it's just life. we go through it. great acting by all.

I don't really feel like I got to know the main character well. His story is not very captivating. The mom is more interesting. Patricia Arquette gave a good performance, but not good enough to be award winning.The movie is also way to long.

Very original concept as a story which revolves around a family in particular the story of Mason. The movie was shot over 12 years and covers the whole boyhood growing up. Great acting makes this a pleasure to watch

A well acted , nicely filmed yet tedious gimmick of a film. It's like a reality show featuring an unremarkable family doing unremarkable things and I guess that's the point. Maybe it will give other people the feels, but I'm just not feeling it.
Worst movie ever.  Somebody poke my eyes out.

This movie is an absolute disaster from beginning to end. Do not believe the ratings, clearly the ratings are doctored by computer bots or something. I wasted an hour of my life before I fled the scene on this dumpster fire. I only write this review as to help you avoid the same dark and horrible fate. 

Sincerely,
Concerned Human

P.S. I had to go to the eye doctor after this movie because of all the damage done to my eyes. I am doing better now, thank you for your concern.
Initially caught me off guard as it had the Seinfeld complex, not really about anything...touching film, it's life realistically portrayed
slow start. good story. fascinating film work. very cohesive.
The studio should be applauded for funding this bold long term project
Somewhat interesting, because of the idea, but more interesting in idea than in actual execution. And waaaaay too long.
Even with nothing much going on we still age.
It's a very, very, very nice film, not an oscar winner, just nice!

It seems a whole life is passed when I completed the movie. Very long but interesting throughout. A bit stretched towards the end though and could have been edited a few more scenes. Ethan is my favourite actor and he keeps on impressing. All the actors played really well. The intersting fact of the movie is - it took 12 years to film it with the same cast. That's the dedication of making the movie.

A bit of a marathon at 185 minutes, nevertheless a skillfully executed, visionary effort from the Richard Linklater time-machine. Is this the film fellow Texan Terrence Malik was trying to make with "Tree of Life" and "To the Wonder"?
I got really bored. I have problems with these slow indie US movies. People loved Blue Valentine, people love Boyhood... but I do not.

What's ironic about this story is it was told in a fashion that will never be experienced again, and that's the very foundation upon which the story is built upon. Life just happens. . . you can dwell on the past, or worry about what the future holds - but you'll never truly be experiencing this life until you are living in the moment. Bravo!
Not as good as I'd heard, but still good.  An impressive achievement/commitment for everyone involved.

A really beautiful film. "A moving 12 years epic" is the introduction phrase of Boyhood, but this is one of the least important factors in a movie so complete and well done as this.

Richard Linklater was the more attentive and committed director of 2014, also he wrote the script, and it's a work made with lots of love for cinema. This movie  makes us relate it in a nice shape, without too much drama. Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette are so good and so natural in their characters and make us see, how it can deteriorate or improve the relationship between separated parents. Ellar Coltrane is extremely convincing from his childhood to adulthood.

At times the pace of the film becomes a bit overwhelming, but it's necessary because projected us the childhood and adolescence of a person.

Not everything is rosy in Boyhood, my big problem was the end, I think the best way to end this film was in the part where Mason is driving along the road with the song "Hero" in the background, but unfortunately that's not the final scene.

In conclusion, this is a jewel of the seventh art, although only shines in the hands of those who can understand it.
That took a long time to make congrats!
Philosophically significant, this movie depicts boyhood at its truest and is not overdone, nor is it underplayed. Very good social commentary.

Not perfect by any means but remarkably spectacular on so many levels. Captures life's essence through every character. What a brilliant piece of work. Unique film experiences like this one not to be taken for granted as they are rare. Director/writer has given his audience a true gift to watch.
instils meaning and joy into the ordinary

If this movie was twenty minutes shorter, I would've given it 5 stars. Aside from its overlong stay, this film hit home in so many different ways. Just like 'Ordinary People', 'August Osage County', and 'Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore', Richard Linklater's achievement "Boyhood" left the audience in awe, in nostalgia, and in empathy, because we've all had experiences nearly identical to the experiences shown in this film. It's gritty at times, witty at others, and real 100% of its nearly three-hour run time. Patricia Arquette deserved her many accolades. 
If Tatum O'Neal won, let alone nominated, for "Paper Moon", I think this movie's lead [Ellar Coltrane] should've been nominated for best lead actor. His performance is one of the more memorable in last year's shelves of well-developed character studies. 'Mason, Jr.' was 10x more of a memorable character than Cooper's "Chris Kyle" portrayal and Carrell's near-supporting role as real-life Jean Du Pont. 
My only concern is this film's length, as I said before. Aside from that, I loved this movie! Great performances led by a great script and great direction!

I absolutely hated this movie. I thought it was so incredibly boring and slow. The concept is terrific, but would have been much better executed with a better plot. Of course, the movie was about watching a child grow up through an average life and wasn't supposed to be your standard movie plot, but it just made for a terribly boring film.
94% on my Tomatometer.

A decent film all together with great acting and a fresh and risky concept to film making. Though there was something that bothered me about the film, it ends up focusing more it seems on family dynamics and the characters around the main character of Mason. The actor who plays Mason is fine, but I think he is not given much to work with, either due to the fault of the writing or the directing. There's not much of an opportunity to see what is going on in Mason's mind. He's portrayed as a very blank character who is just coasting through life, he's met with various challenges that he never seems to face head on. He more or less shrugs it off.
I feel that in the end the film could have focused on more of what Mason was going through, the film is called Boyhood afterall.
One of the most beautiful and well made movies I have ever seen. Very unique and special piece of cinema which I believe is one of or if not the best film of 2014.
exhausting and pointless

This film had great potential, but, in my opinion, was completely ruined by the insertion of overt political propaganda.   

Early in the movie, and irrelevantly to the plot, I was treated to harsh criticism of George Bush.   I'd hoped this was just an anomaly, and that the director would resist further childishness and focus on the film.   But, shortly after, I was subjected to swooning praise of Barack Obama, with the family members engaging in their civic duty to post Obama political signs, while stealing McCain signs.   

There was lots of gushing for Obama in the "sign scene," but the director wasn't satisfied staying positive: one of the children asked if he could place a sign in someone's yard, and the owner verbally abused the child, going as far as to say he could shoot the child if he wanted to.   Then, it was pointed out that the man had a confederate flag in his yard.  I can only infer that the director wishes us to believe that anyone who does not support Obama must be an angry, racist, potential murderer.

I was struggling to look the other way up to this point, foolishly hoping that something could be salvaged from the movie, in spite of the petty propaganda. Then, the father used the pregnancy of Sarah Palin's daughter as a "teachable moment" for his daughter, stressing how important it is to avoid unwanted pregnancy.   

At that point I gave up.   An effort was made to get a refund, which sadly failed.    I see absolutely nothing wrong with a director destroying his art with the injection of propaganda like this, as long as I don't have to pay for it (I don't, of course, and should have done more research before purchasing this movie).

Just a wonderful tale of someone growing up shot over 12 years for the Star Wars generation. Ellar Coltrane is a very likeable lead as an American Adrian Mole - a real risky casting baring in mind the concept behind the shoot. Ethan Hawke is a very likeable dad though Arquette gets all the plaudits for her performance. Interesting that the cast visit a Harry Potter premiere because this owes much to that franchises filming schedule. I wonder if there's a 'Manhood' in the works?

Bill Welbrock: You don't like me much, do you Mason? That's okay, neither do I.

story of growing up as seen through the eyes of a child named Mason, who literally grows up on screen before our eyes as the movie was filmed over 12 years...it's the selective but cumulative use of seemingly arbitrary but significant experiences that gives Boyhood its distinctive character and impressive weight....There's not a great theme, a great performance or even a great scene in Boyhood but it still turns out to be a great picture but not a classic or ahead of times or something like that(which was its weakness as well its strength going into the oscars i feel)...a must watch for all the punkass kids and for the rest of not so punk/"cool" kids,you can probably figure out why they are so much punk than you while watching this movie ;)

The filming method is so unique and exciting that I could overlook its flaw. Because the direction focuses on realism over exaggerated drama, the pacing seems to creep along, so you need to be patient in order to appreciate the benefits of the storytelling. Filmed for several weeks each year for 12 years, the loose script had a central theme and a strong idea for the movie's final scene. Each new year's footage would be dependent on how the previous year's turned out and any input the actors had to share from their personal lives. There are countless moments where you're left thinking: "how did they get such a natural and loaded reaction from a 7-year old?" As a whole, it is ambitious and detailed, while opening doors for similar production options going forward.

Unreal concept, and overall great movie, but to be honest I had a hard time relating to the film. My friend who I saw it with fell in love and felt a strong connection with the character, but I personally had trouble connecting as strongly as I would have liked.

The only cool thing about this movie is the fact that it was filmed over 12 years and you get to see the same actors getting old... But it's so not worth the 2 hours and 44 minutes you waste watching it!
I appreciate what they did to make this movie, it was well acted and held my attention... but this is no best picture candidate.

Awesome how (spoiler alert) everyone ages. Brilliant by the film makers and a bit nerve racking to make I'm sure, had anyone died in real life during the making, it would have truly ruined the film. 90/100
I would have rather heard the story of the one Mexican youth that was fixing pipes and became a manager at a restaurant than to have watched the life of some emo kid and his weird sister. Just saying

Really enjoyed this movie. Stirred up nostalgia of the past as well as revealing windows into the present. A movie that makes you want to call your parents as soon as it's over. Reminds you that time slips by quickly.

I thought this was quite an achievement. Without evening considering the script and story, I found it fascinating just watching the actors change over the years.
I can see how it wouldn't be to everyone's tastes but if you're a fan of Richard Linklater's Before Sunrise / Sunset / Midnight trilogy and that type of film making then I think you'll like this too.  The second half of the film, as the boy becomes a teenager and then a man certainly resembles his trilogy as the character starts to wonder of his place in the world, just like the older Jesse and Celine do across 3 movies.
Also, great soundtrack that serves as a useful timeline throughout the film.

Putting the incredible methods aside,  the story is quite straightforward as we follow Mason from childhood to adulthood.  As with a number of Linklater's films,  this is more about capturing little moments in time rather than a big epic story.  The cast are terrific,  the direction is assured and the soundtrack is great.
Ive been having nightmares ever since I watched this movie.  The nightmares are that it will never end.  Almost 3 hours of absolutely nothing.
Despite the 5 star reviews, I find it too draggy and slow pace, but saved by the strong performance of its casts...
Amazing film that shows the everyday struggles with getting older and wiser.
Can see why Boyhood got an Oscar Nomination. The film was shot over 12 years, of the SAME characters. I thought it was very good. Told a story of a lad in his teen years ie adolescence.

Compelling from start to finish, Boyhood is brimming with humour, humanity, nostalgia and is ultimately so much more than its filmed-over12-years gimmick. Though that is really cool too. This movie explores the journey of adolescence with honesty yet somehow still manages to be very entertaining.
Random scenes of random behaviors with no story or focus. Oh, yes, it was filmed over a period of years. Hooks into cultural artifacts and events don't make up for a lack of point of view.

One of the best movies I have seen in a long time.  The music alone moved me to tears and that was supported by the plot that, while predictable, was excellent.  You need to know how to listen to music with your emotion to fully appreciate this movie.  If you cannot do that, and I believe that is an advanced skill, then you won't get the most out of this movie.  Still, you can still enjoy it!  Highly recommended.
very long and some aspects are genuinely relatable to all boys.
How did this get rated so highly, sentimental tripe, after 1hr 20 mins I had to turn it off, unemotional and literally showed snapshots of generic growing up situations. Boring.
Beginning scene and soundtrack is very epic.
Cool concept of the same cast set over 12 years, but the film itself was a bit of a non event. All it really did was follow the boy growing up.

Liked the beginning and the...
Simply put, I thought it was one of the biggest wastes of my time
I've never seen anything like it. This is a monumental, transcendental movie-going experience. Richard Linklater is a genius.
I raised 3 boys, this movie was boring and mundane. I 'get' that it was filmed over 12 years, Bravo.

Interesting concept that required lots of commitment to realize. Very real and sincere, with characters developed maybe too organically for my liking, and somehow fell flat. Not so sure all was worth it!

What's in Life? Nothing but small, trivial, minor details of every single day.  By the time the movie ends, it turns my life into a movie. I am living my life and filming a movie where I am the leading actress!

Unlike any movie I've seen. Portrays scenes from childhood that I experienced almost verbatim, and I'm sure will resonate with many male viewers as well. Ethan Hawke puts in a yeoman's performance and the female lead knocks it out of the park as well. The only downside is that the kid goes through an annoying emo phase and a bit of an awkward acting phase that occasionally stops the movie's flow.
A look at how people grow and develop over time. You literally watch the kids grow up. The movie does a good job of capturing life's moments, but it was a bit too long and lagged.
Unique perspective seeing what shapes a young boy into a man.  Still it felt disjointed at times and a few moments of bad acting mixed in.

Stunning movie that I'll be thinking about for days. Fantastic depiction of 5-18 years old, from Harry Potter to university. The good intentions but flawed mistake ridden parents.

Everyday life is brought into focus in a film that breaks the rules but does a great job of cleaning it up. Boyhood is a magnificent drama that was shot ongoing for 12 years. That in itself is a revaluation. I have a warn spot for the actors and actresses more so than the filmmakers. As great as the story was told, I feel it is a greater story guy that these characters were  by b such willing and patient people that had the confidence and willlpower to make it work. A great watch and revolutionary film. Don't miss it, however, don't print it as Best Picture. Originality can be outdone by style
 and substance.

I'd rate this a solid 3 1/2 for the directing, plot development, etc.  The aspect I didn't like as much is the movie portrays a hugely dysfunctional childhood (you feel for the main character), but it seems to suggest it is typical - what every kid could expect in and from boyhood.  America is in a very sorry state if that is true.
This was phenomenally underwhelming. I need to stop paying attention to over-hyped films. Do you yourself a favour and give it a miss

They took a normal day in somebodies world filmed it and made it a movie.  Welcome to what I watch movies to escape.  A truly good idea (12 years) but made a below par movie with an overly paid-off or underqualified review crew all designed to waste 3 hours of my life and $20 because it was uninteresting to the point that I left and rewound to guarantee that I Never had to watch this terrible, undramatic, anticlimactic, empty, movie that overall left me thoroughly convinced that people don't have any existence and need a movie to show what a family is or critics just have some overly exaggerated sense of movie creation where people that pay to watch don't understand and the longer you take to make a movie increases the critics review. I didn't enjoy it as much as I anticipated after all the nominations and all the hype.

Never before has a film with so little plot been so good.  I loved the movie.  It was a journey that was worth taking and it was quite thoughtful.  There was no real dramatic question to be answered, but still it was compelling to see this time capsule unveil a life before our eyes and bring up situations and events that are commonly experienced and develop character and bring forward thoughts about how we become who we become.  It was lovely.
Interesting to watch for obvious reasons, wouldn't call it great though.
The most overrated film of 2014 since Locke! They had 12 years to film it yet still managed to forget an actual plot!
12 years with the same cast, that is quite an achievement for sure but I wish there was more to it than that. It was an okay family movie if you eliminate that fact. Regular.

It's a great and ambitious project, but it's boring and nearly 3 hours long.  It's about the events in our life that affect us. The common, every day events that most of us have experienced.  I can watch a movie of common, everyday moments for about 30 minutes, after that I'm like, "I get it! We're all affected by a series of events, some big and some small, from our youth."  Snooze.  One standout from this film was the soundtrack.  Tons of good jams from the last 12 years, many of them so memorable to me of an exact time and place and album.  I could tell you what year almost all of those songs came out, right off of the top of my head.
boyhood is a true story about life

This movie was great. It covered a lot of ground, and seemed to hit home on some real life issues faced by many families around the globe. I will be sure to recommend this to anyone asking for a "must-see" flick.
Very clever film with an amazing set of characters, thoroughly enjoyed even if I found the last 30 mins to be a slight too slow. Recommended highly.
One of my favorite movies of all time. It's not something you would want to watch too often, but it is a must see and has the ability to make you reflect on your entire life.
In my view, one of the best films of the year. Should paint with force at the Oscars. Film about family conflicts, adolescence etc. Made in 13 years with the same actors.
I LOVE THIS MOVIE SO MUCH!

It's important for anyone going in to understand the work that went into 'Boyhood'. 12 years of filming gives this a genuine feel to it (especially with the development of these characters), which is important as this is more emotional based than story driven. I have heard some refer to this as 'boring', but I think more mature audiences can find enough to identify with or at least admire to get through it no problem.  If I were to name an actual flaw, it would be that I don't find that there is too much to come back to for repeated viewings at least not in short intervals, but this is still a must see for any fan of film at least once.

Neck and neck with Birdman for the finest film of 2014, Richard Linklater's Boyhood is an ambitious film that I deeply resonated with. It's also very well acted (Particularly from Patricia Arquette, who won the Oscar for her role), and newcomers Ellar Coltrane and Lorelei Linklater got progressively better as the film went on, which is nigh impossible for child actors. The film's imposing length, was offset by my becoming mesmerized by what was in front of me. This is definitely one of the decade's finest films so far. Verdict: A+
12 years in the making made this movie create a poor chemistry between the characters, but boy was it a treat to see all those actors age with the movie. Great effort.

An achievement.  Taking a radically different approach to filmmaking, this focuses on a young boy, Mason (Ellar Coltrane), and shows how he grows up and matures through the years, from elementary school to college.  The thing that is the most impressionable about this is the unconventional craft to it; Richard Linklater has been making great movies for decades, but with Boyhood, he has made what is easily his most ambitious film to date.  Short of the Harry Potter series (to which the film even gives a nod to), I don't think anybody has ever attempted anything like this before, and even then, all eight Harry Potter movies took less cumulative time to make than the twelve years that Boyhood took.  There were no guarantees that this giant gamble was going to work out in the end.  For example, this is an intimate family drama, it's not like you can just replace an actor should they become incapacitated or worse.  Obviously, it was a bet that paid off in spades, and Boyhood is something special.  The thing that is the most remarkable about Boyhood is the scope of it all; you have to have vision in order to make everything come together on a project this expansive, and what's even more impressive is that everything about this rings personal and authentic.  While you may not know these people per se, you have people in your life that fit into these molds, which makes it very easy to relate to.  Not only do you get to see everybody here grow up, you also get to see how much has changed since 2002, like how big the cell phone boom was, as well as staples from the past, like a Nintendo DS before it was a 3DS.  This could have just as easily been called Parenthood, and this is one of the most genuine looks at divorced life.  It's always shown through the eyes of a child, and it is intriguing to watch how adults justify all of the little things to kids.  It's also really cool how you see perspectives change, like how parents are viewed almost solely as authority figures at a young age, but then, as children grow up and become real people, they look at and talk to their parents more maturely, like friends; Mason becomes increasingly more upfront with them as he grows older, and you are always interested in what comes next.  You also get to see these children grow as actors in one film, which is something you seldom ever get to witness.  What I think Boyhood is being sold short on is how good the script is; you wouldn't care as much if it was an uninteresting story, but you really get to know this entire family and grow with them.  My only minor criticism is that you do feel the length to this movie, but it is a small nitpick when you consider just how much time this is covering, and it still moves fast.  This is a really nifty experiment that you're not likely to see repeated ever again.
Personal yet epic at the same time.

While the concept of Boyhood was interesting, the movie itself was not.  I will admit it I enjoyed watching the actors naturally age and grow throughout the film, but it almost felt as though the cast lost interest in the film as it progressed. The movie failed to keep me engrossed as it carried for what seemed like 4 hours.  The only time I felt engaged in the movie was during the time with the abusive, drunk husband. This was the one time in the movie where I felt things got interesting and the acting seemed genuine.  I'm not sure why they didn't expand upon this.  Instead, the mom and her kids leave, and there it ends.  I wanted to know what happened to the other two kids, were they just left in the abusive situation?  The couple lines of dialogue about this between the mom and the girl with the annoying hair in her eyes was not enough to end this period in the boy's life.  Overall, the acting was subpar, except for Ethan Hawke who was consistent, and believable.  I don't think this was the worst movie I've ever seen, but I hesitate to call it "good".  Instead, I would rate the film as disappointing.  Maybe it's just me, but slapping together a couple days worth of filming over a 12 year period doesn't automatically make an innovative concept a great movie.

Life might be interesting in movies to make us watch them, but to see 12 years of a real person's life on screen it's not going to be very interesting. We go to school or work, we eat dinner, come home, go to bed. We get married, divorced, we fall in love, break up. When you see these 12 years being crammed into a 2 1/2 hour movie it's not so interesting. It doesn't excite you. There's nothing that actually hooks you to the screen and makes you want to continue watching it. 
This movie is epic in one way, and one way only, it actually took 12 years to film it. This could have been a coming-of-age story about a boy who you see growing up in 12 years time where there's 12 different actors playing the same boy, but then this movie wouldn't have been as epic would it?
This movie took 12 years to film just because the director wanted to use the same actor for all of the characters as they age these 12 years. Even some actors who are only in about four scenes, you still see them age throughout the movie. Despite the movie not being that gripping or exciting I find this absolutely remarkable and therefore it will always be a masterpiece.

This movie depicts something no other movie has ever shown and that is the progress of time and the change which accompanies it. Other movies may try to simulate it through make-up and CGI tricks, however it will never be so palpable as it is in Boyhood. The movie falls into a different league of filmmaking, where it gives the audience a flashback of moments from their own childhood (boyhood) life portrayed through the eyes of an adult.

Beautiful and idiosyncratic, compelling and masterful, articulate and astounding, no one man nor woman shall be the same following their viewing of Boyhood. We empathize with Mason's internal and external struggles as he copes with change, peer-pressure, nefarious people, sexual interests, and more as he travels throughout the daunting labyrinth formally known as adolescence. This film has no definite plot, and that is what is remarkable about its exceptionality; it is the small moments in life that add up. A must see!

I have to be honest - I fast forwarded through a lot of parts but still didn't miss anything.   Some of my reflections on this movie are really not about the movie per se, but instead how important it is for kids to have sounding boards in pairs of parents, friends, other family, mentors, etc.  I cried at the end when Patricia Arquette's character (the mom) said she dreaded that day when her son left for college because it put a spotlight on her life and made her question what her life has been about.  Sad really, because if a person has a true identify with life in a spiritual (not religious) way then it's not a let down when you learn we are vunerable and sort of not to important in the scheme of life.  At least that's my interpretation of that moment.

Character development is here, but older mason was dull and pretentious, and by the time Boyhood's credits rolled I was pleased to have experienced it, not blown away, making it a fantastic film making idea that won't leave a post-viewing impact.

As a concept movie, "Boyhood" definitely can be called a successful experiment. It took Richard Linklater no less than 12 years to realize this film. It's a registration of the daily life of an average American family with characters interpreted by the same actors or actresses in different life cycles. Is this an unique concept ? Unfortunately not. In 2001, the Harry Potter saga started with the main characters growing up while the story progressed. So that gimmick is already used. 

I'm also the proud owner of a whole collection of home videos I made for years with my Sony Handycam. Would the result be similar to "Boyhood" if I'd edit these nostalgic film clips into a motion picture ? No of course not, because my creation wouldn't be right. The synchronization between the different periods would be wrong. The themes wouldn't be in harmony. The continuity wouldn't be guaranteed, especially regarding the overall atmosphere. In terms of content, there might be similarities, but ultimately it simply will become a banal family documentary, dominated by triviality and platitude. What I'm trying to say is that probably there will be some who'll portray "Boyhood" as an extra-long home video, while for me it's not so evident to come to this result. Ingenious and phenomenal at the same time.

Don't expect truly earth shaking events or developments. You only witness the calmly on-going life of Mason (Ellar Coltrane). A life like most of us have experienced it. A life full of ups and downs, with its euphoric moments and sad moments. A life that forms you as a human being into the personality you'll finally be when reaching adulthood. Also Mason goes through all these stages : first a carefree teenager, school troubles, domestic problems, puberty, an exceptional father who occasionally crosses (during major and minor moments) his life, teenage love, his heart being broken and than the final step to adulthood. 12 Years interwoven with no visible indication in what time span it's happening at that time and this summarized in 165 minutes. Together with his sister Samantha (Lorelei Linklater), daughter of Richard Linklater and a teenager with an attitude, and his mother (Patricia Arquette), who won a gold medal in the Olympic discipline "choosing the wrong guys", a touching coming-of-age story unfolds itself. Afterwards you realize how volatile time is and how our life goes on with an irreversible pace.

Ellar Coltrane plays literally and figuratively the role of his life. The beginning was a little bit sluggish and lethargic. It seemed to leave him indifferent which made him act quite apathetic. But as he grows older, I appreciated his deep philosophical musings more and more. His argumentation while driving on the highway about humanity functioning in modern society as self-healing and reproducing robots, because the manufacturing of cyborgs would be too costly, I found funny but at the same time I realized that it was uncannily accurate and that there's actually a little truth in what he claims. Again something I could identify myself with. Lorelei Linklater grows into a rebellious and wayward teenager. Arquette's roundings expand as the years pass. The only one whose looks remain timeless, is that of Ethan Hawke. Although it feels as if he plays an ancillary character who pops up occasionally into the life of Mason, I found this the most beautiful role in "Boyhood" and for me the one who exerts the most influence on the development of the person Mason. A brilliant interpretation: serene, vulnerable and supportive. And maybe it's my imagination, but I thought Mason resembled more and more Hawke as he grows older. What a coincidence.

The final conclusion is that it's a brilliant concept with delightful characters who grow and unfold themselves as time progresses. So what's wrong with it than ? Absolutely nothing, except in the end it's just a dull affair. You can't say there are many startling things happening. Despite the chaotic periods Mason's mother is going through , you can't detect any real traumatic experiences. Every average family's life looks like this. And yet this film is praised to the skies. And that's because everyone sees something in it they can relate to and finally think something like "Hey, I also experienced it like that" or "Damn that happened to me also in that period". And that's the strength of "Boyhood". A mirror is held up in front of you and you'll come to one conclusion : Life is a concatenation of moments you need to enjoy fully, because there comes a time you'll realize that those moments have passed. And that's perfectly summarized by Mason's final sentence: "It's the constant moments, it's just ... it's like always right now". 

More reviews at http://opinion-as-a-moviefreak.blogspot.be

This film started very good, but for some reason I started disliking Mason after the bullying scene. But even though I disliked him for some reason Mason reminds me so much of myself mostly because he grew up in the same time period and because he grew up in a house with his sister and a single mom like I did. The differences between us are that he actually likes his dad and I've never smoked weed and I have never been a big fan of my dad and will probably NEVER get along with him. And the other difference is that his mom was someone who thought she needed to have a man in her life and she made some pretty bad choices when it came to that. This movie makes me grateful that my mom didn't make such bad dating decisions. One thing I actually loved about this movie was that the director put in some things that I found very nostalgic and seriously tear jerking even though they weren't meant to be. The fact that he had Mason watching Dragon Ball Z and that he was a huge fan of it was something I found awesome. Because I felt that on some level I was actually connecting with Mason over pop-culture back in the 90's and 2000's. And his hatred for the Brittney Spears song that his sister sings is something I could relate to a lot as well. Because my sister loves to sing and she has sang some pretty annoying songs over the years. The Directors attention to pop culture back in the early days when the internet was not as big as it is now was accurate and well just the fact that I felt nostalgia watching the movie is something I enjoyed very much about the movie. However as soon as we start to get into his later years of life I started to dislike Mason and was wanting to send that disrespectful little turd to military school. The most admirable thing about the movie though is the fact that Richard Linklater spent a HUGE chunk of his life and his actors lives making this movie. And it really is something to watch the characters grow older over the years to learn and to experience new things. And the director could have just hired new actors to play the older roles, but he chose to go the way that he did and he did is so well. I admire him for being able to do something like this. And on one final note. While I wasn't a fan of most of the characters and how they treated each other what I did like was how they perfectly ended the movie. When his mom tells about her life and all she has to look forward to. And then Mason's soon to be girlfriend we see that time is both an illusion and something that is always present in our lives. We change, we grow and we learn more as time goes on. I feel as though that has been my journey for most of my life. Learning and growing in my walk of life. Great movie but really unlikable characters.
