Bolt, This is the End, The Avengers, Under the Skin, Avatar and Bambi; all critically lauded and certified fresh films over 80%. Most have been called "excellent" and "visionary." Some even called "masterpieces." Most have had a dramatic impact on cinema, the way we approach films and our need for escapism and a desire to question the intriguing. And, all of these films, I have rated poorly (or at least average). Yet, none of this compared to the experience of watching Boyhood.  The Academy Award nominations and wins, golden globes, critics choice awards, BAFTAs, critics guild awards, sundance and according to rotten tomatoes, 256 fresh critic reviews with an average score of 9.3. Called "the best film of the decade" and "a sprawling investigation of the human condition." Internationally, the film appeared on more than 500 critics best year list, with almost 150 ranking Boyhood number one. On metacritic, the film has a rating of 100. The highest rating for an initial release on the site, at least since 1999. 

The project itself was ambitious,  filming these actors over a 12 year period. The technical scope is also rather impressive and the originality of the script seemed to scream everything that draws me to a film. And yet, Boyhood was a major disappointment.  I can appreciate and admire so much about the film's aims and significance to the genre, but I am one of the few people on Earth that will argue this film is not flawless.  And, in my opinion- I really must emphasise that, its far from being a masterpiece.

First and foremost,  the visual style which was disengaging from the start. I know some may say I am nitpicking but, throughout the film's 12 year scope, the style and the tone and the aesthetics remained as mundane and simplistic as possible. And I'm sorry,  but that isn't the reason why I see films. Perhaps that's the point, but it didn't work for me.

Next then, the acting. People have praised and praised and praised the acting, saying its real and authentic. So, why did I think Patricia Arquette's performance was dull and depressing, not deserving of, well, any award? Just because she was in a good film, doesn't mean she was good herself. Next, and this is a really biggy, Mason. He was a terrible actor, being all depressed and once again emotionless.  His sister Samantha was just as irritating and there were many times where I felt no sympathy for any of the three main characters. However, Ethan Hawke was very good and he is always worth a look in any film, although I'd criminally argue that his Predestination is better.

One of the major issues was, along with the aesthetics, the cinematography and editing. It just seemed so clichéd and there was nothing overly impressive about it. Its not bad by any means,  but it seems to me that it should be exquisite in a masterpiece.  The editing was sloppy and at times unforgivable when considering how much effort was actully exhausted in shooting the film. Once again, I think that it could and should have evolved over 12 years.

The biggest flaw of this film is the script. I know for many, this is an exceptionally deep film but I failed to grasp any sort of thrill or excitement or anger or fear or any sort of emotion whilst watching this. And sadly, the best and most eventful parts of this film were at the start. By the time the film concluded at a staggering 2hrs and 45 minutes, I had felt as if the film had dragged for over an hour, offering no tense moments or cleverly written twists . Richard Linklater is a very good and quite ambitious director. But I felt cheated by this, and I expected better, from an Academy Award nominated and critically lauded film.

But the tone was all wrong. At times, the scenes were so dramatic and involving with its cast, almost leaning to melodrama.  Yet in others, I felt as static and stilted as if I was meant to enjoy watching people talk about star wars. It seemed as if Linklater failed to succumb to one form or the other. As if he was picking an icecream topping, and just put both skittles and mint on top. A film which should have left me in sheer astonishment,  left me wondering how I could ever reclaim almost 3 hours lost.

I guess I also had no interest rewatching someone else's entire childhood because I didnt care. Watching a child grow in such a depressing and unchanging way is not my idea of entertainment. I cared not, about the characters or the story they were telling or any part of this mess. And thats the real issue here. All I was waiting for was some dramatic plot twist, something that would drastically affect Masons entire life. By the time 2 hours had rolled over, I conceded I would never get that. This film has truly made me question whether I am out of touch with films. But I will stand my ground, because I can say with great confidence,  I will never want to watch this again

Wait, it took 12 years to make! Which is interesting, but as much a gimmick as CGI. I mean TV shows can take much longer. Most of all the movie is predictable.A movie where every male figure that tries to teach "discipline" is a "bummer" (and often an alcoholic). Only is "cool" Dad is worthy of passing on "advice." Lots of people are p[raising Patricia Arquette. Outside of the wonderful scene where she breaks down, her performance is wholly unremarkable. Then there is the last three minutes, where our "hero" meets a cool college roommate who right after meeting him gives him drugs, takes him out to a national park, along with a single hot female, cause you know it is better to just float through life. What a joke.
It's supposed to be great. It was long, but not great IMO. I don't expect to watch it again.

This movie really deserves two ratings, one for even attempting it (5 stars) and one for the actual product (I give 2.5).  Watching the characters grow and change physically is an amazing experience, which unfortunately doesn't go anywhere that justifies the whole effort in the first place.  Mason Jr. goes from a charismatic, earnest youngster to a slouching, self-absorbed near-adult.  There are lessons we expect him to learn, apologies and admissions we expect him to make, which he never bothers with. He's too caught up in himself.  By the time he reaches fourteen or so the actor (Ellar Coltrane) seems to have lost interest in the project anyway.

What's really troubling about this movie is this: Why make a movies about boyhood that boys can't watch (not without fast-forwarding through the rough parts).  It reminds me of "Where the Wild Things Are" which took a kid's book and turned it in to an adult psychodrama.  

Mason Jr. is really just an observer of the world around him. He doesn't grow or mature morally. He just gets beaten down and world weary and more self-absorbed. He never hugs or kisses his mom or dad or thanks them for raising him, he just in the end runs away to college and joins another band of slackers who probably think the world isn't good enough for them either.  

What's the lesson here for boys?  I watched it with my two sons (13 and 11).  I had hoped it would be a springboard for discussion, and it was a little.  But Linklater was so interested in confirming his slacker, stoner. artsey mentality that he forgets to take responsibility for the message he was sending to kids.  I likes young Mason Jr. Old Mason Jr. was a pain in the rear.
The concept in which this film was made is a wonderful idea. The film itself my husband and I found SO mundane and extremely boring.

I highly recommend this to those in my generation. Linklater perfectly captures the essence of growing up in the 2000's while reminding us how fast time flies. Never have I been so emotionally connected to a film.
Ethan Hawke gives a great performance.

At first I completely loved this movie. I praised the incredible idea and the amazing effort that was put into this huge production. But that's about it: Boyhood ends being an excellent concept, but barely anything else. Although Arquette's and Hawke's performances are incredibly moving, the writing of every character felt empty. You can see Coltrane is really trying to make sense of Mason, but the film doesn't ever feel like it's making its point clear. Anyway it was alright in the end I guess.

There are two types of people when it comes to this film. They either love it or they hate it. Personally, it is my favourite film of all time. It is not only a great technical achievement, it is also well-acted, thought-provoking, poignant film that I really identify with. As the film goes over its twelve year span, I really feel that Mason and I grew up the same way. And I also feel that his philosophies, which are criticized more than anything, are also on par with mine. 20/10. Amazing film and highly recommended.

There's many things to say about this movie. Let me start by saying that it was really beautiful to see the characters age so naturally in a world where some other movies would just try and recreate aging with CGI. 

But on the flip side, the acting wasn't the best, the script was terrible, it was way too long, and this "it took 12 years to make" gimmick isn't enough to save it. 

However, Ethan Hawke's performance as the children's likable father was sort of a saving grace in my eyes. Patricia Arquette was good too, but not as good as Ethan Hawke.

This movie is garbage. All it has going for it is the 12 years gimmick.

Nothing happens, and the charactes are bland and lifeless.

Boyhood just didn't work for me. I don't get the whole fuss about the whole filming over 12 years, because I can't believe they couldn't have come up with a better story for this boy in the twelve year time span they had! The story follows a boy's life with his mom and sometimes with his divorced dad as they just go around the place looking for a new person to cal daddy. The story has no true conflict and what makes it worse is the fact that they tried to add the conflict with all the abusive dads, bills falling over their heads, and just general family troubles that I could care less about. I also don't understand the internal conflict going inside of mason. Many of things he says as a teen just fly over my head because they don't make the least bit of sense. Also the natural aging just doesn't make a difference to me. I bet they would look exactly the same if they used some software, make-up, or different actors to show off the age. Also the end was one of the worst in movie history for me. He enters college, goes out hiking with some strangers and just sits and says some line, and then it ends. I mean I know it called Boy-Hood, but they couldn't have found a better spot than just his family STILL in the middle of poverty and just entering the next big step of his life that would have been way more interesting than his boy-hood. I would not recommend this, because of the unfocused and uninteresting plot, and the fact the aging makes no difference. I know others see the aging as a huge difference, but I don't.
Very disappointing. I thought it would be a great story but no. It survived on the basis of its extraordinarinous. and the ending was like, really? That's it?
I don't really like Drama genre. But this movie was really amazing.

This movie deserves a very high score! Just thinking how this film took long enough to be made... And the transitioning is really exceptional! The maturity of the character has been very well-presented throughout the film. It's very inspiring.
What a great movie!  So happy I watched this.

WARNING: You may have a nostalgia-gasm while watching this film. It's film making at it's most risky and ambitious. The film literally captures 12 years of living and growing from a boy to a freshman college guy. The director took a huge risk and planned one of the most ambitious projects ever. The film mostly examines the human condition and asks the life question, "What's the point?". I recommend this as heavily as the LOTR trilogy.

This film is brilliant, well acted and about as relatable as you could want! everyone can find something to relate to in this story of a boy growing up and shot using the same actor throughout the course of his life. visually stunning, moving and ultimately convincing of a boy coming of age.
Watching the timeline change was cool, but the story was a little boring. Good movie not great!
impressive in scope, but average otherwise
most boring moving I've seen in years.  I don't get all the fuss.  at all.

Boring! I didn't like it! Why so many people liked it?! If this movie won the Oscar for the best picture awards, maybe I was upset! Maybe it was fun to see all people getting old little by little... But cute boy Mason became dirty looking non attractive guy and I was disappointed. Movie told about teenage drinking, smoke, girl hunt, sex, drags, fights, hates and so many annoying things. Some lines were smart, but so many lines were so boring and I hated it. Richard Linklater is not my favorite director. (I loved School of Rock!) He wrote, co-produced and directed this movie and he took 12 years! So I think story was not smoothly moving and so annoying... Best part was final 5 minutes?! and movie was ended so suddenly! I saw it for almost 3 hours and ending was like that?! OH NO! If you don't like independent movies, don't watch it! You will regret and you will waste 3 hours! Yes, I hate this movie!
"You know the saying 'seize the moment?' Well I think the moment seizes you"

This was obviously a very ambitious picture.  12 years to make, wow.  It sometimes felt like 12 years to watch.  This should be taken mostly in a good way.  I did not like that their are some storylines that are not fulfilled, but I think this was a deliberate choice.  Unlike movies, life doesn't have all the stories wrapped up for you.  It was a very fascinating examination in the life of a boy.  Notable moments:  Mason staring in the sky, waiting for his mom.  Dad taking Mason and Mason's sister bowling.

This movie was so disappointing. I felt like I just watched 3 hours of home video at someones grandparents house that I had no connection to. I applaud the dedication to filming for 12 years straight but no grandparents got an award for their home videos.

Boyhood is an extraordinary drama that was filmed over the course of 12 years, following the main character, Mason (Ellar Coltrane), as he grows from age 5 to age 18. Rather than sticking to a standard coming-of-age plot, the movie is more about the rhythms of life itself: trying to get by, making mistakes and moving on. There's strong language that comes in bursts, including "f--k" and "s--t." One sequence involves an abusive, alcoholic second husband. No onscreen violence is shown, but it's definitely suggested, and there's a sense of threat. Sex talk comes up from time to time, and the main character is seen briefly kissing his girlfriend. Teen characters also experiment with drugs and alcohol. Despite the mature content, this is a special movie that, if teens and parents watch together, could spark many fascinating discussions about life.

Passionate movie that is a great experiment. It will be remembered for years to come and it doesn't only trust the timeline it was shot in, it has a better writing than a lot of movies that represent life of a person. Truly a groundbreaking film that deserves the attention it gets.
Well written story, you know the social background of a typical American kid through this film. But standing for 2h 45min is just way too long.... seriously~

In spite of its long duration I still feeling that this is a beautiful film. It may not be a masterpiece, but it must be admitted that as a movie is very good. A great direction for the part of Linklater, and extremely strong performances. A story very nice and a lesson of life.

An earnest performance by all, a spontaneity too seamless one cannot help but suspect a heavy hand from the director but with an eye to the gentlest of details. The mundane is made magnificent. The film speaks. The film feels alive. And for the longest time in this decade, this is a film that feels human. 

P.S. Runtime is monstrous

great great film.I thought top 5 of movies I seen all year.And watching these kids grow up in front of your eyes is breathtaking. Linklater is ahead of his time in his direction..Should of won oscar..Hands down

Documenting the impact of passage of time on human lives has been Linklater's passion, and he does it again in a spectacular fashion, and makes one of the purest cinematic expressions that pretty much nails the coming of age genre to become its definitive representative. It doesn't have a climax nor an ending that wraps things up as we're used to.  It really just follows a family around for twelve years.  Sounds kind of simple and perhaps boring, right?  I was riveted.  I would have voted this Best Picture of 2014.

Yeah filming a movie over a 12 year periods is "interesting" as a technique but I don't see that adding anything to the movie.  Other reviews speak of a richness of character development.  Where?  All of Mason's Mom's men become alcoholics.  Yep, but why?  Mason is faced with some life troubles due to a single mother/ repeated step dad families, but no where is there any challenges and decision made that develops Mason as a person.  Mason just seems to change with time and life happening around him.  No one seems to be really engaged except for Mom ... but then again the move is not about her else it would be titled Motherhood?  What passes as a  "story" is the slow burning of time; so 12 years is distilled down to 3 hours of this is what I remember happening.  Why should I care?  What  was discussed?  What is revealed?
THIS MOVIE WAS A PILE OF BURNING GARBAGE ACCENTED WITH ELEPHANT TURDS!

The Academy have lost their credibility in my eyes by awarding the Oscar to Birdman, an artsy albeit well acted tale about narcissism without redemption, and not Boyhood, a soulful tale of an unfolding life. With a promise of what they could be.  I would gladly watch this tale again.

It depicts a child's growth and changes in his family like an epic. It's a fulfilling movie as Richard Linklator said: "I've long wanted to tell the story of a parent-child relationship that follows a boy from the first through the 12th grade and ends with him going off to college. But the dilemma is that kids change so much that it is impossible to cover that much ground. And I am totally ready to adapt the story to whatever he is going through."
In `Before` series, Richard Linklator made three movies by shooting the same cast every 9 years and 18 years in total. In 'Boyhood', Richard Linklater and his crew got together annually to film Linklater's script about a boy who will eventually grow up into a college freshman. Linklater's method behind production was essentially to make several 10- to 15-minute short films over the course of 12 years, each depicting a year in the life of the boy, and then edit them together as a feature film.
None of the actors were contractually obligated to return to the film each year due to the De Havilland Law under California Labor Code, which makes it illegal to contract employees for more than seven years of work. Had Richard Linklater died during the 12-year shoot, Ethan Hawke would have taken over the directorial duties. Richard Linklater asked her not to have any plastic surgeries, since it wouldn't make sense for her character. All of these episodes are because of the 12 year shooting period.
Richard Linklater casted his daughter Lorelei Linklater because she was always singing and dancing around the house and wanted to be in his movies. At about the third or fourth year of filming, she lost interest and asked for her character to be killed off. Linklater refused, saying it was too violent for what he was planning. Lorelei eventually regained her enthusiasm and continued with the project.
Linklater thought Patricia Arquette was the only actress he ever thought of for the part of Olivia as she had been a mom in a very young age while there are big changes in actors circumstances: both of Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette experienced divorce and remarriage and got new babies.  
According to Richard Linklater, Everybody Wants Some (2016) is a continuation of Boyhood in terms of beginning right where it ends with a guy showing up in the ending. I am looking forward to it.
A bit too long but definitely appreciate the creativity behind filming with the same cast over a 12yr period.

Just like any other stupid Hollywood glamorization of aberrant behavior in life -- like it's totally normal and okay for kids to get involved with drugs, alcohol, and promiscuous sex with hardly any consequences. Not real life at all -- which is ironic since the premise of this movie was that it was a more real depiction of growing up.  Nahh.  It's just that it took them 12 years to make it.  Nothing to see here.  Same old nonsense.  ?

It's true: Linklater took 12 years to develop his family of characters. While I was intimidated by the 3 hour run time, I have to admit, there was not a moment of this film I could have done without.

This is more than a coming of age story; the title "Family" or "Motherhood" would be just as appropriate. Set in Texas, the screenplay is natural and reminiscent of plenty of Linklater's other work: a film that begins with dialog unlike any other Linklater films evolves into thoughtful, poignant discourse not unlike that from the "Before" series. One character in a late-night nacho scene was perhaps a callback to the heady "Waking Life." With that said, this absolutely is not a mere think piece. What makes this film truly fantastic is how accessible the material is, given its scope. Without giving any narrative away, I'll say that the story itself is absolutely engaging and not without surprises. I watched many films at Sundance 2014 (including comedies), and this was the first that had the audience reacting throughout: we laughed, gasped, covered our eyes, and I am sure more than a few of us wept.

The characters are well developed. Don't be fooled by the title --- the spirit of Boyhood is alive here, but the female characters are thoroughly developed, distinct, and alive. Unfortunately, though it's 2014, this is a rarity in cinema.

Like in "Waking Life" and "A Scanner Darkly", Linklater has again delivered true visual innovation. This time, however, his set-up is simple: shooting on film, Linklater replaced rotoscoping with time lapse. Has a single film ever intentionally traced a character over such a span of time? Linklater wisely chose to reveal the main character to us subtly. Despite this, the effect is riveting.

I am not exaggerating when I say that after I watched this film I sold all of my other tickets to Sundance films. Though this only premiered a few days ago, I am confident that this will go down as one of the most ambitious and rewarding film projects of our time.

Well, I hadn't really heard about this thing until one day I logged on and saw a whopping 100% Certified Fresh, and I crapped my pants with excitement. I looked at the trailer, and I was excited as hell to see a movie with such a simple but interesting idea behind it. I saw it, and instead of coming out with a new outlook on life, I came out saying: "Meh, it was pretty good." 
Making a good movie is hard. Making a great movie is extremely hard. But making a movie that gets a 100% on the Tomatometer takes skill that is beyond my knowledge. I was expecting for this movie to completely change my life and perspective, but instead, I just liked it.
Even though it didn't live up to the hype, in my opinion, it's still a nice tale of growing up, and deserves to be seen nonetheless.

While watching this I kept thinking: "How are they going to wrap this up?", and then I got my answer... they don't. This is like one of many "artsy" movies that just abruptly end and are supposed to be thought provoking or something but really it's just lazy writing. Cool, it was filmed over 12 years. It would have been better though if they filmed something with an actual plot over the same time. You just follow this kid through a fairly ordinary life for for some time then the movie ends. Yeah, the kids life has some turmoil - particularly in having divorced parents and a mother who has horrible taste in men - but nothing ever really happens. She divorces the terrible husbands, they move a few times, and the kid goes on to meander through life without any focus. We don't know what happens to him because there is no conclusion. Maybe for the sequel we can watch him finish college, get a run of the mill job, get married, and  have kids of his own just like the rest of us. Earth Shattering.
A study about the quiet moments that define us.  The film is secretly depiction of a struggling single mother who by the end is so emotionally raw that it's both sad and endearing.

Saw BOYHOOD today--a wonderful concept leads to one of the best special effects you could ask for--living with a cast who age before your eyes! Lovely, natural performances from the cast of a flawed but decent family and how life changes and shapes people, If it has flaws, they are part of the concept--the film can feel long and lacks some drama--but the filming was long and not every life is filled with big drama. Definitely worth seeing--and it may make you want to visit Austin someday!

Had Boyhood not been filmed over 12 years, it would not have attracted nearly as much attention as it has, and would just be a good film. And although many would call it a gimmick, the idea to film it over 12 years is nothing short of pure genius. Sure, it is a gimmick of sorts, but it makes the movie feels so real and lifelike that you almost forget it's a movie at all. The acting is fantastic all round (save for Lorelei Linklater, who is pretty awful), the writing observes the life of a child beautifully, and the direction adds a realistic feel to the whole thing. It is a bit on the long side, but overall it's a very sweet film, and it gives you a real feel of nostalgia that no other movie could.

Richard Linklater writes and directs Boyhood, which encapsulates the life of a boy from age 6-18 in 2 hours and 45 minutes. The results were pretty great from many perspectives. From a filming perspective, maintaining such a cast over such a long period of time was quite an achievement. Linklater does not try and force anything, and create unlikely scenarios, nor is this a collection of home videos. Instead you get interesting glimpse of how one grows up, and how it really is all over in the blink of an eye. Boyhood was really an interesting movie project that will not overwhelm you, but certainly appreciate the growing up process.

As most of this year's award ceremonies have occurred and fled, it's probably out of common certainty that Boyhood will take home the Best Picture Academy Award - although, I'm not convinced; Boyhood was a fine effort to tell a heart-warming tale without any emotion or supreme acting from its leads, instead it's mostly just stolid performances.
Within the first hour of the movie, I agreed with my positive, critical thinking that Boyhood would be eligible of having a chance of earning an Academy Award for it's unique screenplay by Richard Linklater, who is also director - and for all the audience know maybe it will - the first hour was great, but thereafter the screenplay and direction falls, immediately, in the direction of clichés. Linklater did a splendid job in telling a heart-warming tale about the 12 years of boy's life from his early childhood right up to him preparing himself for graduation and subsequently college - and following the first hour there's one hour and forty-five minutes left, which covers some potential clichés; there's little emotion to be found on the screenplay or from it's actors, and stolid performances can be favourable nonetheless, but that's not how, I believe, Linklater hoped to get his message across. 
As truly great and outstanding this story appears to be in its first Act, I think the second and third Acts were a tough job, which were hard to reach a conclusion unlike most similar dramas, but fair play to director and writer Richard Linklater, who dedicated a lot to this movie.
So there's no real plot to this movie, but it's still mildly interesting to take in.

The parents are interesting and the concept is quite beautiful. But sadly the boy is incredibly unlikable, and not interesting once he reaches the age of about 12. I stand by the fact that if this movie was made in a normal amount of time, it would be known as a flop. Sadly it seems like people want to find meaning and depth to lines delivered so poorly from Mason in his teen years. Very disappointing.

Boyhood is a rare piece of cinema.It's not the first film ever made about family and time,but is the first one that actually shows us the reflections of time before our eyes.Boyhood is that type of film that sticks with you. You can easily relate with this characters,wheter you're a father,a mother or a teenager,because it is a film about life and its dilemmas and problems. These characters literally grow and mature before our eyes.Patricia Arquette is sensational and heartbreaking,especially at a particular scene at the end of the film.Ethan Hawke gives one of his greatest performances as Mason's father. Richard Linklater really is a special director,always showing sensibility is his films and philosophical questions that we all have at some point of ours lives. Boyhood is a film for the ages. It is universally loved by critics and deservedly so. In its simplicity,Boyhood aims high and beyond.

This one would never have been on my radar if it weren't for its Academy Award  nomination. Boyhood is the title of this movie about a boy named Mason (Ellar Coltrane). We see his life from age 5 to 18 pass by in little under three hours.

First off, this movie could have been called 'Girlhood' or 'Parenthood' as well. While the focus is mostly on Mason, we see enough of his sister Samantha (director's daughter Lorelei Linklater) and his mom (Patricia Arquette) and dad (Ethan Hawke) during his years of growing up.

Boyhood is the second movie I've seen that is nominated for Best Picture at the 87th Academy Awards that relies heavily on a production trick. The first was the style-over-substance heavy Birdman. The trick here in this movie is that the same cast was filmed over 12 years to create a magnum opus about, well, boyhood.

Thankfully there is more substance here than in the other movie whose title I won't mention again. While the narrative and characters as a whole could have been more elaborate, this movie was watchable despite the length and it never got on my nerves. 

That's quite an accomplishment in itself, but here it is significant because it's to the merit of the complete production value from actors to story to the excellent (if not inherent) portrayal of pop culture throughout the movie. It also has a diverse and well thought out soundtrack to top it all off. If  I had to characterize this movie in one word, I'd say 'touching'. 

All in all, this movie is a good one. Not great, but enjoyable nonetheless. The 12 year production shows consistency and attention to detail, which is lacking more and more these days, even in smaller projects.

Pros: charming, adequate acting, production quality
Cons: long running time, somewhat underdeveloped/charicaturized supporting characters

Verdict: good for a rainy sunday afternoon
Not that good of a movie, but Boyhood's an interesting watch because of its grand production scale.

I can't articulate what it is, but this feels like a period piece set in the present day, and everything about it just works.

That was a really long movie... It took a long time to film, and you can tell. It follows this kid, Mason, through the majority of his childhood (bar a few years at the beginning of it.) It just keeps going... A lot of stuff happens, a lot of characters are introduced, and a lot of dysfunctionality occurs. There are a lot of dramatic characters in this, including the mother. A lot of scenes go on for a long time, too. I feel like a lot of it could've been paired down. The movie was pretty slow, but I suppose interesting, and an artistic undertaking. Good stuff.

Boyhood is unique. It's an event-based movie that follows Mason (Ellar Coltrain) until he reaches manhood. Much like one of the film's morals, you won't remember everything about the movie, but you will remember the milestones.

The performances are hit or miss, depending on the current age of the actors and who is on screen. 

The unique part of Boyhood is how the same actors play themselves over the 12 Years of filming. This is really awesome to watch, and it works perfectly. You bond with the characters because you have seen them grow.

The story is told from Mason's point of view. Because of this, all of the adults come off as jerks with no parenting skills. This became incredibly annoying to me. 90% of the adults appear to be stupid, a couple of which I would have called CPS about. Some may connect with Mason over the horrible adults in his life, but I did not. I was raised by some of the best parents I have ever seen, and such, did not identify with Mason during some of the more pivotal scenes. Without identifying with Mason during these parts of his story, I found myself bored and uninterested. 

Boyhood prefers to show an event and let the viewer form their own options about it. These events involve things such as drugs, girls, and divorce. I was unable to identify with many of these events, which left me without much meaning for these scenes. This is in stark contrast to a few other scenes which I heavily identified with and had a lot of unconscious and conscious meaning to attach to Mason's life. 

I think I would have enjoyed the movie much more had I had a childhood similar to Mason's. As such, I would recommend Boyhood to those who had difficult childhoods with lots of bad adults, divorce, and emo phases.

An audacious, and mostly successful, experiment in filmmaking, Boyhood isn't quite the masterpiece that the hype portrays it as, but the fact it comes close is impressive. 

This movie is at its most special when its at its most earnest and raw. Instead of over dramatizing certain moments, viewers get to experience them through the lens of Mason, whose boyhood is the one we witness. 

While tropes ate addressed, such as sex, drugs and alcohol, the film doesn't give them undo attention. It doesn't glorify any certain choices in life, preferring to present them as simply real things that happen. 

The acting isn't perfect from the children, but it's not distractingly poor either. Ethan Hawke as the father is perfect. He embodies the transformation that goes on, not just in Boyhood but adulthood as well. 

Some of the best scenes occur between Mason and his father, and there's clearly a great deal of chemistry between the two, not to mention a strong resemblance. It is truly special to watch the same actors grow over the 12 year filming run, an excellent effect and directing choice by Richard Linklater. 

Rather than distracting from the film, the use of licensed music and products throughout plays to the authenticity of the picture as a whole. 

Boyhood is special. It's not perfect, but it is not a film to be missed. Go for the nostalgia if you must, but realize there's a real story with real heart just beneath the surface.

By the time it actually did fizzle out I for one was exhausted.  Is Boyhood a solid flick & worth your time? Yes.  Is it overrated? ABSOFUCKINLUTELY.

In this innovative  film we see the world through a boy's eyes from ages 5-18. Not only do we see a physical transformation of himself but the transformation of his world.  Through Ellar Coltrane (Mason) the viewer can experience, and in many cases relive, their own childhood experiences. This is a must-see film and a favorite for the best film of the year.
Quality flick, way over-hyped.

Impressive as it is to make a movie over such a long time span and manage to keep the cast intact, pretty much all of this stuff happened to me growing up. That doesn't make it interesting. They can have a gold star for dedication, but if this wins an Oscar, I hope Kanye West bum rushes the stage (appropriately this time) and rips the Oscar out of their hands. 

Watching 165 minutes of Mason's transformation into a hipster emo college student felt like I was there for all 12 years, and that is not meant as a compliment like I was engrossed or captivated by its majesty or anything. 

It's like if you took a good movie, Dazed and Confused, picked the worst character, Mitch the sensitive emo kid no on cares about, and made a movie solely regarding every minute detail about him growing up. The last two hours felt like the end of the LOTR: Return of the King where you're just begging for it to be over but they keep including unnecessary scene after another. Two stars because I'm feeling generous because I'm about to grab lunch.
Amazing piece of life full of magical moments and great performances. This movie is a unique masterpiece by Richard Linklater.

So, it's difficult to say anything about this movie without mentioning the ambition of it.

It pretty much succeeds at a number of things;
making a coherent story with a consistent tone over the huge amount of time that it was constructed,
consistently decent acting from the whole group, including a believeable growth of the main characters whilst all remaining human (including human faults),
pace - for a looooong movie it skips along at a decent rate of knots,
documenting a feeling of time and place, with lots of cultural references to make one nod and smile.

So, cleverly done and enjoyable enough, but it won't change anyones life, I'm not sure if i like any of the main characters after spending all that time with them and I won't be compelled to re-watch it anytime soon.
Truly ,a lower middle class American life! It was a little too long
Was rather boring and drug out way too much. Certainly not Academy Award worthy in my opinion.
Interesting idea but the movie is boring

A remarkable achievement for the director. A crazy concept and phenomenal casting. Change is the only constant is never depicted better in movies. So is the banality of life. Through relatively straightforward events, the director portrays one set of normal lives with all their achievements, failures, laughters, sadness and most importantly changes induced by the passage of time. For a regular viewer, the sheer purposelessness or meandering could turn overbearing despite the realism.

Boyhood is an amazing film that does no wrong. It truly is a lankmark in Cinema. It is original and so unbelievably real. Everything about Boyhood is done perfectly. Never before and probably never again will we have the opportunity to experience the perfect depiction of a child growing into a man and expriecing boyhood. The subtle changes of Ellar Coltrane aging is like life itself. We don't notice the change and progression of children aging. It just hits us out of no where like in the film. Everybody can relate to the emotions and issues portrayed in this film. Boyhood is one of the best pieces of work of all time.

Cool concept of seeing a character age in the story and in real life proves how boring every day life can be.  Outside of seeing 'The Medium' (Patricia Arquette) behind the wheel of another Volvo station wagon this is not worth the 3-hour investment.  Rent any 2 other movies and play the 50% odds one will be better than this snooze fest.

Ok so first off, I understand why this movie is huge Oscar bate. It's cool to follow these characters through life and everything. The gimmic Is pretty nifty. However there is a huge issue with the fact that the kids are mediocre actors at best especially Masson. Now I get that they casted them as little kids so they had to keep them and have them finish it out but it does take a toll on the movie. However there are some characters in the movie that are played by some REALLLLLYYYY BAD ACTORS. One scene imparticular is extremely bad when mason and his friends are with some high school seniors drinking and breaking things in an abandoned house. The acting in this scene is so bad I cringed. There are only a few moments like this and the rest of the performances range from decent- great. The second problem is the screenplay. Some of the lines in this movie seem obviously scripted as well as some really cheesy moments. This may be due to some bad actors but it takes away from the realism of the movie. All this being said this movie is still quite captivating with a few great performances from the mother and father and a variety of other characters and the gimmic of this movie over the course of 12 years is very innovative, ambitious and clever. Good movie over all but I expected more.

So. Heres the thing. This is a high concept movie that was pulled off. I mean that as a compliment. We see the actor (Ellar Coltrane) literally and figuratively grow up, and its fascinating. In a way, we also see Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette grow and change not only as their characters, but as people. Like I said, its interesting to watch and kudos to Richard Linklater and his team for making it happen. That being said, I think if you take the gimmick of the concept away, if this was just a normal movie and they filmed it all in a year or two, I dont think it would be receiving as many accolades. It meanders a bit, especially in the late grade school/middle school stage. Plus, they gave Patricia Arquette basically the same storyline three times. She just had a different haircut each time. Then, at the end, she has this great monologue about milestones in life and it really pulled everything together and put the whole movie in a certain perspective. But then it randomly cuts away and we never see Patricia Arquette again and he goes to college and falls for a girl he meets in his first 30 seconds on campus. So, I guess I was looking for a more poignant ending perhaps? Nevertheless, this is still worth a watch for its concept.
First half is awesome. But despite the fact the movie was really filmed throughout 12 years, there's nothing too much special about it.

Was it impressive that they filmed the same cast over 12 years .. yes. did anything happen in the movie??? NO!!!! Every scene seemed forced and contrived the most notable was Hey i'm the guy who fixed your sewer years ago and couldn't speak english and now i run into you at a restaurant I manage and tell you how great you are for telling me all those years ago that i should go to school.  It was ridiculous!!!!  Patricia Arquette was horrible. Everything she did looked over dramatic and complete unrealistic.  As one other reviewer said .. there was a beginning , middle and end... other than that the movie was a complete bore.  I compare it to Lost in Translation. another movie where nothing happens but critics loved it.  At least that one had Bill Murray in it.

Massive naval gazing, George Costanzo's old idea -- a movie about nothing. Save your money and check out some parking lot security cams. Seriously, I can not imagine a duller movie if they had tried. One laugh in 2 1/2 hours ... wooohooo!
Dumbest movie ever. No plot, bad acting, horrible ending, etc. This movie is a scam. I want my 2.5 hours of life back.
Great idea, boring story.

Boyhood puts forth a great concept and idea of filming the same actors over 12 years and watching the one character Mason, growing up. For the first two hours we really get a sense and remembrance of what it was like to grow up as a kid. All the memories and things come back to you while you watch this film but yet I did connect with Mason I felt once he got to the teen years he just became a complete tool. Once this happened the film practically lost me for the final hour and I wanted nothing to do with Mason anymore. Boyhood presented a great idea but most of the time it felt like they put on a camera and said "okay do stuff". I do think Boyhood was a great film but it doesn't deserve all the massive hype it has received and may have only gotten it because it's different. It would be cool to see in the future another film like this but with a girl as the main character, maybe even call it Girlhood. Boyhood is worth seeing and will get you sucked in at points but I can only promise it's likely only in the first half. I went from liking this character all the way to hating him. Boyhood could've been cut a lot in time and ended at a certain point when it just went on for another 10-15 minutes. Does it deserve best picture? No but it is worth watching and experiencing what 12 years in the making has done.
Worst movie I have seen in years. Awkward and bad acting. Don't waste your money.
Probably hit me harder than most since I'm a new(ish) Dad. A great realistic tale of growing up and the pitfalls that we all go through.
What the film had in terms if creativity (and perseverance) it lost in terms if a good  gripping storyline. Boring and forgetful!
i found ths film nice i could watch it but i just found myself thinking it was dragging a bit.

People are getting too excited about the fact that it took 12 years to make this movie. That's a really cool aspect of it, and it's really cool to watch, especially if you go in cold, like I did.

But dude. Come on.

Don't get me wrong. It's definitely not  boring or anything, I was glued the whole time. The acting is good, and the realist aspect is good. 
The realism is strong, even without the 12 years thing going on. It's brought to life by the acting and the photography, of course. That's what brings realism to a picture, even if the dialogue is wacky as shit, with the right acting and photography, you got yourself a realist film. 

This a realist film. A good one. A really good one. It's just not the best film of 2014. It's not even Linklater's best film.

This review is awful. I can't get my point across with this film. It's THREE HOURS LONG though.

One of a kind movie that was filmed in over 12 years, "Boyhood" serves both as a testament of patience, on-going raw acting talent (Patricia Arquette & Ethan Hawke most notably) & documentary of the top culture & historic moments of late 20th and early 21th century. While it hadn't anything really definitive moments or something, the whole movie stands a proof that films hasn't been overdone yet, new things are still possible.

This movie got me with the gimmick of watching the characters grow over the period of 12 years but ultimately it was a profound waste of three hours of my life. There was no point to the story, nothing special happened, no climax, nothing. Just watching children grow up, which I actually do every day for free.

The only thing this movie has is the gimmick of filming the kids of 12 years. No story, no humor, no drama, not entertaining. It went on forever. I was glad when it was over. It was like watching paint dry. I know I never agree with the critics but this is not a best picture of 2014.

You need patience and an appreciation of how the film was made to enjoy it. It is a small independent Linklater film in every sense. Very cool film experiment. No real plot beyond the basic "boy grows up in broken family".  Not the most exciting or even entertaining films. Its as long as Lord of the Rings, and feels it towards the end. I did start caring for the characters and wanted to see how they all turn out.

Not only was this moving filmed over the course of 13 years, which is a feat in and of itself, but is a compelling journey through a boy's life. The time jumps help break up the movie into segments organically.

It was OK, but no "Best Picture". I liked the idea more than the execution.

Some thoughts/observations:
- It seemed heavily skewed toward his later years. I don't know if this was because he was older and could act better, poor planning on their part w/ not enough footage the earlier years, or if it was their plan overall.
- The main character was a lump. He really didn't seem to have much personality. I found him to be one of the least interesting characters of the piece.
- A kid growing up in the 2000's and he never mentioned Pokemon or played w/ a gameboy? That is the most unrealistic thing of all. :-)
- Patricia Arquette's character had a really, really bad taste in men. It looks like Ethan Hawke was the best choice of all of them.
- I did like how they transitioned between the years. No real transition - just sort of an ordinary scene change. It would have been less effective w/ title cards, overlays, wipes, whatever

This movie felt like life unfolding before your eyes. That description is not far from the truth as the film took 12 years to film, in order to film the same characters undergoing growth, maturity, and coming-of-age events. The growth of Mason before your eyes and his transformation into a somewhat subdued, but intense and philosophical young man is one that happens in an earnest light. The way he experiments with different friendships, jobs, girlfriends, and family structures shapes him and we can see how that affects his life down the road. Although the happenings in the movie are often mundane, or at least typical teenage activities, the movies remains interesting and subtly suspenseful during its nearly 3 hour play time. I would recommend seeing it for merely the art form that it is, a portrait of a young man's life throughout the course of 12 years.

2 stars, but wait, it might win Best Pic. 
wow. where to begin. For those of you who don't know,  the movie takes place over 12 years. Literally, 12 years. The footage at the beginning of the movie was filmed 12+ years ago. And it is a complete mind blow, watching a movie in which the actors are growing older. That is completely original, and to my knowledge, has never been done before. absolutely amazing... 
Sadly, that is about the only good aspect to the movie. The acting was good, very believable, very good chemistry. But after 12 years you could expect that. 
The storyline was slow, sad, depressing.  The score was forgettable. 
The camera work was novice. 
This movie is oscar worthy, in my mind, more so than alot of others. The type of movie the academy loves. I am happy that I saw it. But I will never see it again.

Boyhood is a film that is being called boring. If you are one of those people, you don't appreciate film, or a unique story. THIS FILM WAS FILMED FOR 12 DAMN YEARS!!! I don't want to over sell it but holy crap this was fantastic. Seeing these kids grow up is just... Words can't describe...

Sprawling across 12 years of life and film, boyhood illustrates how a simple story can be so compelling, sad and beautiful. Watching the characters aged, set to an excellent soundtrack and topical material, Boyhood manages to create a timeless piece of cinema, that will certainly resonate feelings of days gone by.
Best film of the year and one of the greatest films period. This movie is a master peace.

You must know the setup - filmed over a 12 year period featuring the actual growing up of a boy from ages 7-19 this is undoubtedly a pretty amazing feat by director Richard Linklater and his cast. However, at almost 3 hours with very little in the way of excitement, I do think the film has been way over praised. 
Early on, Mason (Ellar Coltrane) and his family read Harry Potter and go to a midnight book launch for the Half Blood Prince. In many ways, watching Daniel Radcliffe and co grow up on screen is the closest analogy to this film.  Of course, you could also just look around you at friends and family too!
It isn't just young Mason who grows up. Patricia Arquette has been deservedly Oscar nominated, and indeed, the changes she goes through are in many ways more interesting than the well worn teenage boy cliches Linklater struggles to avoid. Ethan Hawkes' Mason Sr. develops less as a character - and Hawkes seems to age least of the cast! While Linklater's daughter Lorelei is slightly erratic as Mason's sister - sometimes great, sometimes less convincing as an actor.
There are some genuinely touching moments and definitely a feeling of peeping into a real family, complete with the more mundane times. 
The film is a one off, a novelty project but a real labour of love by all concerned. As a viewer however, it drags a bit and lacks a proper narrative. This is a movie to be admired but it didn't bowl me over the way it has so many critics.
Without the "filmed over 12 years" gimmick, this would have been a direct to cable TV movie.

Tryin to get the best pic noms in. This was fun to watch due to the innovative time lapse shooting. Several times I smiled because they had captured what my and most others, boyhood was like. I can see it winning best pic but Im not sold, since it has no real plot. More of a biography.
A tale of a young man's dysfunctional family. If your family was dysfunctional, you will relate. If not, enjoy the drama.

I wanted to watch it because of all the hype that was around it, not because I was interested. I came into this movie with very low expectations. 

Glad I did that....

What I found about this movie was that at the beginning, this move was pretty decent. The story of a broken family trying to get by and seeing it from the point of view of the children was actually quite interesting..... but the story just dragged on from there. I will actually be so disappointed if this wins best picture at the oscars.
Stultifyingly dullness for almost three hours. The only thing this movie has going for it is the gimmick, watching the kids grow older.
Not a fast pace movie but still fascinating
It's good, but it more impressive as a piece of film making than it is as a movie.
12 years whoopie, still doesn't cover up the piss poor acting from the boy and the mother; I mean unbearable acting.

The ambitious concept of director Richard Linklater's Boyhood is undoubtedly profound. It was filmed over the course of twelve years (it feels like a documentation as much as it feels a fictional drama), the actors noticeably age as the dichotomy of chaos and beauty known as adolecence gradually unfold before us. The characters are relatable, and the acting is spot-on, particularly from Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke as the parents of Mason, the center and anchor of the narrative. While it is a spectacle to see these actors and characters develop both physically and characteristically, the film just didn't feel particularly satisfying. This was likely because of a combination of the slightly overlong running time (2 hours and 45 minutes) and the low amount of entertainment value. Given the Oscar buzz and critical acclaim surrounding Boyhood, I found it relatively underwhelming. Boyhood is not a bad film by any means: in fact, it truly is an excellent depiction of growing up- I just couldn't find the spark that I was looking for in a film so grand.

Of course the 12 year thing is really cool. But as a kid who grew up just outside of Houston with a single mom (& loved DBZ as a kid) the relatable factor kept me intrigued through most of the movie. Then the kid gets all emo & I just admire Linklater's great directing at that point.

Richard Linklater is one of the best screenwriter/directors of the generation.  He captures life in the moment and the place better than almost any other.  It seemed so real without a bit of pretense.

Definitely one of my favorite films of 2014 and so far, I consider it the best one.  

The trials and tribulations of childhood and adolescence, all captured beautifully on film.  Really a pleasure to watch the young actors grow up in front of your eyes and go through both physical and emotional changes.  The plot structure is simple, and the film, more than anything, feels autobiographical, as if the director himself was looking back at and reflecting on his own childhood.  We see the main character as a young boy coping with his parents' divorce and trying to reconnect with his father.  We see his life path filled with joys, obstacles, falling in love, and experiencing heartbreak.   We see his life evolve and look back at both his happy and sad moments, and build so many bittersweet memories.  It's just a wonderful movie, period.

There's one certainty about Boyhood. It will win the Best Picture Oscar this year, not because it's the best film of the year, but from an artistic point of view, it stretched the boundaries of conventional filmmaking which writer/director/co-producer Richard Linklater deserves full credit for.
Filmed over a period of 12 years, the story is a simple coming-of-age tale of a boy's life from the ages of 5 through to 18, covering the usual issues a child encounters during that time in their life. Raised by a single mother, regular excursions with the estranged father, coping with an older sister, school, birthdays, bullying, puberty, an abusive stepfather, etc.
With each year of the boy's life covered in average of 14-15 minutes, the film is essentially a series of short films and home video style moments which bring an air of realism whilst the performances and dialogue are incredibly realistic. It also has to be said that it's a piece of movie magic to see all the characters physically age throughout the running time without the assistance of fancy makeup or prosthetics, not only of the young stars but also for the on-screen parents Ethan Hawke & Patricia Arquette.
There are a few minor gripes with the film, but not enough to make it unenjoyable. The main one is that it doesn't really deal with any issues that it brings up, it only skirts over the periphery of them. Another is that it doesn't really possess any nostalgic value. It's all set over the years post-2001, so if your childhood was prior, you won't generally share the same views or experiences as the main character & will sympathise more with the parents characters especially for viewers who are indeed parents, unfortunately, Arquette & Hawke aren't in the film as much as you'd like them to be. It's not their film though, it's Ellar Coltrane who you watch growing up before your very eyes, hammering home how quickly children grow up and how, indeed, time and moments can pass in the blink of an eye.
Richard Linklater used a similar style of filmmaking with Before Sunrise, Before Sunset & Before Midnight, a trilogy of films about the development of a relationship over three decades.
Still, Boyhood is an admirable filmmaking experience which provided an arduous, lengthy task for its cast and crew and fully deserves all the praise it's been receiving.
" I will only show sympathy with Richard Linklater 12 year journey regardless how bad or good it is"

The fact that Boyhood ends on Mason's first day in university at the age of 19, the same position I will be in in a few months, made me look back at my life and think "Wow, look at how far I've come. Look at how...old I am now. I can't believe this Mason character's my age. Just 2 hours ago he was six."

Full review at http://ianthetan.blogspot.com/2015/02/boyhood-review-coming-of-age-movie.html

If it held my attention better I wouldn't have minded the length, but that's not the case. They also took a risk hiring a child actor to be playing the role for the next 12 years, because there's always the possibility of him turning out to be a bad actor, and that's exactly what happened.  There were a bunch of scenes that were hard to watch with how awkward he delivered the lines.
Worst movie I have ever seen. Don't waste your life, it is 3 hours you will never get back.
If they have an Academy Award for "best Gimmick" then Boyhood will win hands downs. However, in all other categories, this was basiclly a poorly directed home movie.
Long, Touching, Beautiful, Ambitious, Mysterious and a Rollercoaster of Emotions, Boyhood is the definition of Life at it's most unique point of view narrative time-span.

I liked the film but did not love it.  As a 12-yer project and film-in-the-making it certainly stands out.  But had that not been the case, would it still earn such high praise from many critics?  Some of the characters are okay, but some are mere throwaways.  Arquette and Hawke re good, but their screen time is limited.   Ellan Coltrane was excellent and of course the real star.  Lorelai Linklater was good as his sister; although I only just learned that she is the director's daughter.  I did not care for her character, however.  As a mother, I thought Arquette's character was too weak, mostly; and Hawke's distant father seemed on-target.  But, as a non-traditional film, Boyhood lacked a true start or finish, and there was no climax to build up to.  Which was disappointing.

Initial rating.  I may have to watch it to really formulate an opinion.  Unfortunately, the movie is long so I'm not eager to revisit anytime soon.  I feel the first half is more interesting than the second.  The first half really feels like snippets of an evolution of a child from young boy to teenager, but then the movie tries to be "about something" in the second half but it never really amounts to much.  The lead character becomes more and more introspective as the film wears on but nothing really happens in his life to warrant such scrutiny.  Technically impressive, but I think the film needed a tighter narrative.  It just ambles towards the end.  Paul Thomas Anderson would have done wonders with this concept.
Great performances and interesting ideas but, for me, lacks distinctive focal points to make it engaging enough to hold my attention.

This is not your typical movie, that's for sure. Witnessing the growth of people, physically and mentally, on screen is absolutely magical. This may be what home movies typically achieve, but to see this achieved on the big screen is remarkable. Definitely recommended.
Don't waste your time.
So good and really captures life in all its little moments.
Good film ,worth watching

This was easily one of the most boring movies I have seen in a long time.  While the concept of filming one actor grow into adulthood  through fictional storytelling is interesting, it lacked any cohesive or dramatic pull to make me empathize with any of the characters.
waited for the big part & it didn't happen.  boring

I found it incredibly long. I had no idea going into it that it was 3 hours. It would have been incredible to film things over the span of 12 years and still make a two hour movie. What I liked the most was the fact the script wasn't showing the most important pieces of his life, but rather moments of the years. You didn't see the strife of the divorces and what not, but sometimes just a moment of the aftermath. I liked Patricia Arquette's monologue as it capped off a very real performance (but, if you're just realizing these are the types of performances Patricia Arquette gives- you are late to the party.)  Ethan Hawke has a very similar acting style to Patricia that puts the audience at ease.  I found myself, when watching and drifting mindlessly away, what would have happened if any of the actors died in the twelve years while filming?  Because I started drifting away with mindless thoughts, I can't quite say this is the Best Film of the year.  That- and I think the daughter deserves more praise for her performance. I wouldn't necessarily believe this deserves a Best Directing nod. To me- it was an experiment of- "can I do this?" and he did. Good job. But like "Across the Universe" was, it was like- "Good job. It was done. Let's never do it again..."

The only good thing about this movie is how unique it is in how it was made. Other than that, the entertainment value you get out of it is pretty low and the quality of acting was very poor in sections. Not something I would ever watch again.
Awful movie. Interesting technique used by keeping the same actors, but not a story worth telling or showing.

After all the buzz for Boyhood, I finally got around to watching it last night. First off I must say that it is a remarkable project; Linklater should win the Oscar just for this fact. The cast was all quite good and Ellar gives a very natural performance as should be the case with his life unfolding on screen, Overall, however, it didn't meet my expectations based on all the hype. It's a good movie, kept me interested and it was emotional in how it conveys the years that pass so quickly and the milestones in life. I felt it was too long and could have been better edited. It seemed like there was a lot of "filler" scenes in there that didn't really belong; they didn't really add to the story. I also felt that the dialogue contained too many "big" pronouncements as to the mysteries of life and that some of the dialogue was a tad pompous. Overall, it's well worth watching and I can't understand all the negative reviews about it being boring and no plot. I don't think I'd watch it again and it's really not that kind of movie in my opinion anyway but it's well worth a viewing.
welcome to life!!! what a beautiful movie that can't be more unique.
Not a bad movie.  A little long.  I dont see why this was nominated for best picture, I dont think it is nearly that good.
I thought this was too long. It was a decent film, but it's not up there on a favorite list.
Interesting concept but too long and somewhat slow.
Boyhood is the story of a boy growing up over the course of 12 years. It is a well-written, well-acted, and ambitious film that will be remembered for a very long time.

As I feared, it's a nice gimmick to film a movie over 12 years with the same cast, but unless you've got a good story in mind to begin with it just ends up as a meandering light drama where nothing of note ever really happens. Even the little stories lacked any impact. Would've worked better if it was simply compressed into 30 minutes so at least the changes to the cast would've appeared more dramatic and it wouldn't have harmed the plot at all.

The fact that this awful travesty of cinematography is so highly rated just lowered my opinion of humanity. It's downright boring and about as original as a Rocky Sequel or a Disney princess cartoon. Thanks Richard Linklater for showing us what 95% of American boys experienced either directly or indirectly while growing up in the 90's. You managed to create a movie that made my formative years seem boring, tedious, and frighteningly more deserving of an Oprah episode than the ESPN 2 stuntman series I was hoping for.

If you tried to gun down "Boyhood" with a silver bullet, it would probably deflect the ammo and knock you down instead.  How do you criticize a movie that serves as one of the most ingenious experiments in the history of cinema? You can't.  You don't want to.  Richard Linklater has forged new ground before - the "Before Sunrise" trilogy presented romance in a wordy, realistic bundle, "Bernie" knotted mockumentary impulses with true-crime jolts - but never before has he, or any director for that matter, made something as disparately pragmatic as "Boyhood."
	You know the backstory: "Boyhood" was filmed for over 12 years, IFC financed it on a wing-and-a-prayer, and, now, it is hailed as being one of the best films of the decade (and by some, ever), with abounding Oscar nominations to prove it.  It delivers exactly what you think it will: it directly, and honestly, tells the story of a boy's childhood, growing from a sprightly six-year-old to a thoughtful collegian, growing before our very eyes.  The unremarkability of "Boyhood" is what makes it so remarkable; aside from a few shitty stepfathers, Mason's (Ellar Coltrane) experiences are relatable, and if not, understandable, and the film doesn't sugarcoat that.
	So many coming-of-age films would rather play it safe and venture into quirky yet emotive territory, just teary enough to make you go awww at the end but agile enough to trick you into thinking that the humor involved makes it immune to the clichés you've come to know.  But "Boyhood" doesn't aim to be a typical coming-of-age film; it doesn't even aim to be a typical film.  If it isn't always as captivating as we'd like it to be, it prospers in its momentous moments.  The mundane is invigorated by the idea that, just a few minutes ago, the characters sitting in the mundane chateau of life were younger, their opinions and goals shaped completely differently since we last saw them.  You cannot say that about any other movie, and if we were to, we'd most likely be referring to a documentary (more specifically, one of the "7 Up!" films).
	What Linklater does here is far more profound than many would like to admit.  "I give 'Boyhood' a B, for boring!" my father exclaimed in an Aunt Linda sort of way when the film finished.  When we go to the movies to escape, seeing something gritty and real is far less enticing than traveling into a faraway land where The Avengers are the heroes of the world or a meet-cute suddenly becomes involving and pressing.  Seeing our own reflection in a character, a story, or a setting isn't always fun,  The truths a mirror provides can be disconcerting.  Even if we haven't had two alcoholic stepfathers, even if we haven't moved several times and even if we haven't received a shotgun, a Bible and a suit from our grandparents on our birthday, all of us, male or female, can relate to Mason because we've all grown up.  We've had that one bad hairdo, that one misunderstanding with our parents, that feeling of doubt when thinking about the future.  Maturing isn't always exciting, but "Boyhood" points out that our clashing identities make us a whole - our flaws, no matter how different they initially seem, are rooted in the same fears, the same ambiguities.  When Mason's mother (Patricia Arquette) breaks down towards the end of the film, pondering if life really is just a series of unexceptional milestones, we can't help but ask ourselves the exact same question.
	Does the film contain great performances, great writing? Traditionally, no.  The actors don't so much portray their characters as they do fill their shoes.  In real-life, Arquette is a mother, Hawke is a father, and Coltrane is a young man with an unknown road ahead of him, and they most likely directly took their own lives into account during the filming process.  What we see on the screen is so instinctive that the cloud of illusion clears into a sky of reality; we forget that Linklater, Hawke, and Arquette are all established professionals.
	Not a lot happens in "Boyhood," but its effect is extensive and weighty.  Linklater has made the movie of his career.  The 1970s were a time in which films were testing out their newfangled abilities to cover the screens in sex, violence, and unheard of ideas - many consider it to be one of the best eras in movies.  But it seems the 2010s are past all that, preferring to test the limits of filmmaking itself.  Alejandro González-Iñárritu shot "Birdman" as if it were photographed in just one take; "The Artist" made the silent film cool again.  "Boyhood" proves that time should never be a limit when it comes to art.  No, "Boyhood" does not get a "B for boring"; it gets an A for astounding.

To start off, I'd like to say I that don't think anyone can deny the brilliance of this film. Ambitious and innovative in in it's concept but yet accessible and natural in it's approach. It's charm and originality is derived from the fact it is a life story first and a coming of an age movie second. Instead of presenting the story within the context of the movie, Boyhood presents the movie within it's own story. The audience discovers the movie within their own introspection of the real life moments that are fluidly being presented by  director Richard Linklater. In this sense, Boyhood has the possibility to relate to it's audience as much as it relates to itself. Speaking volumes about all the truths and contradictions of life without needing the capacity to say anything at all. But even in all of this real to life feeling taking place in the movie's ebb and flow, Linklater does not bore or presents these moments in a way that comes off as dry or ordinary. Even the most minimal and seemingly trivial scenes get weaved together with the rest of the movie in an almost  lucid fashion. Occasionally recalling me back to the dynamic and spirit of his 2001 animated film Waking Life. Most especially in the subtle cues and emphasizing of moments happening outside it's basic plot - like the man talking to himself at the restaurant or the brief monologues on time and change by both main and secondary characters. Another success of boyhood is in how it uses the model of a coming an age  film as an accurate introspection of of the reality we all live in now. Through depicting Mason's childhood in a hyper accurate and real sense (the harry potter book releases, obama's election) we also get a coming of an age of a new generation (our generation) along with coming of an age of Mason. And in itself it becomes a critique and an embracement - but all through the lense of a life story. A lense that see life through the perspective of poetic vignettes in which these vignettes are nothing more than passing moments. Thus what Linklater teaches us through Boyhood is that in which is expressed in the movie's last scene and happens to be the movie's concept as whole: experiencing life is not about living the moments of one big story but rather continuously living the story of each moment.
Visually great work. And enjoy how raw the story was, felt like a real documentary

This is a movie unlike any other. It's ambitious, it breathtaking at times, and it's incredibly memorable, however it all rests on kind of a gimmick. That gimmick is what makes it special, and that gimmick is the fact that it took 12 years to make. It really is incredible though to watch this boy grow up. The director took a chance and it paid off. Every summer they filmed for a couple of days and created this movie. There isn't really a plot per say. It's more like a bunch of short films put together that shows different moments of a boy growing up. The acting is fantastic. Patricia Arquette knocks it out of the park with her performance, Ethan Hawke is equally good, I really enjoyed his performance and I felt the movie had the most life when he was on screen. Overall it really is a fantastic movie. My only gripe is the fact that if you take the exact same script and shot the movie over a period of 2 months, it wouldn't be special, it would be boring, and it would be very forgettable, it's only because of the gimmick that the movie works, and boy, does it work!

Boyhood. A landmark cinematic achievement and an astonishingly powerful portrait of youth, of family and of life that I simply love more than I can say.  This quietly confident masterpiece oozes glorious humanity in its abilities to engulf viewers with a simple and patient story of life and of love. 

The headline feature of this movie is undoubtedly its tender and loving craft over a period of 12 years, an undeniably astounding cinematic feat. Watching the movie for the first time, a feeling of awe was almost compulsory as my tiny brain tried to compute this essentially unprecedented experiment with time undertaken by the masterful Richard Linklater. Both the physical and emotional transformations of Mason (Ellar Coltrane) and those that populate his life unfold in a rich and loving tapestry over the three hour running time, combining to mould a stunning portrayal of an average family's life and effects of time and age. 

A second viewing, however, allowed me absorb the film within its own merits, relishing in the sheer delight of its patient, understated and subtle ways. It is a poignant study of life and the struggles and wonders of growing up. Most impressively in my eyes, Linklater has constructed an utterly blank canvas of emotion, not exploiting or patronising viewers with prompts for when to feel and not really relying on major plot points. Instead, these helplessly relatable characters populate our lives for the best part of three hours, inviting us in to bare witness to their experiences, whether they are trivial and mundane or major and profound. In short, the wonders of the cinema are used to allow us to fully immerse ourselves and experience these lives. By the end, the imminence of time has well and truly engulfed the viewer, lending a stark and sobering sentiment to the close. On the flip-side, the movie never allows itself to stray from optimism, delivering the ultimately uplifting notion that the slight, unassuming moments that make up this movie (and equally of lives) are really our lives, often missed whilst we scavenge for a more profound meaning in our own lives. 

Aside from this, this film amounts to perfection partly due to the overwhelming virtues of its relentlessly likeable central cast, with stellar turns from the children of the movie (especially newcomer Coltrane, who throughly embraces his gradual movement to the forefront towards the latter half of the movie and displays real promise) and the parents, with a thunderous and painstakingly realised performance from Patricia Arquette, rightfully cleaning up this awards season. The soundtrack is sprawling and runs parallel with the movie it inhibits, evoking painstaking nostalgia from the first bars of Coldplay's Yellow and closing the movie with a flourish of Arcade Fire's Deep Blue. 

Simply put, however, this is not a movie that can evaluated like any other. It is simply like no other. In a year of wondrous compound titled films (Birdman, Whiplash etc.), Boyhood, a small and truly independent film, doesn't so much as stand out amongst them but distances itself from the rest through its sheer uniqueness, its audacity and its utter humanity. It is an tender creation of time and one that has come to fruition through Linklater's faultless perseverance in this 12 year labour of love. 

Beautifully and delicately crafted, Boyhood is a film about life that simply inspires love and, in the process, shows itself to be one of the all time cinematic greats.
