I liked the premise and hated the execution.  I watched this movie from the comfort of my own man cave and kept a running diary of my thoughts.  I will share them with you so you can understand how I reached my conclusion that this Golden Globe winner is extremely overrated and should not win the Oscar. 

My running diary of thoughts as I watch Boyhood for the next three hours...
Edgy opening. Immediate Coldplay Yellow took me a straight back to the early Aughts. Well done. 
The little kid talking about his rock collection reminds me of Jake Lloyd talking about midichlorians. It's too bad George Lucas didn't take 12 years to film the Clone Wars. 
The girl is annoying. Oops she did it again. And I'm annoyed by the soundtrack already. Way too many gimmicks - Soak Up the Sun? I guess I need to lighten up. 
Acting: Young Ethan Hawke > young Patricia Arquette
Bowling hasn't aged in 12 years. 
Wow. Transition. Now PA has married her creepy Pavlov professor. 
Boyhood & Stepboyhood are chatting about Star Wars and now playing Halo. This sounds like my boyhood! Wait, that was college at BYU.
Family charades. I'm bored.
Harry Potter & the Deathly Hallows is now out and Boyhood and siblings are waiting in line. I'm bored but I do appreciate the pop culture references to mark then passage of time. 
Douchebag high golf shorts stepdad is lecturing sister. I'm annoyed because I hate them both. 
PA's haircut is ridiculous. 
Now they're chasing butterflies.
Mid-Aughts EH is still > mid-aughts PA. 
Roger Clemons on the mound. Back when EH and everyone thought it was completely normal for a 43 year old to be unhittable.*******
EH and Jimmy are now performing for Boyhood and Sishood. Jimmy is a douche with guitar. I'm bored. 
Boyhood just asked EH about magic and elves. Now they're talking about whales. I'm bored. 
They're getting haircuts because stepdouche is on a power trip. Now Boyhood is faking that he's sick because he looks like an idiot. This is the first time I've truly felt sorry for any of them. 
Now they're giving the Texas flag pledge. Texas is so weird. 
Now his hair has grown back and there's been an altercation between PA and a drunk stepdouche. He's drinking at the dinner table. Drama. "I hate squash."
A "Funny or Die" clip that isn't funny. I'm bored. 
Stepdouche is checking everyone's phones. And driving them to the liquor store. I can see where this is going. Oh, no crash. Just a near wreck. The oracle was wrong.
PA is screaming and has just rescued the kids.
Omg. This new girl at the friend's place is singing at the table while Boyhood and his new friend play Wii. They're moving on. Time marches on. Richard Linkletter is boring me to death. 
Annoying girl is crying outside her middle school. Now PA just had a meltdown. Kudos to her. Boyhood is at a new school. He just met a new brah. Brah-hood. 
Now they're putting up Obama/Biden posters. I'm bored. 
2008 EH is > PA. Now he's using Sarah Palin as a hip way to talk about birth control with the kids. And now some ginger bowling girl is trying to seduce him. 
Boyhood's voice is lower. His balls have dropped. Now they're hiking. I'm bored.
Now they're having s'mores and talking about Return of the Jedi. And now he's peeing on the fire to a hipster music transition.
And now he's getting bullied in the bathroom. And now he's talking to some girl who is riding a bike as he walks over to the college where PA is now a teacher. This girl is reading To Kill a Mockingbird instead of the cheesy Twilight books. 
Ugh. I would hate having late Aughts PA as a teacher. This talk about attachment theory is killing me softly.
Hooligans messing around in a construction zone. Drinking beer, talking about sex. I'm bored. 
Now one of PA's students is in Boyhood's room chatting about life. Now they're at the table listening to stories about Iraq. Now edgy student chick is playing Wish You Were Here on the guitar. 
Time change. His hair is now longer and it's his birthday. He just admitted to PA that he's been drinking and smoking. And EH now has a baby and a minivan and a mustache.  He had to sell his cool car for the minivan. Oh no. He told Boyhood he would give it to him when he turned 16. He forgot. Now they're having a fight. Drama. 
Now they're watching Gaga on the iPhone. So hip. Now EH is explaining his Beatles mix. I'm so bored.
He got a shotgun and a bible. What a birthday. More singing and guitar playing. 
They're skipping rocks, but Boyhood's true passion is photography. "Any dipshit can take pictures, Mason. Art, that's special." 
Edgy boy has painted his nails. PA's sheriff boyfriend is not pleased with that or the earrings. He needs to be responsible. 
Friday Night Lights. Beer pong. Jell-O shots. "I just want to be able to do anything I want because it makes me feel alive As opposed to giving me the appearance of normality."
Drunk sheriff - oh wait, his shirt says corrections. Anyway, he is mad at Boyhood for coming home late. Now annoying PA is paying her bills and being preachy at the table. I think even mustachioed EH is still better.
Now the manager is yelling at Boyhood for eating leftover shrimp and flirting with April. He will get a raise as long as he can handle the added responsibility. Giddy up.
FaceTime with EH. Longer hair and some scruff. The baby bro is growing up. EH just called him ObiWan. Now I'm annoyed. The first Star Wars reference was kind of funny. Now it's getting lame. Same with the music. 
I'm soooooo bored!
Boyhood is talking to some girl in the truck about cyborgs and how we get dopamine rushes for text messages and facebook notifications. He wants to be a real person, not just a profile. He wants to live his real life not through a screen. He doesn't want to live in an in between state. He wants to experience. Cyborgs are consciousness. Cyborgs are alive. Cyborgs are Chappie.
Now they're playing billiards. Annoying sister is talking to Boyhood's girlfriend. College is really fun. Unlike this movie, which is boring and the opposite of fun.
Douche with guitar in the street while someone does a hoola-hoop. When will it end!?!? This movie feels like it really has been going for 12 years because it's so boring! 
I just spaced out for awhile and didn't miss anything.
Back. Awkward roommate walk in scene. He won a silver medal and a scholarship. His photography is his meal ticket. He has a great heart.
Boyhood. More like mopey adolescent whines about prom and pouts to his girlfriend who slept with her college boyfriend. "He's not a jock. He just happens to be on the lacrosse team."
Graduation party!!!! Everyone's here! What a party! Toasts. A toast to the future. A toast to the douchebags. So bored. 
Sam's turn. Good luck. Lol.
Old EH is still > PA
You are responsible for you. Not your girlfriend. Not your mom. You are responsible. 
It's all timing. It would have saved Boyhood the parade of drunken a-holes. 
"What's the point?" Of life? Or this long movie?
They're moving. Again. Sam is complaining. Again. Full circle. 
Time to take responsibility. 
Wow. Their waiter was their sceptic tank cleaner years ago. PA changed his life. Gracias. 
Boyhood is trying to look like a young EH. That's profound.
Boyhood is happy to be leaving. PA is sad. Her life is just a series of milestones. Now she's upset. We just thought there'd be more. 
Now Boyhood's hitting the open road to some stupid emo indie song. I'm so mad.
And..... Xbox's servers just went down. I'm five minutes from the end and I can't finish it right now. I was so close. Now I'm so mad. I don't even want to finish it but I have to. 
No achievement for me.
And no, this is not a weird joke. 
Initial gut: This had potential, but it was just stupid. Way too boring. But maybe that's the point. Life is boring? No way. My life is hilarious and full of jokes. 
After an hour Xbox is back. Here's the final few minutes. Taking pictures of random things out in the desert. A gas station. A fire hydrant. Now he's in the dorms. He just met his roommate. His ginger roommate. They're going hiking with some babes. This one's a tap dancer. They're both artists. Seize the moment. But it's the other way around. The moment seizes us. "It's like it's always right now." 
End credits.
With that hour break, it made the last few minutes seem like an encore. Initial (full movie) thought: that's it? If it wasn't filmed over 12 years, no one would think twice about it. Like Steve said, a boring movie is still boring even if they filmed it boring scene by boring scene over a decade. Although I do have to say, the edgy end credit choice of Arcade Fire's Deep Blue is perfect because it bookends Yellow from the opening credits. The edgier things get, the more they stay the same. Just like time itself. Just like Boyhood.

" Art, that is special. What can you bring to it that nobody else can? "

Richard Linklater delivers realism on a scale that cinema rarely explores upon. Linklater and the story he tells through Boyhood truly revels in the magnificent and  abhorrent, the remarkable and dire, the simple and the complex. 

How does one take nothing beyond the doldrums of every day life and turn it into something more for an audience? Boyhood excels at taking the ordinary and making it extraordinary. Who would have thought that chronicling a normal family for twelve years would reap such reward and promise?

Carrying that story is a remarkable cast that comes together as if they really are the family next door, our family even. Lorelei Linklater offers that tantalizing but loving sibling who doesn't always vocalize her feelings. Ellar Coltrane brings to the table an inquisitive son and sibling that is hungry to find a purpose. Patricia Arquette puts forth maybe the performance of her career as the mom that only wants to do right by herself and her children but seems to make poor decisions over and over. Ethan Hawke is equally as brilliant as the dad who wasn't quite ready to be a dad. His struggle and triumph to connect with his children is heart-warming. 

What makes this cast so beyond comprehension is that fact that they make it all feel so real. The bonds they share, the journey they face, and the endless questions and answers. The relationships between mother and ex-husband or father and son or brother and sister, they are all cemented in the sometimes inconvenient truth of life. It all feels so real -- and I imagine working with one another for twelve years has forged many of those bonds to be as true and genuine as they appear on screen.

Linklater, cast, and crew scrounge every crevice of life and the realism. Boyhood stands far taller than simply great cinema... It stands as art -- a window into the frail lives of each and every one us. Life lifts us up and it drags us down only to lift us back up again -- that's the reality Boyhood captures.

And that is what Mr. Linklater brings to cinema that nobody else can.

You've got to give my boy Richard Linklater (he who made "Dazed and Confused") credit for his vision in this movie as it's a helluva concept. And the kid turns out to be a pretty phenomenal actor which really makes this a win on many levels. I admit Linklater's daughter (who plays sister Samantha) was quite awkward, ugly, and geeky but now that I realize she's the directors daughter I understand why she was cast in that role. The movie itself is an amazing time capsule of the past 12 years and there's a lot to relate to for anybody even if they hadn't actually grown up in that time. I also really loved the last line of the movie: "It's like it's always right now."  I hesitate to give this 5 stars only because it's 2 hours and 44 minutes. It's hard to watch ANY movie that long these days. Aside from that though, this is probably your Best Picture in March.

When you are Mason jr. and you know that you don't be the hero you just wanna be yourself, that's living the good life. When your director Richard Linklater and you are filming a movie for 12 years focused on a family and their challenges year by year such as the mother going divorce multiple times and there kids trying to find their own identity and what they want to do with their lives, thats incredible.

a simply massive undertaking. filmed over 12 years. nothing like this has ever been done before. the script itself had to have been very loose because the technological and cultural references were literally non-existent as the chronology of the film advances. the film chronicles the life of a young boy and his sister from age 6 to 17, when he begins college. the same actors are used throughout the entire film, year after year. The actors literally age before your eyes as the scenes are seamless cut and edited together to form the arc of the story - showing how the various men in this young boy's life, including his father, played by Ethan Hawke, have a profound impact on his development.

The good: it's fascinating watching the kid grow over time and seeing Patricia Arquette weight yo-yo like Oprah. There are also some interesting interpersonal interactions. The bad: the music and pop culture references seem to be pandering for nostalgia. It's waaaay too long and simply boring in places. There are needless political references spread liberally throughout the film. And the kids acting was subpar. This movie does not deserve the praise it has received.
It was cool to watch the actors grow up. A nice bildungsroman, but nothing too profound here.

By the second half the novelty of the realism wears off and you are beginning to wonder where the movie is going and ultimately its a unique view into a character growing up, but nothing spectacular.

Boyhood isn't a commentary on the human condition; it's a [very damning] commentary on that part of the middle class that's numbed out. Where potential in kids never gets realized, where dreams are tiny little niggles that barely make themselves heard through the fog. Where people shuffle along towards death and a realization that it was all pointless.

It's a perspective on life and a lot of people do subscribe to it and live it out but it's not the entire human condition. The part that's missing here is that within us which responds to those niggles and prompts us to fight with everything we have to dissipate the fog. And plenty of people succeed.

The blurb calls Boyhood 'groundbreaking'. I disagree. The concept of using the same actors for 12 years for a movie is unusual for the movie industry, that's all. For the rest, it's self indulgent film-making and script writing and could have said the same things in less than half the time. It's easy to write a 180 page script, which Boyhood was, but it's not so easy to masterfully edit that down to 120 pages or less and still say everything the longer version says. 

I think it contains some real brilliance but it's so watered down by the sloppy writing that in the end it has become not just a commentary on but a product of middle-class aimlessness. I don't think it deserves all the accolades, awards and award nominations it's gotten and am hard pressed to understand how anybody could have finished watching it and not wanted to slit their wrists.

OK - here goes. Based on reviews of family and friends, on Facebook and elsewhere, this is a very polarizing film. I know some who hate it with a passion and some who love it. I fall slightly below the "love it" camp - I merely liked it. Parts of it are fascinating, particularly the "gimmick" of the male lead (and his movie sister) growing up before our eyes. I loved listening to some of the dialogue. Even though I was raised in a different era and had a very stable childhood, I could relate to a lot of what the kid went through. However, I struggled with the acting. I thought it was just OK. I'm not getting the awards love for Patricia Arquette. Probably my own prejudice since I've never thought she was a substantial actor. She's adequate here, but not more than that. Ethan Hawke is his usual scenery chewing self, but he's fine in the part - he fits the character well. As for the kids, I thought they did a smashing job for non-professionals. Another struggle I had was with the characters themselves. I found it hard to root for any of these folks. The young man was a bit whiny and depressing, his sister was a bit nasty, and his mother and father were poster children for bad decision-making. Yep, I realize there's no movie otherwise, but it got tiresome after 2 hours and 45 minutes. So, I recommend the movie if you're looking for a slow, languid watch on a Sunday afternoon. However, if slow and languid are not your thing, stay far, far away.
Phenomenal! I related so much to this film!
If this gets Best Picture over Grad Budapest Hotel AND Birdman, I am going to be SO pissed.

It was very interesting watching the trials and growth of all the characters.  The kids grew in front of you over 2 hours 45 minutes.  Thought provoking and reality hits you on how fast it all goes by.  You literally get your kids present in your life for a little over 1/4 of it.  It's important to stay invested.

57 mins into the movie I finally gave up.  It's time in my life that I'm never getting back. 

The movie making process, as interesting and committed as it was, doesn't make up for the morbid, depressing & generally awful story. A real shame.

Undoubtedly an unique cinematic achievement. Watching the cast literally age in front of your eyes makes Boyhood a remarkably personal, intimate film. And although very little actually "happens", the film is on the whole very watchable. For me the film is as much about stumbling through the challenges of parenthood as it is a tale of a boy growing up in a modern world. Although no one gives a bad performance, I lost interest in Mason's story as he grew into a sullen, monosyllabic teenager. He may be a dreamer and free spirit, but it doesn't make for a charismatic lead character and made the latter half of the film drag. For me, Patricia Arquette was the heart of the film, as the battling single mum, always trying her hardest for her family. Overall a sweet film and a once in a lifetime filmic achievement.

Who on this planet can sit through this mind numbing dribble of a film.  This was a total waist of 2 hours and 40 minutes.  I was intrigued by the concept and the stellar reviews.  Never trust a critic. 

 The movie features a mother who always picks the wrong man because all men evidently are louses.  Her depressing son and nihilistic daughter speak volumes to her parenting skills and lack there of.  The only interesting portion of the film is completely dropped.  Mom removed her own children from an abusive father while leaving his 2 biological children behind to fend for themselves.  Rather than the  Hispanic immigrant who thanks the mother for inspiring him to get an education I would rather have seen one of the abused children ask her how she could leave them never to check on or see them again.

I kept hoping the film would get better as time went on, but was relieved to finally see the credits.  My wife and daughter who endured this ordeal with me may never allow me to pick another movie again.
Take away the gimmick of filming it over a dozen years, and this is a forgettable film.

Pfffftpp... A well average film about well average people filmed over a well above average period of time. Another mostly boring film by a guy that has a mostly boring catalogue of movies under his belt. Hawke and Arquette are good in this though.
One of the worst films watched so far this year.
It's like time-lapse photography on a cinematic scale; never once straying from its genuine and heartfelt narrative.   So well done that even I can get past moments of blatant politicizing.

Good movie. But, I didn't see what all the hype was about. Nothing really happens except the main actor ages from about 8 years old in real life to about 20 (so this movie took 12 years to make). But nothing really happened.

Praised as profoundly humanist, and offering the latest answer to "what-can-cinema-do-next", Richard Linklater's Boyhood is one of the most talked about movies of the past year. The groundbreaking gimmick is that Linklater's actors met up once every twelve years to shoot footage for the finished three hour product. The reality (often overlooked by those blinded with conceptual praise), is that Linklater's lifetime-long film is enough to give you growing pains. 
The problem with Boyhood is, let's face it, none of the characters are particularly likeable, or even genuinely interesting. Our mopey boy doesn't do so much as share a single thought until he starts driving a truck and, let's face it, Ethan Hawke's frothy father (strictly in younger incarnations only) is the only person here with an ounce of bouncy enthusiasm for his sad, stock role. Then, once we step outside of the characters, we're left with little more than a maddening visual and aural catalogue of blinding cliches and look-at-me pop culture references.
The 'profoundly humanist' Boyhood raises one question only: are humans really this dull, predictable, and pathetic? The answer is no, Linklater has merely invented a new genre: universally relatable kitchen mellow-drama. Exasperating.

In 'Kingsman', people keep saying 'Ah, but this ain't that kinda movie', but (and perhaps because) it is.  This really isn't.  People drink, drive, and survive.  They look at pictures on i-phones while driving and don't crash into trucks.  They play with circular saws, and live, limbs and skulls intact.  The film taunts us with our own cinematic expectations.  In this grand-scale narrative of small-scale lives, it's mostly the parents who suffer the crises, mainly to do with disappointment and disillusion, while the kids just ride on through, only towards the end realising that that experience awaits them also.  Following the child actors as they grow (the hat-tips to Harry Potter are nice) is mildly distracting, perhaps, but to have held the pace of the film so well over such a long timescale of production is an amazing achievement.
Beautiful. Just lovely.
what drives you to see this movie can be satisfied by fast forward at 120X.  Then watch a different movie.

It starts with Coldplay's "Look up the stars, look how they shine for you" and then and there itself it catches your attention. Depicting 12 years of a typical American boy's life it leaves a lasting impression of the turbulent lives of many people. A usual mother, good dad, bad dad, worst dad and of course an introvert boy. Marketed as a 'generalized' movie but one size doesn't fit all. A daring attempt and certainly a fresh concept.
Excellent film. Brilliantly done. Amazing how they did this over 12 years with all the same cast. Really enjoyed it :-)

Richard Linklater is an icon of independent film industry. He knows how to amazed us. How to hooked the feeling. Boyhood is another masterpiece from his hand. An epic, that shows his totality, patient, make scene by scene in a real time. 12 years is not only Mason grow up himself. Every single parts is getting bigger and bigger too.

Conceptualizing the canvas that Linklater encapsulates in "Boyhood" is difficult to do, let alone understanding the fact that this was actually pulled off.  The film itself, while accurate and intimate, isn't nearly as staggering as the accomplishment of its completion.

It depicts life in the way that we live it -- unfortunately that can be rather drab. The real triumph in "Boyhood" is the dedication it took to orchestrate its production throughout the course of many years. If it wins Best Picture, it will be only in appreciation of that effort. Patricia Arquette is a rather pedestrian version of a mom in transition, and does not seem much different from her character in "Medium." Coltrane starts out as a gorgeous and serious child who morphs into a reserved, lackadaisical albeit bland adult. He and his sister lose the vibrant vigor that made them interesting children. Mom never seems to find herself in juxtaposition to her kids. If this film sends any message to its audience it is "life doesn't get any better as you get older, only duller."

The sheer ambition of this film was amazing.  How do you make the most realistic "coming of age" film... by filming the same kids over the course of 12 years.  It's crazy to see not only the changes in the kids but the adult actors as well.  It's not the most interesting movie you'll ever watch but for what it looked to accomplish it did a great job!

I'm clearly in the minority when it comes to my review of this movie, but I go to the movies to be entertained, to escape from reality, and this was nothing more than a story of a boy growing up dealing with everyday problems. I'm living real life so no need to waste 2:45 watching a movie about it.
He found his people in the end! Brought me back to my extremely shy days
Watched this movie because i heard so many good things about it.  Have to say it was a waste of 2 1/2 hours that i will NEVER get back.  It was boring and not very original.  Blah!!!
Beautiful movie. Encompassed in scope, story evolution and a feel of the coming of age to it's charming protagonist.

This was an amazing film. First of all for being filmed over 12 years and having truly a story about one's boyhood. The film touches upon adolescence and one's boy's view of the world that he is growing up in. This was a rare film that truly kept my attention to it and made it seem like a true, realistic film. I think people can connect in a manner of knowing someone going through what he did, or even personally experiencing it.

I really liked the movie Boyhood. A movie about a boy named Mason from being a little kid until until he goes to college. He goes through lots of challenges. Patricia A. was excellent in this movie. She plays the mom of Mason and shows lots of great emotions. I recommend the movie Boyhood for people who like fictional documentaries and who like long movies (2hrs and 45min).
Simply extraordinary.
Innovative movie with exceptional directing. Boyhood contained a simple yet important message: it is the little moments in our life that define us and make us who we are.
too long...nothing too great
An unusual drama which is excellent.

Featuring some of Richard Linklater's most intimate direction with career best performances from Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, Boyhood may have some clunky dialogue, but it never wavers in its dedication to its compelling themes, and is undeniably epic in a technical scale with its sprawling 12 year narrative scope.

If you were raised in another country or on another planet, this might strike you as interesting or clever. If you grew up in the U.S., this is like watching 12 hours of the most boring home movies of your childhood. Nothing happens. At all. I checked my watch for the first time 32 minutes in. This movie is 100% gimmick and 0% substance. It reminded me of The American, without the edginess or violence. The movie is exquisitely awful.
What a great never before done film. A must watch for any film lover.

This is just an amazing film!  It feels so much like real life, and watching everyone in the film age over the 12 years only reinforces that!  Listening to the music change, watching the historical references evolve, and just enjoying the unraveling of the life of these characters is spellbinding.  I enjoyed the throwbacks to Harry Potter, Roger Clemens, Obama's first election, and "The Landlord".  Oh, and I loved seeing the actor from "Dazed and Confused" still working at a liquor store!  What a great journey!

As a concept, Boyhood is quite extraordinary. The amount of planning and commitment that must have gone into this project is probably more than any other movie ever made until now. However, that being said, I'm somewhat dissapointed in the story itself. It's an excelent portray of what it's like to grow up in the USA. It's pretty relatable, sure, but I was there expecting to see something happen at the end, something like the consequences of having such a life. But it doesn't really feel like there was a conclusion. The boy was pretty neutral through all out his life. How do we know if that was a good life or a bad one? I guess it's more of a "enjoy the journey, not the goal" kind of movie.

Good movie. It was fun watching this boy grow up on the movie screen along with his family.  It was sad when his mom got depressed over being left alone.  She had been married and divorced and had to sell her home. That is kind of where I am now so I can relate to that.  ð~
An interesting experiment whose individuals scenes are greater than their sum.
This movie is way over rated, there are scenes that were embarrassingly horribly acted, C+ picture... IF you are in the mood

A fascinating look at the moments that come together an adult. The film can occasionally feel a little disjointed, since it is essentially a series of vignettes, hopping from year to year, but that is likely the point. Linklater skillfully presents each of these moments, none of which are essential, none of which would be considered "defining" or "life altering" in the sense usually expected of a film narrative, but weaves them in such a way as to allow the audience to absolutely understand who this boy is by the time he becomes an adult. By the end of the film, it's unlikely that you will remember many of the scenes, but, much like real life,they all coalesce into a wonderful whole. It may be too slow moving for some, but those with a little patience will be richly rewarded.

What a beautiful film! A remarkable 12 year project full which manages to tell this long story without a dull moment. The film follows a boy from childhood into adolescence moving swiftly through time into the major milestones of this boys life. The relationships in the film come across so organic that I cared about every character in the movie; flaws or no flaws. I can imagine this movie being done with different actors playing the boys character at different stages of his life but I dont think the age changes would flow as natural as they do here. This film made me happy, sad and at points i was filled with fear when the characters were in danger. I highly recommend this film simply because there is nothing out there like it. The film is quite lengthy but by the end of the film I only wanted more! This film is available on Redbox for now but its totally a blind buy if you see it at the store. You wont be disappointed; unless you dont have a soul.
Interesting to watch the kid grow up on screen but the movie had no point and was very long.

Ambitious. Epic. Persistent. Dedicated. 

'A' for effort. 

That's the good side of this unique theatrical undertaking that follows the tumultuous life a boy's stuttering steps into manhood.

Rushed. Disjointed. Stereotypical. Random. Bludgeoning. 

'A' for effort, unfortunately it's 'C' work. 

That's the other side of this unique theatrical undertaking that has some nice moments but is hamstrung by performances that are generally lacking - woefully lacking in some cases - in disjointed and stereotypically perceived moments of boyhood that we stay with just long enough to begin caring about the characters and consequences when the film randomly jumps ahead months and/or years. We know this because suddenly and unsubtly there's less hair or more hair or differently colored hair or there's a baby or the baby's a toddler or the Apple product placement has changed (iMac > iBook > MacBook > iPod > iPhone).

Ambitious. Rushed. Epic. Disjointed. Persistent. Stereotypical. Dedicated. Random.

Bludgeoning.

So, in the end. I guess in some unwieldy, and I'd argue, likely unintentional manner, the film manages to capture some of the essence of boyhood.

"I thought there'd be more," sobs his mom near the end.

Yeah. Me too.

So much better than I expected. I usualy find his characters boringly chatty. I've even reversed my good opinion of his first film after realizing he wasn't being ironic about his boringly chatty hipsters - he really thought they were interesting. Anyhoo, this one is primarily of interest for being made over twelve years, but the material shows a great improvement in restraint as a writer and, so, as a director.

One of the most painful, agonizingly boring and depressing movies I've ever seen.  At the end of it, I was wishing and still wish I could get the 3 hrs of my life back that I wasted watching that movie.  Watching paint dry on a wall is more entertaining.
love the whole story, all the process that becoming a grown-up. But when we grow as time goes by, it will trap.

Richard Linklater is a master of low key, dialog driven drama where nothing much happens on the outside. "Boyhood" is true Linklater with its laid-back pace and undecorated scenes where acting and writing carry the story. Broader strokes of cinematography are reserved for few scenes where they serve as effects.

Linklater shot the movie during 12 years, which makes "Boyhood" a curiosity in and of itself. Story-wise, the extended decade of production doesn't really show- the film doesn't seem to be aware of its most marketable gimmick- but it does indeed lend the viewing experience a certain sense of authenticity. The way the characters, actors as well as Linklater's direction evolve over the course of the two-and-a-half hour so that the movie getting better and better becomes an engrossing element of its own. I was especially impressed by Patricia Arquette, who has never been one of my favorite actors. She starts off really awkward, I felt, but ends up giving a solid performance by the end of her long assignment. I still think she won an Oscar from the role mostly because of her dedication.

The film starts two years after the turn of the Millennium and follows its main character Mason (Ellar Coltrane) from the age of six into his adulthood at 18. Mason lives with his mother (Arquette) and elder sister (the directors daughter, competent Lorelei Linklater). His life is infrequently inhabited by his divorced father (Ethan Hawke).

Nothing specific or particularly dramatic ever happens, and the film feels much longer than its already lengthy duration, but never at any point does it get tedious. The true narrative occurs just beneath the surface. Linklater depicts normal life and captures the journey of growing up tenderly and often beautifully. And yes, the film seems to be in all its understating humility about nothing less that time itself. The way time molds the faces of the actors, the minds of the characters, the visual style of the film and the music we hear. The soundtrack plays a key part, but never steps forward in order to maintain the sense of everything we see being real. There is no movie magic here, and that's a good thing.

What makes "Boyhood" truly alive is that trademark Linklater compassion and warmth that permeates the scenes. There is openness, acceptance and humility here that make the effect of the storytelling ever more powerful.

First half really struck me with the perspective on progress through life that it affords with the reality of ageing. Then I was distracted from this by the excessive accuracy of the essential awkwardness of teenage years.

It is an interesting experiment that I felt, failed. The story is just unremarkable and it certainly pushed my patience to the limit. The characters are just not very interesting nor were the scenes engaging. It was pure voyeurism into the life of an unremarkable and uninteresting family. There wasn't much to tell or much to learn from this movie. 

Running at a ridiculous length of 2 hrs 45 mins, I finished it and wondered if my time could have been better spent. It was just rather mundane. What was really the point of this?

It is akin to Lost in Translation for me but without the gimmick. If you liked Lost in Translation, I suppose you will like this movie.

BOYHOOD was a good depiction of how a boy in middle class America would probably grow up. Nothing spectacular, nothing exciting. Simply growing. Apart from the cinematic uniqueness of the movie, I still wouldn't have given it such a high rating as most critics have. It's not entertainment, it's an experiment in cinematography.

An admirable effort made during 12 years of making, ends up delivering an average drama film full of predictable happenings and family drama cliches. Showing average acting except for Patricia Arquette, the only remarkable fact about this film is the risk, effort and vision that implies to film the same actors during 12 years, and the simplicity that came out from it to the big screen.

While I appreciate the incredible feat of shooting a movie over the course of a dozen years and have it look and feel seamless (as well as the consistency of the actors), the overall experience of watching this movie was disappointment and ultimately, resentment for wasting my time watching a boring, self-centered kid and his boring, insolent  sister for the better part of 3 hours. Other than finding something he likes and is good at (photography), "Mason" never achieves any real measurable evolution or growth; he continues to whine his way through the whole movie. I kept waiting for a catharsis of some kind, for a light bulb to go off, so he could finally realize how fortunate he actually was, but it never happened. By the end it just seemed that his mopieness was a permanent condition.
A long and boring film. it was only Interesting because of being filmed over a period of 12 years.  There was no real plot. It was more like a diary.
Great story line one of the best movies i've seen
If I wanted to be depressed I would just watch the news.
No plot just a gimmick that seems to have caught on. Nothing happens in this movie! Nothing!
A fantastic movie that spans literally throughout 12 years, Boyhood shouldn't be missed by anyone.

Brutal
No story and went nowhere.
A 12-year journey through the life of a boy and his family.  Boyhood is simply one of the most unique films I've ever seen.
this movie was good even though it was about nothing really and it was quite slow. quite interesting how they used the same actors while filming for twelve years so you do see the same not grow up.

Beautiful in it's simplicity, and full of great performances, Boyhood is an intimate and very unique kind of coming of age story. Richard Linklater's bold experiment came to fruition as a personally resonating take on the human condition. ~ A-

I don't get how this waste of two and a half hours is getting great reviews. This movie was as pointless as Napoleon Dynamite making Napoleon Dynamite better for stupid humor. I would have had a better time in the dentists chair getting a root canal.

In "Boyhood", Richard Linklater gives new meaning to the phrase: coming-of-age. Linklater is one who likes to follow his subjects over a period of time. His "Before" film series (Before Sunrise, Before Sunset and Before Midnight) followed the lives of two adults for almost two decades after a meeting by chance on a train from Budapest to Vienna. "Boyhood" does the same. It is filmed over 12 years with the same cast and follows the lives of a boy and his family over that same period of time.

Such effort, without a doubt, is very ambitious and Linklater pulls it off in grand fashion in this groundbreaking tale of growing up in a family raised by a single mother while at the same time showcasing the various terrains involved in parenthood. Experimental in a certain way, Linklater pushes the bar on the art of filmmaking to a level that has not been done before.

Linklater's approach is more than just a gimmick. Instead of real time, there is another way to tell this story using different actors and makeup to show the aging of characters and passing of time. Instead, he opted for a more challenging course producing better results in terms of connecting with its characters and story. Its narrative is affecting with an affirmation that comes close to its 2 1/2 hour mark. And when it is all over, there is a feeling of association to everything that just unfolded onscreen. The performances of newcomer Ellar Coltrane (Mason) and Patricia Arquette are both worth noting.

In terms of production, this is definitely an interesting film. Twelve years in the making is nothing to be laughed at.
Unfortunately, everything about the rest of the film IS something to be laughed at. The script was written as production continued, and it shows. The dialogue is wooden and the narrative meanders with no clear purpose. This is not The Bicycle Thieves. 
I had high hopes for Boyhood, but before long it became obvious that Linklater was not going to let anything happen to Mason. While Mason and his family struggled to make ends meat in the world, falling from one horrible situation to another for a long time, I never felt that there were ever any stakes on the table. Linklater refused to let anything happen to his characters, and as a result, all tension was lost.
The character of Mason didn't help either. Always quiet, never up or attempting to change the world around him, I couldn't help but feel that Mason must have been on some form of anti-depressant. He is a blank slate from start to finish.
All in all, while this Boyhood's method of production was impressive, it's narrative is completely void of life and tension.

It got plain story and very lengthy and gets boring sometimes. Really tests the patience. It's incredible that they made this film for 12 years and that makes this movie special.Hats off to the team for coming up with a movie which is indeed an experiment.An audacious attempt that is getting overwhelming recognition.

Boring. Maybe my expectations were too high, or maybe I'm missing something, but how could anyone think this movie is epic or a masterpiece. Was this movie even scripted or did a man with a camera just follow an ordinary kid for 12 years? I just don't get it, so much hype about nothing. I was always expecting something to happen, but nothing ever did. Total snooze fest.

Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke do a good job. Nice story told through an extended period of time. I was not blown away. I am surprised that this is the front runner for the Oscar this year. It was "aight"
A revelation to modern film making. You've yet to ever see fictional cinema get as close to real life as Boyhood.

I was disappointed by Boyhood. In the pursuit of realism, Richard Linklater spent 12 years making this, so that we could see the characters grow, change and age. Yet he sacrificed realism by casting his own daughter as Samantha; she was not believable as the daughter of Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette. The dialogue was weak, the themes were tired, and the messages were simplistic and overly sentimental. Ethan Hawke, however, gave a great performance. 
Where are the films that challenge us?
Good concept.  Way too long.  I was bored the last half hour.

It was interesting seeing the physical changes over the course of 12 years of all of the characters.  That alone makes the movie with watching.  Still, there was nothing exceptional about the script, acting or story. It was more like a drawn out documentary of the challenges of a single mom and her children.  That in my humble opinion is not Oscar worthy.

Watched this after all the hype and was very disappointed.  The acting was not that compelling.  The story was boring.  It was too close to real life and it almost felt like I was intruding.  There were few points of emotion or confrontation and those seemed contrived.  I appreciated the experiment of making a movie over 12 years, but it felt like 12 years getting through those tedious 3 hours.  For film study and art, which i guess is what awards are for, it was an interesting exercise.  For entertainment value, it was a total bust.

This movie is a masterpiece, a movie about life.  It is beautifully shot, well performed and a fulfilling experience.  The emotions and drama growing up as a kid are there, and I cannot help but feel connected to this movie, as I'm sure countless others do. The most rewarding part of the movie is you watch the character grow up and figure out who he is and wants to be as he interacts with the people and situations around him, which I feel is something everybody can relate to.  It can be slow at times and just seems to droll on occasionally, but this is a film that describes life and growing up, and the way it is made and the result of it is unique and breathtaking.  Plus the music is great.

At almost 3 hours and filmed over 12 years tracking the growth of Mason and the people in his life from when he is a 6 year old till entering college at 18, this is a movie of everyday life of an American family with no real plot but it is so captivating by virtue of being an authentic study of the human condition. It quietly grabs us with an enduring emotional impact as we can identify with our personal experience of the many moments and universal life truths that reveal themselves throughout the movie. More than an innovative film technique where we see the same actors actually age through the movie, the result is a truly monumental movie experience. Some say it's a Linklater masterpiece. I can't argue with that.

BTW, as a photographer, the "darkroom chat" scene was one that had a personal connection.
A lifetime packed into 2.5 hours, outstanding.
Another spectacular Linklater movie.  I could be a critic, but its so much more fun being a fan.
A really well done film by Richard Linklater. Believable writing and quality acting spread out over 12 years. A surprisingly cohesive and poignant coming-of-age story.
Id rather watch paint dry over that length of time.
3 hours of boredom to reach no point at all!

A story without plot is life, and that's what Boyhood delivers. Linklater masterfully depicts the most crucial life-defining moments of a boy's entire childhood in the course of two and a half hours. He succeeds in narrating a vivid account so personal that the viewer is fooled into forgetting it is a work of fiction. Linklater intentionally forces the viewers to transcend the confines of traditional structure and into a unique viewing experience. Whereas traditionally the viewer waits for a film to spell out why something is happening or surmise what is going to happen next, this film allows us to watch the story the way we lived our own childhood - moment by moment.
Beautifully exhausting! and let's add this to the list of most amazing scripts.
I believe that the 12 years of production going into this movie was well worth it. The only downside was the kid acting in the beginning of the movie. But it improved as the movie progressed.
Probably the most unique film I had ever seen.

There are those dreaded words again: "the human condition." When those words pop up in a movie description, I know the movie is going to have a lot of kitchen sinks. Watching people age over the course of 12 years of filming is, well, very ambitious, to say the least, even if it's just watching people do pretty ordinary things. The movie should have been called, "People Do Stuff Over 12 Years." Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke are always wonderful, but the gamble here is the young cast. If you film kids over 12 years, you just don't know what kind of actors they will be... or if they will ever act again after your Oscar-begging cinematic experiment. The answers are "pretty awkward" and "not very likely."
Very cool movie. Nostalgic. I cried. I really liked the people and wanted the best for them all. And they say "real life" movies can't be interesting? This held my attention through and through.
3 hour snooze fest.   Cool concept,  poor execution.

This one of a kind movie was filmed over 12 years, and although more work than you can imagine was put into it - I wasn't always sure it was worth it while watching it. Nevertheless, it's length and powerhouse performances make it an overall good film.

At first glance, Boyhood may seem like any other coming-of-age drama. However, under the skin, it is a beautiful journey of self realization and how we view moments in our life as some of the most influential components of human existence. Performances in this film do not feel like performances; these actors feel, talk and act as if this film is chronicling real life events.
Brilliant - must watch movie
It is a great film how they made, shot, and edited was better then the story. I liked the story but it was pretty generic I know it is nominated for best picture but I don't think it should win.

Phenomenal 

When you think back to Slackers you remember how easy that movie flowed. How comfortably it drifted. Just go with it. Let it happen, live in the moment. Then there's the Before trilogy which again seemed effortless and free-flowing yet constructed with so much care that you knew this filmmaker was not only unusual, but acutely human. That he cherished experience and learning and submitted to the eternal present, surrendering to and tinkering with fate, while tending to the perpetually immediate situation with enormous sensitivity and regard. 

But nothing could prepare you for Boyhood. You can't overstate the fact that it's a grand free-flowing time-lapse experiment and that most of the actors--no not actors, not performers--most of the people were cast when the central figure was a very young boy, looking up at the sky, having no idea how his future would unfold. The world might be a stage but Richard Linkater is not omnipotent. As a definitive work-in-progress, a daring collaboration with fate and destiny, who could really know how the boy's script was going to turn out, and how the wide array of voices in his life would shape him as he stumbles toward adulthood? Only a true sure-footed and fluid filmmaker, an authentic disarming innovator could raise this baby with as much beauty and wisdom. Dazed and Confused? Make room for Clear and Composed.

Hear the lamb howl. Boyhood is a daring experimental wolf wrapped in conventional wool. Needing to be shot chronologically, the linear time-line and 12-year shooting schedule called for a fresh and original approach to crafting a movie. If something went wrong during the many long gaps in production, say, if an actor suddenly became unavailable, or some drastic circumstance threatened to break the continuity of the boy and his family's life, there's no going back to re-shoot. No relying on special effects make-up or casting young and old versions of a character. The faith invested in this concept and the delicate handling of it's execution is a marvel to witness, blooming before our eyes. 

Patricia Arquette was growing up too. Aging faster than Ellar Coltrane, it appeared. This movie defies breaking up into a series of disjointed, episodic fragments. And Arquette stitches together an admirable and dedicated performance as the ubiquitous maternal defender who struggles to keep herself and her family from falling apart. Because of the blur between fiction and reality, between drama and documentary, and because of the way Linklater is able to nurture the process and allow his films to take on a life of their own, Arquette may not be acting on set any more than she has to in real life. A slight adjustment in perspective and this movie could have been called Motherhood.
just wow ... beautiful movie

I am not a fan of Richard Linklater's films. A couple are enjoyable enough but I've never seen anything that made me sit up and pay attention. I chose to skip "Boyhood" for these reasons but ultimately succumbed so I'm fully knowledgeable when I attend Colleen's annual Oscar party. 

I was pleasantly surprised to find a fully realized story of life. I enjoyed watching the various aspects of personhood, from childhood (Mason and Samantha's K-12 years), adulthood (Mom, Dad and the various successive step-parents), young adulthood (Mason in university), and retirement (the various grandparents). I quite liked how Linklater was able to tie them all together by showing the way young people influence older people (in both good ways such as teaching and bad ways such as throwing glassware) as well as the way older people influence the young. He spoke to friendships and mentoring and support groups and really poked around in the way human beings relate to each other. 

The acting was fine, with Patricia Arquette being the obvious standout performance. The direction was solid, but I think the writing was really what was worth of recognition.

This an excellent shout for Best Director Oscar, as Richard Linklater has crafted a really natural, believable and realistic family saga from his mammoth 12-year production time.  But sadly, for me, neither the story nor the performances scream out "great movie".  Everything's just a little bit flat and ordinary, a bit rambling.  Like real life, yes, but that's not what I necessarily want from a film.  I'm still not sure why Arquette is Oscar-nominated either...  This is a worthy and impressive project, but there are so many more entertaining and engaging films doing the rounds.

Being able to follow a family for 14 years is interesting enough, in its own right, watching each individual grow & change... but that's about it... Where's the excitement? Where's the drama? overall I felt it was long & a bit drawn out  maybe even over rated a bit.
Just spectacular. Worth the wait.

It is no fun when you have such a unique idea for a film, and when the final product is all said and done, it falls on its face. Boyhood captures the life of Mason, and follows him and his family through 12 years of his life. But, to quote a dear friend, it felt like it took 12 years to watch this movie. A long and drawn out movie with little to no plot, little to no drama and really painful acting at times. Ethan Hawke shines in his role as the father who is trying to make a difference. Everyone else is fizzles, unfortunately. Very disappointing.

I did like it a lot, although Birdman is better in my opinion.

Whereas, I can appreciate the fact the no one has filmed a movie over a twelve year span using the same actors, I found the storyline sorely lacking. Anyone who has raised kids into their teens has "been there done that". Nothing new or interesting. Nearly three hours of my life I'll never get back.

Risky in its undertaking but well worth it in the end, thanks to Richard Linklater's direction, Boyhood takes what could have been pretentious and boring and finds the poeticness and wonder in the everyday like most Linklater films.

Beautiful film with an intimacy the likes of which I've never experienced in film before, impacting me strongly. As a parent, it makes me want to hug my kids, be the best father I can. 

Highly recommend

What could have been a fairly conventional indie drama about a young boy's experience growing up in a broken but loving family is elevated to a watershed moment in cinema history thanks to an ingeniously-conceived and patiently-executed high concept approach. Instead of casting multiple actors to play the boy over the 12 years the story covers, director Richard Linklater actually directed the film over the course of 12 years, filming his star Ellar Coltrane as the actor grew from a boy into a teenager and eventually a young man. The tone and style of the film is very much in line with other entries in the Linklater canon, especially Slacker and Waking Life, and he explores similar themes. It's not as overtly philosophical as some of his previous work, but it doesn't need to be. His process is philosophical enough. The real key to the success of this film is the patience with which it was crafted. Hollywood has turned into a blockbuster factory line, with each studio scrambling to quickly capitalize on what the newest trend or hottest property is, often releasing sequels and remakes at a pace so breathless that very little thought is put into the content of the films. Linklater has completely eschewed this mentality and crafted what is not only a film that will stay in your thoughts for a long time (as many of Linklater's films do) but a true work of cinematic artistry.

Boyhood is a movie twelve years in the making and twelve years in the watching, but in those twelve years, truthful and from-the-heart performances are shared with audiences. It narrates the realistically flawed life of one boy into manhood, while not really having much resembling a plot.

The concept is original, but the movie doesn't contain the sense of continuity that a project like this should. Some scenes seem to be inserted just to pad the whole thing out, but add nothing to the themes that run through the movie. The ending is a disappointment.

Alfred Hitchcock is purported to have said about movies, "They are like life, with the boring parts taken out." This movie had the boring parts put back in. If you want a story, conflict, resolution, all those things which to me make a good movie, you won't find it here. The Hollywood elite and the intelligentsia are all gaga over it. Ok. They can have it.
Fantastic Movie, would recommend bit long but extremely well shot and very good pacing. The movie felt so relateable if from a slightly younger perspective

I just watched the film here in Mexico. I am 53 years old and there is no doubt that BOYHOOD is one of the best movies I´ve ever seen: as simple as that. No need to review, it is a mood changer movie, and brings up emotions no other movie has ever done. I highly recommend this movie, to watch it along with your family. Director Richard Linklater is a genius. BOYHOOD received six Academy Award nominations, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Edition, Best Original Script and acting nominations for Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke.?

Review for Boyhood:

Boyhood, Richard Linklater's long and detailed chronicle of a young boy growing up from childhood to adulthood. The film literally tells the life of Mason Evans, a young boy, whose life we are introduced to at the age of six and follow him and his hardships and tribulations as we see him grow up from a small child, to a full grown adult, key word being "literally". Why? Because the movie takes a 12 year lifespan chronicling his entire life, seeing all the best parts of growing up, as well as all the worst parts. The movie's 12 year lifespan isnt just in camera; the film was shot in over 12 years, from 2002 to 2014 using all the same actors, reprising their roles as they grew up with age, and with the movie, giving this a legitimate timeless feel. None of the actors, look like their even acting, they dont even look like legitimate actors, even big names like Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, and watching this movie made me feel like watching a really long home movie about this family's life, as I watch them grow up and live through all the stages that life had in store for them. Richard Linklater's vision was genius and incredibly unorthodox to shoot, but the love and dedication that was put into this movie shows from all its dedicated actors, wonderful writing, ingenious directing and beautiful cinematography. I even felt a little bit of nostalgia watching this movie, as like the children in this movie, I also lived through these years and made some of the mistakes they did and seeing the evolution of social media, watching how this family grew up with all the heartbreaks and fun memories spent with one another, it even reminded me of all the hardships my mother went through, though in a different fashion, and made me love and respect her even more than one could already do. Bottom line, Boyhood is a masterpiece and I don't think I've ever seen or ever will see one that lets the viewer grow up with it as it goes along, and even when it abruptly ends and the camera stops shooting, life doesn't stop for Mason Evans as he continues to live his life even when we can't see it. He grows along more as time progresses, the same as all of us.

Overall Rating: 10 out of 10!

Way overrated.....badly acted except the kids...they are fine...generic material....3 hours w these boring people mostly lame situations is too much to bear....it's hard to believe how many critics wax poetic over this less than mediocre misfire....

Review:
I know that this movie got high reviews, which is why I was really looking forward to watch it, but I personally found it pretty boring. The whole pace of the film was slow and after watching watching 2 kids and there mum growing up over 12 years, it really didn't seem like anything major happened all the way through this 2 and a half hour movie. I was hoping that there was going to be a twist or some form of an incident which would change the tone of the film, but nothing really happens. Your basically watching 2 kids adapting to there mothers failed relationships, whilst keeping a grounded relationship with there dad. There are a couple of emotional scenes but I can't really see why the critics raved about this film. Don't get me wrong, it is well written and the actors do play there parts well and I did feel for the mum who had to bring up her children under extreme circumstances but when the movie had finished, I couldn't remember a scene which I found outstanding. Anyway, it's worth a watch if your into your deep dramas and don't mind watching normal family values for over 2 hours, but I personally lost interest after a while. Average!

Round-Up:
This movie really made a serious profit at the box office and with 6 nominations at this year's Oscars, the audiences must have really loved watching this family grow over 12 years. I liked the whole flow of the movie because it really doesn't seem like so many years have passed. The only problem is that none of the characters go through a major incident like most families do. Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette, who play the loving parents, played there parts extremely well and they made the movie seem realistic and emotional, along with the kids who adapted to ever tricky situation well, but I drifted off after a while. Maybe if I watched it again, in a different mood, I might enjoy it more.

One of the worst movies I can recall seeing in the last 20 years. Other than the "it took 12 years to make" gimmick this movie went nowhere, lacked any serious character development, no plotline, no tension or release and no ending. Other than some mildly interesting acting it was a total bore from first frame to the last. The other people I saw it with were equally mystified. That it has been nominated for awards shows how low the bar is set to recieve accolades.

Never has so little taken place on so much film. I can't believe so many people wasted so many years of their lives making a movie where nothing happens to a bunch of characters that you care nothing about. The boy is as unlikable and boring a character as has ever been on film and his surrounding cast is not any better. 

I have never reached the end of a film and felt so angry about wanting 3 hours.
Good job Richard Linklater. An exceptional coming of age story.

Filmed over 12 years this movie really presents a different and new viewing experience.  Over the twelve years you watch the characters as they age and develop, from 6 years old to 18 and leaving home.

  Although a monstrous two hours and forty five minutes the time passes relatively fast.  The constant transitioning of time periods forces the movie forwards, creating new story lines and sub plots.  Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke's stellar performances also enriches and strengthens the story.
 
 In regards to the half a star I left out - Mason throughout the first half was endearing, charming and completely captivating.  Upon his latter teenage years he was replaced with a brooding teenager who spent more time flicking his hair than talking.  I found myself not caring about him as much as did prior to this transition.  The pretentious monologues and angsty silence started to irk me.
  Without telling ya any spoilers - the scene of the Hispanic male reuniting with Mason's mother (Patricia Arquette), seemed contrived, cliched and unrealistic - all of which I felt Linklater has tastefully avoided up to this point.

Despite its minor flaws this movie is both relatable and undeniably powerful. It will leave you thinking about it for days after.  A unique cinematic experience which is a overwhelming success due to it's genius concept and accomplished acting - 4 1/2 stars
