Wow. Just wow. This is the most spectacular film I have ever seen. So relatable and so real. The acting is phenomenal and the story is just so moving. It gives such a great view on the world and on life. Well done Richard, well done.

It was horrible. Boring and unengaging. Can't believe it scored so high with the critics and viewers on this site. I love movies and have never walked out in the middle of one before but it took all my will power not to walk out on this one. Talk about over-hyped!!! Apparently many have fallen for the brainwashing -- I must like this since the critics loved it! Ha. Well, the movie views like a documentary but it's NOT a documentary -- it's fiction. So it fails at both being a documentary and being fiction. The movie is disjointed - it patches together different scenes shot at different ages of the boy's life. This ruins the normal engaging dramatic flow that almost every other movie has. Also, the boy is a sullen introvert. Can't blame him for the sullen part, as he has to deal with a messed up family situation. But the introvert part makes it NOT interesting to watch the kid and not engaging to follow his life. The different events that happen as he matures are basically accurate to portray a boy coming of age, but again, the viewer could care less because of the disjointed, boring flow. Is it interesting to see the actors ACTUALLY age in real life? Sure, but a REAL documentary could do the same thing, whereas it's just a gimmick in this lifeless, boring film. And the whole single mom/rebel dad is very cliche/stereotypical, as are most of the characters in the film. In the end, the boy is so existential about life by the time he enters college that it's depressing. Life goes by too quick to be bogged down in depressing existentialism when you are only 18!!!! For the love of God RELAX and maybe try to enjoy life??!! The movie plods along boring and not engaging to watch, and then a bunch of disturbing things happen to the family, making it now UNPLEASANT to watch. Yep, a lot not to like about the movie. That's my review. Save yourself the nearly THREE HOURS this movie lasts and go ENJOY life. :)

So I watched ??Boyhood? I really can't recommend it. It is entirely harmless, but nothing happens, almost no one is likable and the "protagonist" spouts vacuous statements for the entirety of the end of the movie. Wasn't offended by most of it, but that is the best I can say about it.
A quote from the director that sums it up - "People ask what happens and I say 'Not much'". And he is right no much happens, despite it spanning 12 years all we just see a bunch of random glimpse in the life of a increasingly irritating kid (From bad acting that evolves into tiresome tirades about nothing)
But it took 12 years to make, so it will likely win an Oscar and go on to be remembered in the same way as The Artist is.

Very interesting how they filmed over 12 years. It felt like through the years it was a natural progression for the most part but choppy at times. The movie didn't seem like it was about anything for the almost 3 hours. The movie is called boyhood but there were more interesting story lines in some of the other characters. Each of those other story lines showed how they can effect each other.
Overall I would say it wasn't good and it wasn't bad.

The overly-romantic glorification of everyday regular lives, coupled with some very iffy and sappy dialogue that masquerades as worldly wisdom makes 'Boyhood' a kind of indie blockbuster in ambition and in scope. The story here is largely devoid of any real meaning, as the portrayal of life can't be it's sole purpose for existing. If I want to 'experience' 'real life', I got enough of that in my own real one, thank you very much. The acting is casual, some better than others, the characters absolutely uninteresting, the direction is what some might call minimal, I would call it visually unimpressive. What can commend here is the magnificent PR and marketing campaign behind the film. They sold it like it's pure genius, given it's 12 year shooting schedule and artistic ambition. Needless to say, it's not, and it's pretty far from it. But why listen to me, watch it and lets discuss.

Boyhood is a fascinating experiment in filmmaking. Watching the actors grow up over the course of 12 years is a truly unique experience. I also like that the main characters are good people - they're not perfect, but they're trying to do their best. This movie is like watching someone's home movies...if their home movies were beautifully shot and wonderfully acted. This was a very ambitious film and I'm glad I saw it. I also look forward to seeing "Boyhood 2: Manhood" in another 12 years.

Well, I guess I should be happy that I now have a great contender for WORST movie of the year so early in the game. So mindlessly boring. Linklater, I want my three hours back! (The one star is for the soundtrack only!)

There really is very little reason to see this film, other than the hype it has attracted, and its twelve year production gimmick. Otherwise its dull, shot like a soap opera, lazily written, and tells us nothing. Bugger all happens. The characters may grow and age before our eyes but we learn very little about them, and nothing about life, the human condition, etc. more profound than people change as times passes. Which might be one of lifes great truths, but really isnt all that interesting a point to spin out over the course of one hundred and sixty five minutes. 
If youve heard of Boyhood youll have heard that it took twelve years to make. Youll be aware that Richard Linklater (the guy who did over-rated teen stoner classics Dazed and Confused and Slacker) decided he was going to make a sort of realist bildungsroman film, casting an eight year old in 2001 and then continuing to film them over the course of twelve years as he grows up, matures, and experiences- amongst other things- his parents divorce, a drunk stepfather, first loves and first spliffs. There is a cast of other recurring characters, including the kids father played by Ethan Hawke, and his mother played by Patricia Arquette, who also age and mature over the course of the drama, albeit not as dramatically because yknow, puberty. Youll also be all too aware that the film has been lavished with critical praise and award nominations, with a 95% rating at the top of this page, and a Best Picture Oscar nomination. To take a few choice sound bites, its been described as an important landmark in how great films are made, the greatest coming of age story ever put to film, and a masterpiece by various esteemed voices. 
And yet for all that the film really has nothing to it. Its nothing more than a gimmick. The emperor has no clothes. Because as technically ground-breaking as it is to shoot a film over the course of twelve years, its also pointless. What does it say? It stands as a documentary record of the ageing process, and very little else. Characters come and go, drifting in and out of the narrative as listlessly as our protagonists zits and haircuts. No phase of Masons life can be properly scrutinized, explored, or felt by the audience because within ten minutes of one potentially interesting scenario being set up, Linklater is cutting ahead another year, because look! His sisters dyed her hair now! Hes got an Adams Apple! Now hes drinking beer with emo kids! Now his Texas Hillbilly grandfathers teaching him how to massacre wild ducks!  The overall effect is to create a narrative we can only follow at surface level, and characters who we find first boring and then annoying, as the bit-part kids grow up to be bad actors and we slowly realise that the central character has less depth than an 18-36 month paddling pool. 
His drunken step-father is a caricature, a panto villain. He seems obsessed by control, beats his wife and drinks all the time. We have no idea why he is such an asshole. He features intermittently for all of thirty minutes and then is gone. Masons mum leaves him and thats the end of him, as far as the film is concerned. Masons sister, played without flair by Linklaters own daughter, goes from being a stroppy brat to a mellow and well-adjusted young woman in the blink of an eye. There is no discernible character arc, just a transition as rapid as a change of scene. Likewise their mother herself appears to have no notable features whatsoever. Early in the film she expresses her frustration that shes had kids too early. Later on she starts a career as a psychology lecturer. At one point she pointlessly advises a Mexican handyman to start at night school. She cries when Mason goes off to college, complaining that she has nothing left. As far as the audience is concerned, she never had anything in the first place. She, like every other character, including Mason himself, is nothing more than a cipher. 

The film is concerned mainly with adolescence. The problem is that we feel almost none of the turmoil of puberty because our main character is too grounded, too sensible and frankly too dull. Why a film-maker would choose to make a coming of age film about a mature and contented kid who seems to find almost no struggle in life is beyond me. At no point is Mason especially awkward or angsty. We dont seem him cry, we dont see him fail, we dont see in him any burning desire to express himself or rebel or break away. He just sort of strolls on through, laughing at other peoples jokes, rubbing along and experimenting with his hair. His teenage years are seen only as a series of flat vignettes- forced dialogue about Star Wars on a fishing trip with his father, giggling to his mother about having been out smoking weed, laughing from the side-lines as a friend is bullied by older kids. He faces only two difficulties, a pedestrian break-up when hes eighteen with a girl we see in about three scenes, and weighing up whether or not to study photography. Thats it. Thats his entire life. Its impossible to like him or to relate to him on any level. 
Boyhood is like watching someone elses home videos for nearly three hours- Youve Been Framed with slower cuts and no slapstick. In its less flat moments the endless mid-shots and domestic dialogue make it feel like a second rate TV drama. When its at its weakest its just a series of unrelated filler scenes from a Soap Opera. The experience of watching Boyhood is like being sober at a terrible party, listening to people you dont know make small talk, suspecting youll never see them again and feeling no remorse at the prospect. Its occasional lunges at profundity are nothing more than pseudo-hippy bollocks. In the final scene Mason walks through a gulch with some college friends hes only just met to take hallucinogens. The cinematography remains flat, and the acting barely changes despite the drugs. He sits and has a bullshit cosmic conversation with some girl we dont care about. The final line of the film is Mason saying its like; the moment its constant. Nothing better exposes the shallow premise and weak writing of this film. Dont waste your time with it.
Amazing achievement and some authentic nods to the period when filmed. But really nothing special and wouldn't have stood out if not filmed over 12 years...

I wanted to see this ambitious film since I first heard about it nearly two years ago.  I wish it had lived up to expectation, but sadly it was little more than a self-indulgent art project that the culture-police believe is far grander than it really is.  Mason, Jr.'s life is so remarkably clichè because it is simply the "new" normal.  It begs the question: who doesn't know somebody having a near identical experience, or have lived it themselves?  One can assert that as 'the point' of the film, but is that also not just pandering to an audience seeking self-affirmation? In my opinion, it fails as a cultural critique because it merely documents the 'draaahma' of a slightly updated coming of age story but does little to expose the the mechanisms of the pernicious externalities produced by a post-modern society that has rejected the moorings of traditional 'social repression,' nor has it liberated anyone from an even worse negative spiral.  Ironically, the application of critical theory to the normalcy message of the aimlessness of the median American adolescent suggests that being the child of fully "liberated" parents just sucks--it is despondent and bleak.  How has the hegemony of nihlism's meme liberated Mason's family?
Had some really spot on moments of truth. Felt like I was watching a documentary.

To me this is a 6 star movie. To develop and direct these characters over 12 yrs. in a story that plays like a great novel. for actors to stay in character over this period of time and portray growth and aging maintain the same story line is just awesome.  Filmmaking at its best. So worth the price of admission
Just like a Taylor Swift song, "It'll leave you breathless..."
Boring. Snooze fest. Seriously how did this get good reviews?
12 years???  It seemed like it lasted 20 years.  If you want to see a boring, depressing movie then see this one.
wasted 2 hours of my life compared to their 12 years, my loss is not as great. last hour, i just closed my eyes hoping it never happened. :-(
Like watching The Tree of Life with worse actors.
Wonderful movie- so much feeling :')
The concept was great. The actually story told, or lack of story really, was terrible. Literally nothing happens in the movie.
Very good film, although you can tell that there were breaks in filming. Its not completely seamless.

It provides us with an open view of growing up and the way that we all experience by watching this film, from
 this small boy to an adult that goes to college. Also,masterfully directed and interwoven all of the events through these 12 years of filming to create this consice story into this about this 3 hr film.
Wonderful movie- so much feeling.

If I was not aware of the dedication it took to make this movie I would have just given it 2 stars. It was just like any coming of age movie. I didn't really care for any of the characters. I'm sorry but I just didn't get the hype behind this movie besides the 12 years it took to make it.

probably one of the most beautiful and amazing find that I have seen in years. An amazing story of real life made in a very ambitious and beautiful way. 

Never before has a film taken the same cast and shot over 12 years to tell the story of one young man and the family around him, and the result is an amazing cinematic glimpse at life, love and family.
Extremely long and nothing ever happens. I mean nothing.
After 40 minutes, I had no clue if there was a story here. Other than being filmed over 12 years, this was just (almost) 3 hours of a camera following a kid around.

Boyhood
a movie about perspective,
a simple film about how life should be, there's no over-created things everythings just flowed nicely.

Most actors commit themselves to a 3-6 month shoot with the possibility of the need for scenes to be reshot. The principals in this movie made a twelve-year commitment to a recurrent project. Seemlessly we see Ellar Coltrane grow from a 5-year-old to 18-year-old manhood college-bound. The others who follow Mason on this journey are the actors who play his Mother, his sister, and Ethan Hawke who plays his biological Father. We see hair styles change, limbs lengthen until 'mother' looks up at son, beards and moustaches come and go and hair show signs of greying. 

Intelligence is no guarantee of wise decisions and Mason watches mom marry and divorce three husbands resulting in too many moves to count. Where his Father is concerned the child is father of the man. Though a recurring presence in Maaon'a life the child who fathered a son remains very much a dilettante throughout. Mother's and Sister's growth are not neglected. These characters are more than props. An interesting sociological study, a decent movie. It's that movie you don't want to admit you didn't like because you just used almost 3 hours of your life you will never get back.  Became more interested in it when I started IMDB'ing (during the movie) and realized that Linklater has written and directed some pretty awesome movies -- yes I should have already known this.  It's one of those movies I would recommend IF there is nothing else to watch and you are stuck inside during a storm or something.  Interesting concept though.  I guess.

Boyhood is like nothing you have ever seen before and will go down in history as a masterpiece. It follows Mason from the ages of 6-18 and is filmed over 12 years. It is the most ambitious film to date and should take home the oscar for best directing and maybe best picture. The actors could have been terrible or even could have died during the making but it all turned out brilliantly. It is the most relatable film in my opinion and is the best coming of age drama ever made. 10/10
Probably more of a 3 star movie, but I'm just amazed the director spent so much time on it.
Sooo boring....yea you see him grow up but its 3 hours with no plot.

Boyhood is boring and hard to relate to. There's no story, 2 dimensional characters, and only a few weak themes. By the end of the 2:40 run time I don't think I have any reason to like Mason. We never see inside Mason's head and never even learn his friends' names. The one-week-a-year-for-12 years gimmick makes the movie incoherent and leaves out half of the milestones of Mason's life. I did like watching the changing society over the span of the 12 years, and I also like the messages about marriage and divorce, but overall, I don't recommend Boyhood.

I respect the film, the work, the acting but maybe I was expecting something else?  I don't know, I just don't really know what to think.

one incredible journey through life and time

Great movie, I really like it.

While this film easily is a real feat in technical terms, filmed over 1 week every year for 12 years, it isn't quite as breathtakingly astounding as some make it sound. Oh yes this is a great film. Watching the same actors grow and change along with their characters over a 12yr period is very thought provoking and the film is very realistic in tone and screenplay. I just caution that it's still a film about a boy growing up while that is put forth very well in "Boyhood" it's also 2hrs 45min long and there are parts(more so later in life) that aren't as compelling as more they are "necessary" (such as the "goth" stage Mason encounters).
Watch someone else's life and see you in the process...
Outstanding in every respect.

Not nearly as good as everyone is saying.  Just because it took 12 years to make doesn't mean it's instantly great.  It gets better as it goes, but it's so long and just drags.

Great idea. Following a family (although only actors) for 12 years... ala through "boyhood". Pretty uneventful to fill nearly three hours of screen time. I feel like it really missed the emotional connect with the actors to the audience. Bad things happened- but never enough was shown to truly bring sympathy/empathy or even show a character's true character in how they reacted or overcame. Interesting, but not captivating.

The only real downside is the fact that it is nearly three hours long. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to get nostalgic for their youth.
a must see, especially for those around my age

Special is a word I reserve for the films that really hit me on an emotional level and this film certainly did that. This is Richard Linklater's finest work to date and truly a masterpiece. This film was filmed over twelve years and used the same actors and characters as we watch them grow before our very eyes. The acting in this film is fantastic from everyone involved especially the mom and dad played by Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke respectively. I was specifically floored by the performance of Hawke and I personally think it is his best work to date.  Also the editing on this movie I can not rave about enough as the characters age we jump through time and this is done seamlessly and with no need to tell the audience how far ahead we had traveled. The plot of the film is often a complaint of the movie because there is no real plot but this fit this film perfectly as life does not have a set plot either. This movie is also criticized for being over the top in some elements of the story and maybe this is not a regular family but it is someones. This movie also neatly shows us recent history in those twelve years all the way from Britney Spears to Harry Potter and Obama's 2008 election. This being my childhood as well really resonated with me on a deeper level. This film like no other before it perfectly captures life as we are just along for the ride as we watch Mason grow and try to find his place in the world. It will make you cry, it will make you rejoice and it will make you wonder at the pure beauty of this film. This is an excellent film that really marks an achievement in cinema. 5/5

Great in cocept but ultimately dissappointing and far from a great movie. Seems to be an upswell of support in America for this examination of life growing up in the states. Definately feels like the rest of the world are not quite so in awe of a rather humdrum story. The acting however is very good but the praise lavished on this movie may be better directed at The Hawkins movie or Selma which are far better in content and  entertainment

if you're into subtleties in life like I do, you'll find this movie extremely beautiful and meaningful in every way. growing up and living through life itself maybe defined by a series of milestones, but in between are these seemingly unimportant experiences that eventually make us who we are.

The concept is interesting, but seriously, this is not a movie. I'd say it's a 5/5 star documental of a boy growing up in Texas, but as an european I don't really get why this move has so much awards and nominations. Of course it's an astonishing work of patience, so it shoud be rewarded with that, an oscar to best persistent and patient director. The consistence of time in the film it's also really well done, I don't think it's easy to make a movie that consistent in a period of 12 years. Good job, but completely overrated.
"Life is what happens while you are busy making other plans", well, this movie is what happens when Linklater sets out to shoot a film over 12 years. I give him credit for that.

by far one of the worst movies i have ever seen. the acting, story, cinematography were all terrible. i have seen lifetime original movies that were better executed than this garbage. everyone is getting caught up in the fact that it took 12 years to film, which is a cool concept, but looking past that this movie lacks in pretty much every other category. 12 years wasted in my opinion, but it will win awards

Ambitious in its style, this movie captures the angst of growing up by filming the same actors over 12 years. The story itself isn't very memorable, but the way that the story feels like a genuine coming-of-age is. Well worth watching.
Beautiful and amazing in every way way possible. A landmark in cinema with great performances and great directing by mr. Linklater
Interesting to watch people age before your very eyes. Not much of a point to it though. A better plot would have made this much better.
Amazing concept, pretty typical storyline.

Never in my 48 years have I disliked a movie this much that has garnered such critical acclaim...I don't get it!!! boring, boring, boring, horrible acting by everyone except Ethan Hawk and absolutely zero plot.

"... a scintillating, sizzling explosion of cinematic fireworks; a dazzling, dizzying, break-neck roller coaster ride that leaves you breathless and thunderstruck."

That excerpt from a review would apply to a typical Ingmar Bergman offering when stacked up against Boyhood.

Boyhood, of course, is not an action packed film, nor is it an exciting one. It is best described as the work of a great painter. No, not Picasso or Modigliani, but more like Bob from Bob's Painting and Drywall. Bob may do a wonderful job on your walls, but I don't expect you'll want to spend much time sitting in a chair staring at his final product.

Yes, this is a well made film, and some of the acting - particularly that of Ethan Hawke - is fine, but what can you say about a movie that serves up such original lines as "I'm glad you were born" and "Don't forget to floss"?

I should also mention the performance of Ellar Coltrane who plays the main character Mason. Coltrane's lethargic acting immensely adds to the soporific qualities of this film. He really could have benefited from a few cups of espresso before stepping in front of the camera. In fact, I also recommend a good shot of caffeine for anyone intent on watching this.

Writer/director Richard Linklater apparently uses Turtle Pacing Technology, a revolutionary new technique wherein a film that takes twelve years to make somehow also manages to make the audience feel as if they have just spent an equal amount of time in their theater seats.

This new technology should have been nominated for a Scientific and Technical Award Oscar. Incidentally, the Academy's Sci-Tech awards are no longer broadcast on television due to the fact that they are "too exciting" according to Richard Linklater.

So if you are in the mood for cavalierly tossing aside nearly three hours of your adulthood, then by all means have a look at Boyhood.
Well worth seeing. Ground-breaking. Engaging characters.

This is the worst movie in the history of movies!  What is it that makes people give this film a high rating?  Are you kidding?  It stunk!  My fiance just said, "Yeah, that was the longest, most boring movie I have seen in a long time."  I say "ever!"

The uniqueness about its filming technique make it one of the best achievements in the history of the seventh art. But "Boyhood" goes well beyond that: it takes you deeply within the life of your quintessential American boy (and American single mom) in an exquisite manner. Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke probably give us their best performances ever here.

The concept and vision was greater than what was accomplished.  While the director did a good job considering the 12 year production, it missed the mark for me.  The supporting cast just wasn't capable of making the film seamless and I couldn't for a film, bum rather a low budget documentary.

Very creative idea, and I enjoyed watching the actors progress in age through the film.   Other than that, there is really nothing positive I can say about this film.  The characters are annoying, and I was checking my phone to see when it would be over.   The 98% percent positive rating from the critics says everything.   It's a snoozer.
Not much happens but the 165 minutes passes in a flash.
could of left out the liberal political sense out... that's why hollywood loved it

First off I do want to say this movie is fantastic.  What makes this movie fantastic and what cannot be ignored is the process those involved took to make this film.  Filmed over a 14 year period (somewhere in that range) the movie follows a young boy, and basically how he grows and what he encounters in life.  It really hit home for me in some areas.  I could relate and went through some things the boy went through.  The movie could also be called life.  It shows life evolving on the main screen and the relationships that are encountered along the way.

Now I thought more dramatic things could of happened, more themes could have been explored because really it just showed him growing up without a lot of MAJOR conflict.  It was cool however to see the personality change, the relationships change, and how technology changed.
That was what was cool to me.  Seeing how things evolved and how people change in time.  No cell phones in the beginning to texting in the end as the norm.  Very cool
Hawks and Arquette were fantastic in this film.
The dedication to getting this film made the way the director wanted it to be made deserves a standing ovation.
Very enjoyable, amazing concept. I loved it.
It sure reminded me of very good and bad times I had growing up, but what was the point of this movie ? It was way to long and quite boring sometimes. I tried to liked it, but I honestly didn't.
Interesting concept. Average movie. Will undeservedly win Best Picture.

Well, no matter how much work you put into it, if it's not good, it's not good... and doesn't deserve accolades for effort...I've seen some of Linklaters and Malicks films and I'm not a fan... not to say I have to be, but if you're going up for an award some things should be paramount... (Tree of Life is still the worst award nominated film I've ever subjected myself to)...
 
A plot would be nice... a story... a payoff... consistency... competent acting... believable dialogue... character development... motivation are just a few things I'd expect in an award nominated film...  It didn't take me on a journey... It showed me a series of pointless scenes to show a passage of time... Seemed like a lot of it was written (or ad-libbed) as they went (later confirmed to a degree by his daughter)...
 
The liberal agenda (which I mostly agree with) was stuck in there too obviously and made it feel even more like a really bad LIfetime movie...
 
Reading the reviews, it comes across as people pretending to like or understand the film to fit in, be in the know or appear smart... I prefer to take a serious look at this and be truthful...  
 
I was looking forward to the film... I read the hype, was excited about the premise and am fan of new exciting film ideas... but they have to be well executed... (that's the thing)...I'd like to know what about this film was done well?
 
Linklater had 12 years to plan out a script, story, plot... to direct the actors to better performances... he had a $4 million budget (with no stunts, SFX, costumes, sets, etc)... He made the most basic of films types: I dialogue-driven drama with no costly name actors... There is no excuse...
 
If I come across harsh, it's because this film received so much unwarranted or deserving hype and rave reviews... Had this won at a film festival and went to DVD, great.... good for them... For this to be beating out other great films for awards (and for acting and directing too?!?!?!), it deserves some questioning into what the hell are people liking about it?
 
Is Linklater blackmailing everyone? Were all the critics bribed? Is he best friends with Kim Jong Un? 
 
This film fails to exceed in any of the categories set forth by the awards shows... I'm so glad the SAG Awards are coming soon, so I can gauge how it'll do up against some other greats films... I don't think I can stomach the Oscars if Boyhood is a frontrunner... 
 
Does this film have any rewatchablilty for anyone not involved with the production? Were they any "positive" stand-out performances? Powerful moments? Surprises/twists? Engaging story? Characters to care about?
 
One last question I'd like to pose...Taking out the fact that all the main actors were available to work at various points within a 12 year period; that is, no one died or decided to quit (though Linklater's daughter wanted her character killed off because she didn't want to do it anymore, to which he said 'no, it would be too powerful for the film' - so instead, nothing happens)... What exactly about his movie was done well or successful?
The fact that this movie has taken 12 years to make is itself mind blowing. Unlike anything I've ever seen & feels like you have had h a time travel machine for 2 and some hours. Surreal.
Nice idea, too long, no story and a tad boring.
It takes more than a gimmick to make a movie good, much less great.
Watched it.  Sure, it was neat to see a movie filmed over 12 years but what was the plot?  Oh yeah, to film a movie over 12 years.  Super boring.

Literally one of the worst movies I've ever seen. I like the idea but it had no point. It's like a trilogy of bad husbands and hormonal teens with no direction. I would give this movie negative stars if I could. Considered walking out of this movie that would have been a better idea. Skip this one for sure

Very compelling movie, captures a look from childhood to young adulthood and the trials/tribulations that one encompasses along the way through the journey into becoming an adult.  A bit slow at times but parallels life as it moves at a pace that one can relate to. Captures a real-life look of growing up that isn't cookie cutter and doesn't take this approach.  Brilliantly directed, great cast.  Paints a real life picture of how life is messy and that innocence is at core. Linklater takes an authenticated and beautiful literal view  that is combined with the exploration within of ones own imagination.  Regardless of getting older, this is one thing that should remain and never loose sight of as it's a very valuable trait and gift to have.
Not bad, but I really don't see what all the fuss is about.

I am unsure why this movie is getting such rave reviews.  It's far too long, there is no plot, the dialogue is juvenile, the themes are mismatched, and the acting is horrible.  I am so unimpressed with this film that I am warning others against seeing it.

Im not sure what to say about that movie Richard Linklater did a good jobe but im can't say the same thing about the acors .I think they didn't introduced us well in an environment of film and thats why maybe i miss understand the point of the movie . Maybe i din't like the end too because it was flat and simple to me but thats only my opionion.

Maybe I am too Euro-centric, but what I got from this movie: your taste in music may be influenced by a parent, politics is simple, high school graduation is important, divorce is bad, real estate is expensive, alcohol is bad, friend are good, girlfriends are hard, sisters don't do much and facial hair grows longer as you get older.

We may never see a film quite like this again, it may not be everyones cup of tea but the work and love that was poured into this is so evident, it's amazing.

Best movie of 2014.

Boyhood is a marvel in storytelling, that takes over a decade's worth of dedication and vision of Linklater and creates a sentimental depiction of authentic life experience.

What an incredible, truly inspiring movie that had ever been captured. I mean to center the story about the same boy from when he was 8 years old, to when he graduated high school and all the actors and actresses were the same for 12 years. Seriously?! So it was filmed during several years of these characters. Big deal! ! It wasn't clever, it wasn't good. This kid was so boring. His whole life was lame. There was absolutely no point. I finally called it quits after 2 hours. NOT oscar worthy. No great acting from anyone.
Innovative, well acted and written in a way as if it was unscripted. However, if I was an Oscar voter this year, I'd give it to Birdman...

Overrated.  The concept is cool and the time and effort that was put into this movie is commendable...however, I think that alone is why the ratings are so high.  Other than the logistics behind the movie, there really isn't anything great about it.

All my props for the time and effort put into this. 12 years sticking with the same actors and having to come back again and again to work on it is admirable and it certainly helps to be filming it in real time. There were very familiar things happening and moments of nostalgia for sure (mostly brought on by the soundtrack and the technology).

It just was a touch dull. It's a long movie and you feel it. I feel like you're supposed to be in awe about time passing but it feels like you are aging in real time along with the actors at some points. Also is it just me but is every woman a villain of some sort here? I know we're dealing with a kid's perspective and kids are selfish but honestly. There were a few comments that didn't sit well with me.

In sum I'm impressed with the time commitment and the process more than the actual finished product.

i watched this movie and all i can say is that i wish i could have those 2 hours of my life back.  I get the challenge of 12 years to make a movie but its sooooo boring.   every time you think something is going to happen, it doesnt.
