It was a story we all heard before, a broken family, abusive relation ships, and a social outcast. I can't see what all the hype is about. It's probably from the fancy same cast for twelve years thing, but with out that this film doesn't have any thing going for it. Not once in this 
Movie did I feeling any thing for any one except the dead bird in the second scene. 
It was just horrible.

What's most impressive about Boyhood is that it was filmed over the course of 12 years.  While it's interesting to see the characters physically age, the movie as a whole is mediocre.  I liked Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke's performances, but Ellar Coltrane, who plays the lead role of Mason, is no actor and it shows.  If you liked Boyhood, I would strongly encourage you to check out Michael Apted's "7 Up series", a documentary project in which he films a group of U.K. children at the age of 7 and returns every 7 years to see how they've progressed.  The series is based on the premise "Child is the father of man", which turns out to be true for most of Apted's subjects.
An excellent drama of exceptional quality. Despite the length it did not feel long at all and I was captivated throughout despite my difficulties remembering and following stories.

Life is what happens when aren't looking.  Boyhood is all about not looking.  It's about going along for the ride and reminding oneself to live in the moment.

Ethan Hawke delivers the performance of his career.  Patricia Arquette is her traditional brilliant self.  The lead character is not the boy, but life itself.  Life delivered and then some.

Must experience.  No expectations going in though!!
Love love love. As long as it was, I wish it kept going! Would love to see a project sequel one day.
Best movie of the year, with no actual climax I was entertained through the whole movie. Grab some popcorn and enjoy.
Linklater is a true master of dialog. says so much with so little without losing the audience.

Boring! So boring. Nothing happens. For a documentary of real people growing over 12 years I didn't joy it. But it's just actors going over 12 years talking about a fake story and it's a boring story this movie was terrible and should not win any awards. I tried to like it honestly I tried to keep an open mind but this movie stunk it should not win any awards.

It's not very often you can say 'I have never seen a film like that before', and actually *mean* it. But in this case, it's true.
Not so much for the story (basic, 'life' through the eyes of one boy-then-teenager), but in how it was made, and for the dedication it took to do so. 
Keeping the same cast, literally watching them grow and get older... a simple enough idea, but a masterstroke.
A real achievement for director, Richard Linklater, and all involved

This movie should not be called "boyhood" because it has very little to do with being a "boy". Rather most of the film is focused on the mom, sister, and his many fathers. 
So many cliche filled scenes. Unoriginal, Dialogue that doesn't even feel like its coming from the "boy" in this film.

You can give it props for being filmed with the same actors over 12 years, but all in all it was nothing impressive, not entertaining, annoying and cliche filled at most parts, and certainly a misleading title. Waste of time all in all.
Why was this movie written? All the characters are just stupid
It is genious, it is a landmark to cinema, it is astonishing to see to boy grow. But, the execution and the storyline is kind of a downer deception, isnt it?

Immersive, moving and massive. 
Boyhood will give you your first heartache within minutes if you ever have to move out at any point of your childhood, leaving behind all the stuffs that you cared about so much. Further down the line, there will be moments and plenty of them which you might be able to relate, to relish or wish you could do that.
 This sublime journey of 12 years doesn't have a single voice over. It doesn't need any. Such brilliant and exceptionally written the plot is, the direction, the editing is and such effortlessly the actors played those characters so real, so convincing. 
I always wondered whether Linklater would ever be able to match the standards he set in Before Trilogy. Well, he has. He might have surpassed it. I'll just say, it's a privilege to live in the generation he's making masterpieces such as these. Thank you.
Couldn't really get over the poor acting by the kid, but that's the only negative.
Absolutely amazing. Such a risky proposition with both young actors. A must see Oscar nominee.
Interesting to see the characters grow up, but the acting was pretty bad and the plot was nonexistent. This is artsy fartsy crap that everyone is pretending that they like.
Breathtaking.  Huge accomplishment.  Wow.

This film is definitely a good example of depicting humans itself. It is just necessary that the movie will contain violence or any thematic elements into it. At least, it is portrayed in a realistic manner. Boyhood is a kind of movie that touches your heart and a kind of movie that we can relate into.
The premise makes it a very very good movie,  if it was filmed in a normal time frame it would have been just a good movie
I don't understand the hoopla on this snooze fest. Maybe my expectations were too high. Such a disappointment.
I can't believe how highly rated this movie is.  It's a slog, and though it flows like molasses, it does get better near the end.  It's dragged down by wan dialogue and acting.
A film about life and growing up... with both strong and weak performances and no discernible plot... thereby perhaps making it a true reflection/metaphor of life and growing up!
Amazing how you could see they had to manipulate the story over time. Artful.
This movie was cute but seemed to ramble on.  It seems like a Hollywood attempt to discover the "meaning of life" type of film.  It was neat to see the boy grow on film.
I feel like I just wasted almost 3 hours of my life.
A triumph of modern American cinema.
The most boring 2 hrs 45 mins of my life!

I just watched this movie on DVD  and it was soooo boring. Watching it felt like the 12 years it took to film it. The story and characters weren't very interesting and I didn't care what happened to them, especially the main character Mason. I really wouldn't recommend this movie. I think the movie being filled in a 12 year span is the only interesting thing about it, otherwise save your money.
Too much hype. I'm well aware the movie was shot over a long span of time. However that doesn't take away the fact that this film is flat and boring.
I was a bit bored and fell asleep during part of the movie so had to watch it again. I think it's highly overrated.
Incredible after growing up 12 years later with real prop shots!

Not your typical movie. Most movies/stories introduce characters so the audience can connect with them. Then something dramatic will happen that threatens to ruin anything/everything good the movie has built up to attain. All so the main character by whitty intellect, or stupid luck, will somehow manage to fix the unthinkable. Then all is right with the world, & voilà! Movie over. NOT THIS TIME. Boyhood is totally unconventional but brilliant. There is no one bad problem, & no in particular fix it situation. Instead, its simply the story of a family growing & trying to find their places in the world. This movie made wonder which moments in my past would be a scene in a movie about my life. The truth is, no one truley knows what we're doing here. As my mother once said, life is only a series of Hello's & goodbye's. This is one heck of a movie. The actors were obviously committed, & they did an amazing job. Boyhood is a must see.
Beautiful and near perfect movie all around.
Slow movie as it was... When it turned in to pro Obama propaganda, had to tune out...

Interesting film. Feels very 'coming of age' -- which in many ways I guess it is. Patricia Arquette is a wonderful actress, but I'm not sure the Best Actress statue is for her (or Ethan Hawke as supporting actor). The movie is LONG, but so much happens in the lives of the main characters that it feels real. The ending is so abrupt, but I guess it's sort of an epiphany for Mason -- everything is in the NOW (as opposed to go out & seize the moment). Interesting. Could sneak in to win Best Picture, but I don't think it's worthy of that honor. Good? Yes. Best Picture? No.

Normally when I rate a movie badly it means I disliked or hated it.  In this case, I really feel nothing.  It wasn't an actively *bad* movie.   It just was... nothing really.  2 hours and 45 minutes of nothing.   No real point.  No real story.   The acting was fine.   I definitely don't see what the hoopla is here.
Very interesting concept and story telling.  But now that I've seen it,  I will never watch it again.
Boring.   Typical Hollywood insider picture with no meaning.  Will be sad if it wins anything at the oscars.
Quite a potent glimpse into the consequences of fatherlessness, though most will disagree with me.

OVERRATED!  98% critic rating, really?   The movie is 2 hrs 47 min long and 98% of it is pure boredom.  The only thing it has going for it is the kids age with the movie.   So you see them as 6,7,8 year olds and you see the same actors as they mature into young adults.   Pure garbage.  Piece of crap movie. 

I barely want to waste time writing this review because I just wasted 3 hrs watching this.  Bottom line when you devote nearly 3 hrs of your day to a movie, you hope and expect to be entertained.  I found myself mostly bored and wishing it would end, or wishing at least something exciting would happen.  It didn't.
long movie about a boy growing up. no real plot.

OMG, most boring movie I've ever seen and at 3 excruciating hours it was painful. I kept waiting for something, ANYTHING to happen but it never did. The novelty of the concept (12 years, actors aging, I get it) wore off after about the first hour. I can't believe they took twelve years of their life and this is what they filmed.
Giving this a rating of one star was more than undeserved. But this goes to the actors who worked on this horrible film, 1 star for their efforts.
Quite a good film...
Sorry I spent 3 hours of my life watching this movie about nothing
The most boring, overrated film I've ever seen. I cannot fathom how this got an Oscar nomination.
One of the best movies I have ever seen!

Boo! Full of stereotypes. The guy drinks, so he's bad. Conservatives have confederate flags and will shoot you. Boring. Bad acting. Nothing happens. Unrealistic. She's teaching at a university with a master's degree? No. I'm going against the popular grain on this one, but maybe I'm the kid who points out that the Emperor has no clothes. Forced myself to watch the whole movie just because I wanted to do my due diligence. Okay, I need a drink. Ooh, I'm bad!
For me, this was a loser flick.  Boiled down to thinking the meaning of life is living in the moment and then...  there's nothing.  Very depressing, nihilistic.

Groundbeaking in method but too long and lacking a plot, Boyhood follows the messy and rambling lives of a small family in suburban America.  One could argue that life itself is too long and lacking in plot, so this movie is perfect, but if I'm going to plunk down cash for a film, I want it to go somewhere.  Linklater had twelve years (plus!) to work on the script and this is all he came up with?  Meh.  But there were fine performances throughout and the idea of taking so long in order to follow the real life aging of the family is quite innovative.
An interesting look at growing up, but the ending was a little underwhelming. Excellent acting performances by Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke, and Ellar Coltrane.

This is a very boring movie about a kid raised  by a divorced mom who makes some bad choices in men. All of the pretentious critics who call this "a wonderful "film" about a "coming of age" boy...blah, blah, blah. The kid is boring as a boy and a young man and the dialogue in this movie is boring also. Don't waste your time--trust me!

Great Concept - Poor script. BORING!!!
I was looking forward to this so much - and no that is not why I was disappointed.  I felt that the movie had no true qualities of a movie.  It seemed more like someone said hey we have an idea... lets do these scenes to show a boy growing up. VERY DISAPPOINTED - 3 hours I will not get back
Absolutely boring and empty movie. I want 2 1/2 hrs of my life back!
Phenomenal! A story told over the years with the same characters. Charming.
One of the best movies I've seen in some time. Refreshing, innovative idea of capturing time, great acting and directing. bravo!!!
A lesson in perspective.

Sure its an enchanting movie. Feels like you watching some neighbourhood kids growing. Beautifully made, nice performances. Long and slow yet fast n quick. A different one...!! The abrupt end is disappointing. Worth watching though.
Great idea to have the same actors portray their characters over a span of 12 years!  The content and script were lacking. A bit of a let down to watch this movie.

The time put into this movie is clear to see. This may be one of the greatest film achievements of all time, spanning 12 years you really get the amazing feeling of seeing someone grow up, its really like experiencing ones youth all over again.
disappointed but interesting and depressing
One of the least entertaining movies I have ever seen. Boring, no story line, couldn't even watch to the end. Good acting but thats about it. You might like it if you came of age during that time.
just watched it......most slow and boring movie ever!!! lousy movie don't waste your time or popcorn!

Wish a filmmaker daring enough to film a movie over 12 years would have been more daring with the story. Mason, the protagonist, had one of the least interesting story arcs in the movie. On the flip side, I enjoyed the re-occurring side characters.
Made me realize how epic a journey everyday life is.
I found this kind of boring at times, especially at nearly three hours long, but I love how it was shot over 12 years with the same cast.
Great Film! Filmed over 12 years!

A "moving" epic it was not. I'll give it A for effort. Too gimmicky without much substance in the way of story. Yeah, shooting for that long a time is hard, but come on! Film is more than just about creating a gimmick concept. It's about bringing a story with impact. Boyhood's story was pedestrian at best.
Raw and real and emotionally powerful. This film is not entertaining but it is a marvelous piece of art and deserves the best picture oscar for it's amazing 12 year scope.
Great movie honestly.
An amazing accomplishment.
a definite watch... reward yourself with a unique movie experience!
There was not a single second when I didn't love this film. The most surreal, amazing, mold-shattering work of art I've seen in a long type.

I had such high hopes for this film. The critical acclaim got me so excited. But as it progressed and Mason reached the generic, contrived doldrums of teenage angst, I almost couldn't bear the poor writing and acting (aside from Ethan Hawke). "Moments seize us" was as corny as the remnant kernels in my popcorn bowl, emptied after three hours of waiting for something relatively exciting or meaningful to happen. 

This movie simply cannot be compared to Birdman, Whiplash, or any other film it is up against. Yes, filming over 12 years is a feat and I respect the dedication it took. But the result of those 12 years lacked resonance. I really wish I could understand why it is receiving such high praise. I'm a real sucker for emotional, impactful movies that epitomize human connections and life (i.e. Magnolia), and absolutely believed I would be a sobbing mess by the end of Boyhood, awed by its scope and ability to reflect a coming of age story similar to my own. Instead, I was left disappointed in every aspect of the film. The existential crisis Boyhood tried so hard to solve ("What's the point of it all?" Mason asked his father) only manifested itself in me ("What's the point of this movie?" I asked myself) after it cut to black.
Wow. Believe the hype!

Truly surprised by the massive deterioration of writing and acting quality as it pushed on. For about the first hour, I was extremely game and wrapped into the journey. From then on, the potato quality dialogue torched the movie's good will. The only shining light was Ethan Hawke, but he was sparsely used. Really think this was largely hype, can't believe a quality critic would think the writing worked on any level in the last 2/3rds. Some scenes were embarrassing to even watch (namely the teens drinking beers in a run-down house and talking about whores). Nuts. Did I enjoy the experience as a whole? I'd say so. But much of it was nothing better than TV movie-quality. This was largely concept driven and faulty in execution, but the masses can overlook such things. Amazing accomplishment, either way.

This movie is absolutely insufferable. I don't care if you started shooting it 12 years ago, I took a crap 12 years ago,  does it get nominated for an oscar? Yes I remember Dragon Ball Z, Aaliyah and High School Musical, simply referencing these things does not a good movie make.
Longest movie ever!!! The concept was cool, but the acting was absolutely terrible!!!! The story was stereotypical and completely uninteresting!
This is torture. The acting is horrible and the plot was predictable and derivative.
This movie is great! Very realistic - I could relate to every year in Mason & his family's lives!
Good to watch at home. May make you antsy in the theater as it moves at a slower pace than we area accustomed to. Good movie and very interesting.

The story of a boy growing up.  Simple enough.  But what if you made a movie about a boy growing up...as he grew up...over 12 years with all of the same actors.  That'd be cool...and this movie is cool.

This is a sneaky movie.  At first it seems a little slow, but it grows on you and pulls you in...I mean, you're seeing these people grow up and change...the son, daughter, mother father.  You see what you've seen, in your children if you have them, or your self from years past..  Those innocent years, awkward years and years of discovery.  Maybe you see yourself as an adult...going from that young cool person who is taking on the world, the parent that schleps their child around in a mini van.  It reveals how life isn't easy...it's hard and confusing and rocky and sometimes it sucks...but it keeps moving forward.  

I found myself misty eyed in this movie a few times, and I'm not sure I can articulate why....but I found it moving.  Maybe you will too.

I don't know if Linklater is a genius or if he was just lucky in casting  Mason, the boy in the movie, but he was perfect in this part.  As boy, as an adolescent and finally as a young man...he just seemed right.  Ethan Hawke is great as is Patricia Arquette.

Now I'm a huge fan of Richard Linklater, the writer director.  His movies Before Sunrise, Before Sunset and Before Midnight (filmed 10 years apart with the same actors...which if you haven't seen, should), Slacker and of course Dazed and Confused are some of my favorite movies of all time.  He has a way with making the normal, extraordinary...in a nonchalant way.  Boyhood may be his best film.  See this.
I need a plot, I'm afraid. It's like watching paint dry and go from a pretty color (when the kid's young) to an awful shade of puce (when he grows into this charmless gawky guy.)
One of the few times I actually related to a movie character.

Incredibly ambitious to watch these characters grow and age on screen.  Unfortunately, the rest of the puzzle pieces don't fall into place.  The acting is sub-par, the dramatic tension has no building climax, and the emotional investment never pulls you in.  Richard Linklater might have been innovative, but the final result is just lacking too much.
Good acting. Interesting concept. But slow. And kind of hard to believe the could make so many poor choices.
Gives the word boring new meaning - 12 years in the making  = 12 years wasted.

Worst movie ever I don't care he took 12 years. Give him an award for endurance or project management but as a movie that had something it had nothing. Keep reality tv on TV so I can skip the channel. Should not have even received a nomination. Save you to time more valuable then this dribble
ENJOYED watching this  Movie!!!

The concept alone might win this movie Best Picture.  It is unprecedented in modern film-making and divorcing yourself of it to just look upon the content of the movie is very tough.   I believe the movie itself is very well-done and plausible (except for Patricia Arquette's character becoming a college professor in the blink of an eye) and raises some great questions on time progression.

Great film. From the first minute you feel like watching something different, maybe not revolutionary but quite original and absolutely fascinating. Richard Linklater has a powerful but surprisingly simple way of directing, wich makes the film feel so realistic. The cast is awesome, specially Ethan Hawke who plays his role brilliantly. 
Must-see film. A masterpiece. IMHO, the best film of the year.

Good stuff. Two and three-quarter hours of movie passed without longueurs. This is well-observed Life as Art, made to look easy. Expect no major crimes nor disasters: this is life as she is lived. This film deserves the critical acclaim that it's received.

Quite an impressive achievement and a very well documented look at someone's adolescence!

My only quibble was that it moved verrrryyyy sllllooooowwwly, but on the plus side, it moved at about the same speed as life itself....okay maybe a little faster.

The movie is filmed over 12 years with the same cast. You literraly see the child Mason grow in front of your eyes as the movie progresses. There is no entertainment factor to this film. It is 165 mins of movie spanning the 12 years of Mason's life. The movie ends abruptly too. I felt it to be a very slow drama.

Its an epic feat. that this movie even excists. But besides its techinal succes it also delivers on performances and storytelling. Its not the epic masterpiece that it has been hyped to be, but for a few generations it might just be a Classic.
Not sure. Overrated a bit?

Even after it's 3 hour running time, I found myself wanting to watch these people for another 3 hours, or even so, for their entire lives. Richard Linklater has made a lot of good movies,  but this movie (which took 12 years to make with the same cast) hits every note perfectly about growing up.  The genius behind the film is that it flies by, just like time and life itself
This was such a great movie.  A great movie showing relationships and how they grow and change.
Enjoyable, I understand how groundbreaking the concept is about a 12 year filmed movie, but I think I just had too unrealistic expectations.
That's 3 hours I'll never get back.
the concept and the acting were good. The story was pretty boring. It isn't enough just to have a cool concept. The movie still needs to be interesting.

If you don't know the concept of Boyhood, then either you don't really care about cinema that much, or you've been living under a rock. So much has been said about the idea that Richard Linklater spent 13 years filming the same actors as they slowly developed the life history of a young boy growing into a man. So this is where I'm supposed to gush about the brilliance and daring of this entire concept, and I will admit it was interesting to see the physical transformation of the people as the film progresses. However there's another way you can see the same effect and that is by watching someone's home movies. But guess what, no one enjoys watching other people's home movies for that long, and frankly home movies tend to capture the highlights of life while Boyhood continues to capture the lowlights or even the mundane moments of life. I think the problem I had is just that this was indeed adventurous film-making, but Linklater didn't utilize it to do something interesting with the story. It's just the story of a kid's crappy childhood, and I've already experienced childhood once, I don't need to trudge through his. I swear this is just a gimmick to get all the critics worked up in a frenzy of praise for one of their beloved directors, so they can shower him with awards.

One of the things you must consider, when you start making a film like Boyhood, is that you're basically going all-in on a big bet. You are banking that these kids are going to grow up to be decent actors. Sadly they bet on the wrong horse. Ellar Coltrane's line delivery is wooden and awkward as a kid, and then it is mumbled and incoherent as a teenager. Nepotism didn't pay off either because Lorelei Linklater is even worse and only has one facial expression in her repertoire. Of course I can't throw all the blame on these kids, because even Ethan Hawke has moments that feel artificial. I think this is a symptom of a bad script, because some of the conversations are so odd I find myself totally taken out of the film and realizing they are acting because real people don't talk that way.

One other annoyance in Boyhood was the way it kept dropping little markers to denote the time as if to say "This scene is really happening in 2005, see Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince being released?!" "This scene is in 2013, because everyone listened to that Gotye song at that time." It just felt so forced. Now I must admit that, when I hear lots of gushing praise heaped on a film I don't particularly care for, I tend to over-compensate by absolutely ripping it apart in my own review. However, if I'm perfectly honest, there were moments that I was entertained by Boyhood. It was lovingly shot, and has a nice timeless visual quality. Also there were moments where I looked back in my head and thought "it's crazy this is that same little boy I was watching 2 hours ago." That doesn't really mean I liked the overall experience, though. It still was exceedingly bland and overly long. It's going to be hard to watch this one win the Oscar, but I'll totally understand why it happened.
A decent portray of the boyhood in a natural family drama. A real life story telling. an excellent piece of work from director Richard Linklater.
Simply a great movie. Like nothing else.

'Boyhood' has the typical Linklater stamp all over the place. The transition of 'boy-to-adolescent' has been portrayed in the most realistic way. Ethan Hawke is excellent in the dad's role. In the last half-hour of the movie, strong shades of Linklater's 'Before..' trilogy are felt. At 2 hours & 45 mintues, it's safe to say the movie never lags one bit, but brings in ample dose of nostalgia along the way.

Absolutely amazing. This is an original masterpiece that was patiently and carefully put together. Great performances by everyone involved and clearly a lot of commitment as well. This film is simply a masterpiece.
it was good, but not that good ok
One of the most thought-provoking movies I've ever seen.
Amazing! Best film I've seen in a really long time.

A great movie that will blow your mind with how surreal it is. Richard Linklater is one of my favorite directors, as he has directed some of the best films I've ever seen. This is certainly one of them. I cannot even begin to explain the entire film itself, so you'll have to see it yourself. It is truly a life changing experience.
Not worth the 3 hours!
Leaves a really good sensation of life

So I just saw Boyhood and it was kind of stupid.  I wouldn't really recommend it.  Like I get why this movie has so much hype around it.  Conceptually the movie was daring and interesting; not many filmmakers would attempt to film a movie for over the coarse of a decade.  They were definitely things you can appreciate about that decision you couldn't in other films.  However the mere concept of Boyhood does nothing to show it's quality.  What's more important how well they executed that idea.  Unfortunately for Boyhood it's ambitions was not enough to excuse it's shortcomings.  
  First I want to give credit where credit is due.  I was for the most part on board with the movie when Mason was still a little kid.  Despite the story lacking flow that was kind of the point.  Things kind of just happen when you're younger and we see that through Mason's perspective.  They even go so far as to not reveal Mason's Mom or Dad's name.  It was also pretty clever to show relevant events or even product placements to show what year it was without ever explicitly mentioning it.  I also loved the scene towards the end with Mason and his mom.  Even though that scene is pretty cliché considering the stylistic choice to film the movie it felt well earned.  I wouldn't be surprised if Patricia Arquette was feeling the same emotions her character was which made her performance that more convincing.
  Speaking of other performances, Ethan Hawke was also pretty good.  The daughter Samantha was pretty awful.  There's no sugar coating it, am I supposed to be nice since she's Richard Linklater's kid?  Is anyone going to defend her when the entire point of the fucking movie is to feel as natural as possible?  Ok sure, I guess I can give her some slack because of the choice to film this over 12 years.  Then how am I supposed to excuse characters who have literally show up for but a brief moment and can't act for shit.  That basketball man's delivery was so hollow it was laughable bad.  Let's not forgot that Mexican worker with the worst accent ever!  Apparently the movie that's supposed to be this natural experience still has cliché bullies from the 80's.  
  Sorry Drunk professor dad, you were not convincing as an intimidating drunk.  His body language and tone of voice never felt natural for his supposed intoxicated state.  Does anyone else not see how ridiculous it was to have him shout "I hate squash!" right after his meltdown at the table?  Apparently all it takes for a newly wed dad to have drama with Mason is to be drunk.  Now don't get me wrong, alcoholism is a seriously issue that you can tackle in film but when it's a consistent characteristic in what only happens to leads to a divorce with both of them then it's clear that it serves as a pathetic excuse as a plot device.  Yup, just add beer.  Instant drama.
  The music is some of the most overbearing I've heard in some time.  Does anyone not see how stupid cheesy it is to have that guitar rift happening while Mason he's tagging graffiti?  Like wow this kid is so hardcore.  Also I get why you wanted to play popular song from different parts of the time but did it have to be over the soundtrack and not within the universe?  I don't see how Crank that Soulja boy being played over them riding their bikes has any purpose.  It's not the only time a song is played outside of the universe so why the inconsistent use of in-universe songs and soundtrack for the film?  
  The biggest issue though I had with the film would have to be Mason when he turns into a teenager.  He turns into an unlikable douche hipster sprouting preachy pretentious lines.  Stop whining about not getting your Dad's car you little brat.  I'm fine with having a movie more centered on the characters than the story.  I'm fine with movies that are slow paced.  But when you're main character is not only uninteresting and unlikable with about an hour and a half of screen time left with the last 30 minutes being filler then I don't know how I'm not supposed to be bored.  Seriously the movie could have ended when he graduated.  The point has been made that he's going into adulthood but it's cool you wanted to beat it into me for a superfluous ending.
  You know there's another movie in 2014 that aimed for an unfeasible scale in film making.  It's called Birdman and the difference is they actually pulled off their goal.  Everything in Birdman had purpose and was masterfully delivered.  Again I want to stress that what's important is the execution not the concept.  I understand that not everyone might be bothered by the same things I so excuse me for judging a movie for the high standards it wants to be judged on.  So if you enjoy Boyhood good for you.  You're not wrong for liking it.  But my reasons for disliking the movie aren't wrong either.  Is it a bad movie?  No.  Is it as exceptional as everyone is making it out to be?  No.  6/10

Interesting way to film a movie but still boring.  This is why none of our normal life's are filmed over 12 years. I'm curious if the liberal bias helped it get it's nomination. Boyhood makes the top ten boring movies of the year.

Well I'm definitely an outlier on this one. Although I've really enjoyed LInklater's other films I found this one grueling and a little dull. The first two hours is like watching paint dry. The final hour is like dying from the fumes - gawdalmighty just let it end already!

Just because something took 12 years to make does not make it good.  I challenge you to find a good plot line, anything that makes you laugh, or a reason to stay awake. A completely overrated waste of 12 years.
Somebody owes me 165 minutes. This was the worst movie I have ever seen. Ever. If it wins best picture, I will never watch the Oscars again. Never
Terrible ..... I can't see how the ratings are so high!!?
Even though the film is a little over hyped by critics. It's still a really cool experience watching a kid go from young to old in a matter of 3 hours.
Awesome! Beautifully shot and great storyline

This is a melodrama so why is it so good. Is it all down to the fact that it was filmed over 12 years and we get to see the characters grow and change within the movie but also physically over time? That's a big part of it but just think for a second about the directors vision and commitment to this project and also his ability to create a coherent story over this time. Wow. This movie is about time. Time experienced by a boy of 6 until he is 18 with all the life that comes in between. Maybe its because I'm now 41 and I watched this movie at just the right time but I got quite the emotional hit from the final scene. I can't quite put my finger on why? It was something to do with the boy wondering about his place in the world and the universe and remembering how that felt at 18. This is art.
An amazing narrative story that pulls you in to the family's life...and what direction they will all take over the 12 years....cast were all amazing!

Directed by Richard Linklater and stars  Ellar Coltrane as the son (Mason), Patricia Arquette the mother, Ethan Hawke the father and a couple of  some unknown actors. The film is about a little boy, growing up experiencing adolescence and everything comes along with it. Yes we see that a lot of times before but this movie has something unique that no other family movie manage to make me feel like this. What makes this film incredibly special is the filmmaking technique. The filming began in the summer of 2002 with the young main character and filmed yearly all the way until last year with the same actors. So boyhood took 12 years to be done and we actually get to see through the eyes of  Mason who literally grows up on screen before our eyes. Snapshots of adolescence from road trips, family dinners to birthdays and graduations and all that moments make me think my own childhood journey and i believe it's impossible to watch Mason and his family without thinking about your family about your journey. I mean the massage of the film really hits you. While i was watching this film i was thinking abou the performances of the actors. They were outstanding. These performances do not feel like performances, they feel very much just in the moment, the dialogue doesn't feel like a movie dialogue, it just feel like people are talking. The real drama of this film comes from just how real it feels and the message behind it is just a series of milestones and once you hit them you are just on the next one. I'm sure that a lot of people are going to come out and say this movie isn't really that special and if it wasn't made over the course in 12 years well then it would be just some boring movie when nothing happens. I can understand that because nothing actually happened, it's a lot of really really interesting conversations between the actors and very very cool filmmaking techniques. Okay it's not that type of movie you are going to see again because is a very long movie, about 2 hours and 45 minutes and it's not the kind of movie that you poppin at a party and say hey guys we 're gonna watch this movie because is just not that type of film. Overall boyhood is a very very different and unique movie and i can't even imagine the idea of physically filming a movie for 12 years, that's crazy, definitely should be seen. So i'm gonna give boyhood 4 stars and if you guys saw this movie what did you think about it?
Absolutely tremendous. Best film of the year hands down.
Cool idea.  Boring and painfully slow movie with no point.

I went in to this movie expecting it to be my favorite of the year and to be totally moved and all that.  I wasn't.  I was so let down that at first I hated it.  Then I thought about it for days and realized that the scope of the movie, the fact this has never been done before, the fact that I am watching kids grow in a movie, that redeemed the movie somewhat.  All that said, I can't say this is better than just average and that's a bummer.

A classic movie like "Tree of Life". I could tell that right now. What a sincere portrayal of derailed American family life where people are struggling to find their true identities. Don't miss it. Only for serious minds. Hope this movie will won an Oscar.
It was pretty interesting to see how from year-to-year the kids have changed I thought it was a well-done movie seeing all things the kids had to go through and the things that the mother ignored

I don't usually review movies but I feel it necessary to warn people about this one since most people seem to be raging over it. This is an absolutely boring movie. It would be just like if you videotaped your son over a 12 year period and then rewatched it only this is less interesting because it is not your son.

Boyhood is an amazing, heart-touching epic which centers on Ellar Coltrane, and his boyhood. Its length may be a bit too long looking at the story, but the movie still succeeds. Richard Linklater's beautiful 12 year masterpiece, will surely affect you.

This movie was pretty great.  I thought the ending was pretty great as well even though some did not.  Tells a pretty great story. I thought the mom (Patricia Arquette) was pretty terrible though other than that it was pretty great
The concept of filming over a number of years was interesting, but you'd think they'd come up with an equally interesting story line to go with it.   No such luck.  Very dull.

I saw BOYHOOD! Along with being the single most conceptually complex movie ever made, it's possibly the most interesting and uninteresting movie that I've ever reviewed. I'll unpack that box in a minute but first let me give you the rundown of what it's about. The movie follows a young boy named Mason, played by Ellar Coltrane, as he literally grows from a boy to a man and chronicles all the loves, losses, joys and disappointments of growing up in Texas along with his mother, father and sister played by Patricia Arquette, Ethan Hawke and the director's own daughter, Lorelei Linklater.

The film is the brainchild of director Richard Linklater and literally took 12 years to make as it weaves through the early 2000s until present day. From a conceptual standpoint alone I should be giving this movie 10 stars. The style is consistent across the years, well shot and the actors grow up and grow old before your very eyes... that is except for Ethan Hawke who is apparently some sort of immortal daywalker vampire. Needless to say, this is a true achievement in film from a technical standpoint. From a story standpoint, it's a little different. The story in the film has this feeling like it was written on the fly, without any real direction as to where it was going or what it was building towards any kind of earth shattering event but here's the thing, there comes a point where the movie knows you're realizing that fact and it even addresses it but asks you to hold on just a little longer. By the end of the show, the message the film has plays a lot like real life, not every story is glamorous and dramatic, real life is what it is and a lot of times it's not super eventful but when you look back over everything, you truly saw a boy grow into a man and experience the kind of joy, disappointment, loss, and love that we all do and it was done in a real life kind of way.

Overall, I really liked this movie and despite the fact that a lot of the acting by the kids was less than stellar, and the plot seemed to meander a bit over it's nearly 3 hour run time, the end product was such an achievement that I really can't knock off any points for any mistakes in pacing because at the end of the day, I got where I needed to be and honestly It just couldn't have been done better! Plus, the movie was shot in Houston, Austin and San Marcos, three cities I call home. Taking all into consideration, I simply CAN'T give this movie any less than a perfect 5...out of 5.

Filmed over 12 years with the same cast is the only interesting thing about this long boring movie with abandoned story arcs and terrible acting. I mean truly awful. The breakup scene at the end was so uncommitted I wasn't even sure it was a break up scene until the literal words started coming out. Even then I wasn't convinced. Truly awful.  I'm obviously in the minority on this one. I think people are giving it a free pass because of the 12 year concept which is interesting and, for the cast, daunting.  But I'll take substance over a gimmick any day. The ending was abrupt but welcomed. The story lines never settled in and the most interesting aspects were the nuggets of things from the past. Changing cell phones, music references, etc. Again, the gimmick.
I believe that this movie is getting nominated because of it's uniqueness in filming over 12 years, not so much for the storyline. It is good but not amazing enough for all the accolades.

I didn't see the film but I am giving it 1 star based on the boring ass plot, and terrible trailer. I lived through high school and my childhood, I do not need to watch 3 hours of someone else's, I mean really??!?!?!?
It's great until he grows up

Unique movie filmed over 12 years with the same cast follows a young boy grow up and head off to school.  More interesting then the boy's life was the story of the mom and dad.  Mom Patricia Arquette making poor decisions in the men she marries and Dad Ethan Hawke eventually becoming the man Arquette wanted him to be.  Liked the fact this film seemed like it could have been anyone's life.  Favourite scene has to be the teacher's lecture to Mason in the school dark room.
Groundbreaking, unique, and possessing a wonderful story unachieved by any film before, Boyhood stands a true testament to it's title and sets new benchmarks for filmmaking.
absolutely fascinating on all levels
A fairly mundane story presented in a unique way.
Ellar Coltrane was awful in his older years.  The only reason this movie is beloved by so many is because it was made over 12 years.  No one in their right mind would watch this movie again.

I give it two stars  for the original fact that it was filmed during 12 years like any other movie has been and for that it represented... well... the boyhood of the main character in 2.45 hs. Still, I didn't feel it gave me any possitive message or good feelings at all. Characters that appeared in a part of the movie never reappeared , problems that the main charactesr faced remained unfinished and so on. It was not a story as a whole with learning and a moving ending, it actually finished abruptly. I was entretained in some parts and bored in others. I wouldn't recommend it to my friends or family but I still have to recognize that the fact of the 12-years-filming is unique.

"Boyhood" 10 Scale Rating: 5.0 (Mediocre) ...

The Good: I have to admire the ambition. It takes a lot of guts and vision create a film piece by piece over a 12 year span and I have to give Linklater credit there. Overall, the film is well acted and the characters are at least somewhat interesting. Ethan Hawke turns in the best performance of the film and newcomer Ellar Coltrane improves drastically as the film progresses. At times, "Boyhood" starts to head down a very entertaining path and you can briefly (albeit very briefly) see why it was nominated for Best Picture.

The Bad: But then, once it heads down that path, it does an about face. Time suddenly passes in the film and the previous storyline is an afterthought. At 2:45 the film is also extremely long and it feels it. There are far too many gaps where nothing happens and you feel like you're just watching the life of a regular every day family. Maybe that is the point, but it doesn't make for a very compelling film. Slow moving and with a highly unsatisfactory ending, "Boyhood" might be among the most overrated films of all time.

?#?Boyhood? made over 12 years is one of the most boring and unbelievably overrated movies. It has 8.3 rating on IMDB... Classic case of herd thinking n hype. After the first hour the characters just go through the motions and act like they are all on dope and you begin to wonder where the heck the movie is headed. Looks like the child actors lost interest and acting abilities somewhere between 2008 and 2014. What the director was trying to achieve by making this movie over so many years is unclear. Guess he lost the plot too. One should instead watch "This Boy's Life" starring Di Caprio and De Niro. Or better watch a few episodes of "The Wonder Years". Boyhood is yaaaaawwwn!
Ok movie, just a life of an avg American boy. No twists and turns, no excitement.

Truly a spectacle achievement!  Seeing the young star from kid to adult makes you feel like you're growing up with him, including the whole family.  Though nothing much happens, it does takes us on a journey from boyhood to manhood.  It's hard to describe how amazing this movie is.  There's something so special about it.  Seeing life go pass your eyes...  It's, ugh!  No filmmaker has done anything quite like this.  Hell, even the script and cinematography manage to stay fresh.  Everyone did a great job on it, especially the cast and crew.  The commitment they made for the film deserves a recognition.  Bravo!

Ellar Coltrane and Lorelei Linklater literally grow up 12 years in front of our very eyes within the 165 minute running time, visionary filmmakers still exist. Although the story line is fairly simplistic and one might argue, unadventurous, the sheer ambition of the director is reason enough to hand your money over; shot over twelve years with the same group of actors, audiences can experience the true evolution of a character like never before.
The idea of the film is great, they are exploring a side of cinema never before explored, however I feel that taking on this task should have demanded more creativity.
This coming-of-age film revels in the genius that is Richard Linklater. His innovative vision is simple enough in its concept, but compelling enough to garner full audience attention. Genius.
Solid Movie. Overrated big time.  Ambitious project

What a great and ground breaking concept, and so refreshing to see a cast naturally age, with no change in actors or special make up. It takes you a few age jumps to get used to the fact that they are not going to warn you with a "2 years later" sign or anything like that - they just let it flow, and hope you keep up, but you soon fit into that. Now.... for the film as a whole, and I feel that this will seem pretty controversial considering the awards it is winning and the reviews it got. If you take away the wow factor of how it was filmed, then the film felt a little lack lustre, it plodded on with what seemed to be very few huge events taking place. OK, there were big milestones for this family, like there is in real life (college etc), but I was expecting something unexpected, and I didn't get it... The acting seemed very natural, which I guess working together over such an extended period of time means they gelled in a very unique way. But I think for me, it relied to heavily on the concept, and not enough on the material to keep the audience gripped. It certainly deserves recognition for the dedication and approach to filming, but I was left a little disappointed by the whole thing, which I am a little gutted about to be honest.

It's hard to explain, but after watching the film several times, I realized that being a kid compared to being an adult is the most the interesting thing about this movie.  The closer the kids get to adulthood, the more they realize that life doesn't have much to offer anymore.  Even the mother's mid life crisis later on kind of validated that point and in the end, we all still have many questions unanswered about why we are living.  This movie mostly reminded me of my half brother that didn't have a father like myself, he grew up lost with no particular goal but trying to figure what life is about, in the end only realizing that exploration may be the only truth.  But unlike him, my generation had our version of woodstock 69, but he didn't. It's a good film for everyone I must say, but it was very sad to me because it made me understand how many young people are lost these days when they reach 18.... :(

Basically a three hour movie to remind us of how overwhelming, confusing, and unpredictable life can be. And as if my own 23 years hasn't conveyed that enough, Linklater put it upon himself to spend nearly 12 years to tell us that. 12 YEARS TO MAKE THIS MOVIE. And no one in over a decade of this films development told Linklater what "story" or "plot" is.  Although it truly is impressive to watch these characters grow up on screen, this movie looses its charm after the 45 minute mark.
This movie was so slow!!!! And boring idk what's up with the hype!

I wanted to like this movie. I even harbored high hopes that I would. About 15 minutes into the 166 minute running time I knew that I, in fact, did not. Similarly, I want to like Patricia Arquette. She seems like a genuinely sweet person amidst that cliche sea of sociopathy that is Hollywood actors. For the sake of journalistic integrity (or perhaps in my case just plain old brutal honesty), I can only liken Arquette's performance (with her wooden demeanor and nasal delivery) to a marionette with a cold. Still, I like her. She remains likable. Oscar worthy is the descriptive statement at which I draw the line. In stark contrast is Ethan Hawke. Not personally burdened with the obligation to like him, I can say with integrity in tact that this is Hawke's best performance (at least that I have personally witnessed). That and the well-deserved proverbial applause for a 12 year filming process is about all I can positively say about Boyhood. In a time where originality and ingenuity are scarce in the mainstream arena of film, one cannot simply dismiss Richard Linklater's unique artistic process. Unfortunately this process was, for me, overshadowed by a stilted script (and/or lazy editing), sloppy directing and subpar acting, save for Hawke. What could have been immensely compelling simply fell flat. The subject matter was there: a normal, lower middle class boy traverses his formative years amidst an absent father, a mother struggling in all aspects of motherhood, step-families, abuse, etc. etc. But to watch it unfold was akin to watching a highly trained dancer miss one critical step and proceed to stumble through what would have been a beautiful and unique dance routine. Still, this review is not an attempt to dissuade the reader from watching Boyhood (as much as it may seem like that's precisely what it is). There was a point in the film, however short-lived, that I found myself commiserating with the "Boy". In that brief moment I connected with what (I assume) Linklater was attempting to do with this film. I related to it. And I felt something. I can only hope (for Linklater's sake, for the viewer's sake and for the sake of the integrity of the Academy) that more people will walk away feeling a connection with the characters/story than will be distracted by the convoluted dialogue and choppy storytelling. Unfortunately that just wasn't the case for me.
Boring, pointless, mostly poorly acted...nearly 3hrs of Linklater's navel gazing crap....
A little long, but a good watch.
Surprisingly watchable despite its nearly 3-hour length.  My only quibble is the guy had way too cool a high school experience to be believable.
very brilliant concept...movie started out great but i lost interest toward the end.
Unique concept however the story was weak. Should not be an Oscar contender.

Amazingly ambitious film! Does not flow like a run of the mill film but more like life, as it should. Filmed over 12 years yet it still seems to come together and create a true coming of age tale for young boys.
A very interesting study of the steps or stages in life. very well done but, I just don't see the same great things the critics see.
Reminding us of all the stupid decisions we've made throughout our pathetic lives...
An incredible concept with an execution that disappointed me on so many levels.
Great concept, well executed. But the lack of a driving narrative left me feeling underwhelmed.
if u want to take a nap. put this in
The film is awesome. I`m lovin it.
Ok but wouldn't watch it again

The movie itself I only thought was worth 3 stars. Good, but not great. The story behind the making of the movie would add another star, but I didn't rate the movie on how it was made. I only rated the movie itself.

Very well done film that must have represented a tremendous effort to get all the players back for each filming session.   I liked the fact that the Ethan Hawk Dad figure looked like a stereotypic divorced Dad and ended up being the most supportive parent over the long run.

Certainly an interesting idea, but after watching a film for close to three hours I expected to know more about the characters I was watching. It is cool to watch the actors grow up and age -- but there is surprisingly little in the way of character development or understanding. Patricia Arquette stands out with a performance that cuts further deeper than the script. This film is very over-rated by critics.

Nothing really happened in this movie, and after a while it felt like, 'If nothing has happened so far, then when something happens, it's going to be BIG.'  They lingered a lot on driving scenes and we all agreed that we expected someone to get t-boned at any minute because of these lingering nothing-happening car scenes.  It was an interesting gimmick for a movie and the characters were interesting to meet, but there wasn't much substance to it.

It was weird and interesting seeing the actors slowly age as the film progressed and seeing the portrayals of the recent past (and what music, events, etc. they chose to emphasize).  I was convinced there was going to be a car wreck due to all lingering car driving scenes.
An enthralling tale that feeds off of our own nostalgia.
Much better than I expected.
Very well done and a great concept to shoot the film over 12 years.
One of the most boring films of the year. The novelty of how it was filmed was interesting, but the movie itself is a long bore fest.

Maybe I simply don't get it?  I think this is a cool idea for a movie.  Same actors over 12 years, following a family and in particular a young kid as he grows up, it's a cool idea.  I'm not sure I get fully why this is an interesting movie.  It's an interesting gimmick/experiment/idea, but maybe since I thought the boy in Boyhood was a bit of a whiner, I was somewhat bored.  I mean I kind of liked this thing, and it kind of ticked me off.  Is there a statement here that the movie is trying to make?  Or is it simply about a divorced family just trying to make do in America today?  Plus it's long, and it feels long.  There are some almost three hour movies that I wished were four hours long and there are some that needed to be cut more.  This movie has been  nominated for best picture, and is a favorite.  I wouldn't pick it for Best Picture, not sure I'd nominate it either.
One of the best movies I've ever seen.
Powerful performances from all its actors, Boyhood changes the common way of filming and goes beyond the realness and truth of growing up.

The only real reason is nominated for an Oscar is because it took 12 years to make it I'm sorry I really didn't think this was that good of a film it was lacking big climactic moment that everyone that goes to the movies hopes to see the whole movie and thought it was dull if you were to go see one movie this whole Oscar season don't waste it on boyhood

I thought this film was very entertaining, but not as groundbreaking or moving as I had been hearing. Maybe I had heard too much hype before seeing it. The lead characters were acted superbly, but the supporting actors not always so great. Overall, it reminded me of a very good, 3-hour stand alone episode of Parenthood.

Boyhood is a film that works better as a concept than a completely formed story. While the movie deserves all the praise it has been receiving for the performances, the story features nothing that has not been done a thousand times before, just on a more grand scale. This is not to say that it is a bad film, it is quite good actually, it just doesn't do anything remarkable besides its 12 year shooting schedule. It seemed more interested in throwing out cultural references, than with developing a thorough study of the lives of the characters. The film seemed to have a very cynical view of relationships, which for me, was quite off-putting. If it weren't for the three hour run time, I would recommend it to everyone, but as it stands, I think that the other best picture candidates such as Birdman and Whiplash stand as much better films. 3.5 stars out of 5.

long, slow at times, totally unlike anything I have ever seen.  I could relate to almost every character.  A mountain of  truth packed into one film.  it made me reflect on how profound our simple lives really are.  made me wonder what Chad will make of his life.
Like the twist hated the ending and the acting was just so so for me.

A very telling narrative of the question "what is life?" Through the scope of a human growing up rather than some religious explanation that holds no weight. It gave me the feeling that is okay to not know the answer to that question. To live life by giving importance to what you think matters.
Interesting but boring and very, very long.

Excellent acting by adults and children over a decade (more) allows for a many layered film of a boy growing up. As do everyone around him. You know you have a good movie when there are many ways, viewpoints, levels from which to talk about this movie when you are done. We can all identify with everyone in this film at some point during this Boyhood. Be sure to see it!

The only cool thing about this movie is that they showed all the characters age, but other than that, the movie went absolutely no where. It just dragged on and on and on. Ugh waste of almost 3 hours. I would have liked it a lot more if at least it had a climax or an interesting ending.
Lovely and charming. Kudos to Linklater and producers for taking the risk on a movie shot over 12 years.

This is a real nice film.I just really fine it incredible watching this 12 year journey of seeing this family ups and downs. I love Ethan Hawk and Patrrica Arquette even though both them look like they didn't aged I really enjoy what they did with there roles. My only issue with Boyhood is it's just too long. I would love the film more if were two hours but I understand were Richard Linklater was coming form, this took 12 years of your life you want to make sure you but everything in to this. but still if you can take the time length then I think you would appreciate this interesting film experiment.
Interesting, but not earth shattering...ethan hawke for best performance, but otherwise...underwhelming.

Truly like no other movie I've watched - filmed over 12 years, the film tells a very simple but touching story of a young boy growing into a young man. Love that the cast remained so committed to such a unique project. Definitely has a shot for best picture.
Massively overrated!
Like the real life linklater is expertly emulating here it's boring, pointless, and tedious. Plot or real adversity would've been nice.

Great flick..   It was good to see a movie which takes place over 12 years with all the same actors..  That's some talent there.     Was totally into it for 3 hours but the ending just ended..  No nothing.  No closure which makes me sad  so I now take a star of the ratting.

Enjoyable but longer than it needed to be and lacked the intimacy and depth I was expecting.  Hawke and Arquette performed well as the parents, but they weren't given enough moments in the script and the kids were only okay, just fine for first time actors really, but was disappointed in the end.  It wasn't a bad film, but it wasn't great either and not one of writer/director Linklater's best (whom I'm a big fan of).
only if I could give six stars

I made a pre-order for this movie on Amazon having seen such an excellent review score of 98% on RT. I endured 3 hours of complete boredom and have to conclude that other members believe its already April 1st and want to have a joke on the rest of the community. I have one positive word to say, the young Mason was quite entertaining for the first 10 minutes, Richard Linklater should have stopped filming after the first year and saved the world from this boring painful nothing film, do not become a victim of this cruel joke.
BEST MOVIE EVER. So emotional and relatable
Simple yet very powerful. It is certainly the best film of 2014
The best film of all time.
Wow. Very relatable, very personal. More of an experience than just a movie. So fucking good!

A tad over-hyped with enough passable sentimentality to propel it above the average 'family drama'. Don't expect engaging story to accompany the interesting concept on which it was filmed. I like the idea behind it but honestly Linklater has better  writing chops than this - we all know it.

People are too hyped up in how the film was made. Just because it was a new way to crate a film that took this much time does not automatically make it a great film. It's a decent movie but two hours in you start to wonder when it's going to end, you don't need it to end but you kind of start to want it to and it just doesn't. It plays off simple nostalgia more than the deeper aspects. And then follows the all to typical hollywood storylines between the drunk and abusive husband and father to the born again dad. Everything about this movie is how it took 12 years to make, well it felt like it also took 12 years to watch. That being said it had it's moments and is worth a watch but I highly doubt anybody will sit through this movie twice in their life.
Fatuous crap. Linklater does a really good job of making it feel like 12 years pass as you watch it.

To be frank this movie is long and boring. Yes its "real" and they filmed the same kid over 12 yes but that kid is boring. He has a typical, divorced parents life but he has zero personality that makes me even care that his life is boring. The only thing this movie has going for it is the gimmick of filming it over 12 years....otherwise there is nothing but average people having an average, crappy life. Pass.
I don't understand what all the hype was about. Sure it's a great concept but my god that acting was cringe worthy.

I don't get the love for this movie. It was shot over 12 years and takes you on the journey through this kid's life, but there's nothing in the story that leads to a climax at any point. I was waiting for the story to take a twist or a turn at some point, but it never really did. If it wins an Academy Award then fine, but there are more deserving films in for the 2015 ceremony.

This movie was boring and overrated. If looking at Facebook profiles of people you don't know is you're idea of a good time, this is the movie for you! Nothing happens, and so what if it did. Any notion of dramatic tension is quickly resolved and glossed over.
Sheer brilliance. Richard Linklater's 12 year masterpiece is extraordinarily groundbreaking, an not once did I stop smiling throughout the 2hr45min runtime.

The film is by no means incompetent, and I am hard pressed to name something I would call "bad" in it, there's not much I would call great. The centeral character of the movie is easily the least interesting character, surrounded by small tangents of people more interesting. While it's thematically sound, it overstays its welcome, and at it's heart is impressive more for it's technical achievement than for it's actual content.
I highly recommend it!
Loved the authenticity of the characters. Not the stereotypical teen roles.

I can't even take grand statements about "Boyhood" seriously. It's was not nessarly a bad film, Ethan Hawk as always did a fine job, the whole 12 years to film was a cool experiment. But that's all it is. A 12 year experiment. It's not superbly directed, the acting is at times laughable and just bad. The storyline was not compelling nor for the most part interesting. Actually for a coming of age story it is one of the worst I have seen. 
It's just a bleak, depressing view on a boys life. And a boring kid for that matter. He has next to no screen chemistry and walks around like lame duck most of the movie. 
The most interesting scenes take place when the boy and his sister are small children and then it's just a downward mess for the remainder of the film. Ethan Hawk does whatever he can to salvage it, and the scene near the end where he talks to his son about ambition and time passing and life's meaning was well acted by hawk. But he couldn't save this film. 
Classic? Not even close. Good? No not really. It's not bad but mundane, simple, ill- cunstructed, poorly laid out, akward, pestimictic and for the most part lame. It really is pointless and seemed like a huge waste of time watching. 
Gus Van Saint has portrayed realism In a much more convincing way and simply better. As well as making better coming to age films. and it didn't take him 12 years to make it.

I can see why Boyhood won Best Picture at the Golden Globes.  It is so true to real life: full of small stories, ironies, lessons, disappointments, disfunction, acceptances, imperfect parents trying to do right by their kids, kids accepting their circumstances, hopes, dreams, etc.  Watching this family grow up is amazing and natural.  It reminds you how quickly real life passes.  The general sentiment is that no one has it all figured out but it's going to be okay.
boyhood is truly groundbreaking. but when looking at a movie perspective, there are some minor flaws.

#BoyhoodTheMovie Interesting premise. It's like a core sample of life in the O'dubbs. #EllarColtrane's performance got better through the years & #PatriciaArquette's gritty-ness brought the reality to the project. Crazy to think they filmed it over 12 years.

A beautiful movie about the magic and despair of life. It's crazy how you wait for this moment that will get everything messed up in the movie but it never happens.
Mason's life was pretty difficult but always peaceful.
Very enjoyable and personally thought provoking. Arquette does a great job with her character and seeing the young talent grow with the movie is unique.

I can't see what everyone loves about this movie. It was simple, boring and depressing to watch. By the end of it I just felt nothing or maybe apathy to the kid, resentment towards the stupid mother,and felt it was shallow and didn't accomplish anything. For taking so long and taking such a long time to film I thought it would have had some major impact or event. I'm obviously in the minority.
Overrated, but worth seeing...

an over wrought over done overly long dirge of a movie. nothing spectacular or revealing or revolutionary story about a modern era young growing up.
the fact that it took 12 years to make is more of an indictment than testament to movie making. a waste of 11 years, 11 months.
Best movie I have seen in a while :D!!!

I didn't think I was going to enjoy Boyhood. The masterpiece behind this film is the casting. I think we've found a new star inside of Ellar Coltrane. Patricia Arquette is so good and I fully understand now why she won Best Supporting Actress. Ethan Hawke was really good as well and the rest of the cast was great. All in all I wasn't blown away by it, but the fact this took 12 years and Linklater kept the same cast throughout showed the magic in this film. It's a masterpiece within itself for that alone.

Kudos to Richard Linklater, this film clearly required incredible forethought, time, and effort. The performances were nothing short of what is to be expected when you watch a Linklater film, honest and real. Unfortunately my only gripe is a pretty big one. Where is the plot? The movie just sort of...continues. The only visible sense of purpose that I could see was that a woman drags her children across the worst parts of Texas whilst turning a well respected college professor and a decorated war veteran into full blown alcoholics. Oh yeah, and there was the step dad whose only real purpose was to give the kids something fun to do when they weren't being self obsessed or attacked by the drunken ex husbands.
Leftist movie maker pushes for obama openly in this movie all while making a plotless movie you will regret watching.

Damn. That's a lot to sink in. I don't think I even have a review for this. I wasn't sure I'd like it. Thought it might be gimmicky, and I actually thought it would be more documentary-like. In a time where I often nod off while watching tv, I never yawned and I got emotionally invested in this. That the final line of the movie seemed to basically match my synopsis of a movie that lasts nearly three hours tells me I think I got it.

Yes, there is some bad acting. A lot of the secondary characters are pretty weak...like the high school kids when the boys camp out. Real lame. But scenes like that still stand because we've all been there...someone probably older than us challenging our manhood and we maybe lie or stretch the truth to defend it. 

That's the brilliance of this film. It takes a series of moments...in the "life" of this kid, some fairly dramatic ones, and maybe just reminds us that every moment is important. When you're growing up, or even now, it's easy to forget that. Or not see the importance. But we all have them, little regrets we may not even know we regret. First loves, school, shitty first jobs, relationships, trying to find yourself, trying to fit in, dealing with parents and independence. The difference in this movie is you see the "real" deal as a single actor progresses from being a little boy to a college freshman. 

So yeah, you can pick out this and that and call it a flaw in the movie. At nearly three hours, that's pretty easy to do. But as a whole, the movie is very effective. Even though this kid is not necessarily identifiable to me, he kind of is. Frankly, given that he's a little out there, I wonder how many people relate to him. Because I think that was also brilliant...take a non-mainstream character and make him the one we relate to. On the whole, it was neat to watch these characters age in real time and try to figure out life. Just like we all do every day. That no one ever figured out to make a movie like this until 12 years ago...that's another mystery.
Approximately a dozen vignettes of a boy's life. Good performances, great writing. Tough childhood.

12 years is a long time to make movie. You would think that within those 12 years a writer/director would form a dramatic driving story that would reflect coming of age rather then mirror life itself. you would also expect that technical issues like soft focused shot and mics being seen beneath clothing would be fixed. But within 12 years, the director has failed to create a movie with a central driving conflict, he has also created a somehow lackadaisical technical failure.  

Boyhood does feature amazing performances from the central cast, but the supporting cast seems to fall short throughout the film.

Boyhood is a difficult film in that its more of an experience than a drama, flashing through life like a reel of whatever got cut from the highlights. Its intimate for sure, and (for the most part) admirably avoids melodrama in favour of semi-awkward musing and reflection. It doesn't have any easy ending or necessary high points, but then again neither does life. It just follows a particular random trajectory from which a formless child becomes an ill-defined man. The path is made general enough that nearly any relatively-privileged person will be able to identify with most of the film, which leaves the titular boy feeling a bit like a blank slate up until the final act. As if the growing actors wasn't enough, Boyhood uses cultural reference points perhaps a bit too much to purposely date itself; there's a fantastic Harry Potter scene, but the soundtrack sounds like it was cribbed from American Pie for half the film. But perhaps more deftly than anything else, Boyhood is a portrait of parenthood, with both parents having distinct roles that refuse to be pigeonholed into stereotypical descriptives (some side characters don't escape this). 

Doesn't matter. Words are stupid. Boyhood didn't change my world or my perception of what film can be, but the experiment was certainly successful.
Boring, Boring, Boring.  If the film hadn't been shot with the same kids (gimmick), it would not qualify as a mediocre Lifetime movie.

I thought his "deep" thoughts came across as  shallow. Despite the movie being too long and poor casting w/ Mason Jr) there was an excellent underlying message about not treating life as a series of milestones but making the most out of live in the present.  Bottom line-  very good idea for a movie- could have been much better.

Boyhood is a historical landmark in filmmaking as Linklater's 12 year epic at a run time about 3 hours had my eyes glued to the screen. (for most of it.) Boyhood follows Mason, a boy who we see grow up on screen literally and in his interactions between his family and friends. Richard Linklater is superb in his direction telling a coherent 12 year story in merely 2 hours and 45 minutes. His has captured life in such an abstract way that it seems straight forward. The film looks great as I could not tell that it took 12 years to make. The acting is great all around with Patricia Arquette providing the emotional anchor throughout the film. Ethan Hawke is also fantastic in the film. Ellar Coltrane, who plays Mason, was very good as well.
The screenplay for the most part is very good however it is where I start to have my problems. When we get to teenage Mason his character is kind of dull. Towards the end of the movie I felt it was getting lost and did not know how to conclude. So what began so strong ended on a fire cracker ending instead of an amazing fireworks display of emotions. But that is just me. This is still a tremendous film and a achievement in filmmaking in general. And you should see it at a least once in your life. It is a great film.

My favorite movie genres pretty much reflect that I watch movies to experience fiction - be a part of something that just won't happen in real life (at least not according to what we know as of now).
But this movie proved that our 'ordinary' lives are far more interesting than we give credit for. 

It is one of those movies every time you watch it after awhile, your perception of it will change and you will probably reflect your own life in it. I was pleasantly surprised about how hard it hit home at some parts.  

This 'Technical Masterpiece' wouldn't be complete without top notch acting all round and its narrative prowess. It is not just some movie that took twelve years to shoot, it is much more than that. I'm sure it will be a Classic in the future.

Okay.  I'm not getting the big awards excitement about this one.  It was entertaining enough, but the whole second husband plot was so predictable, I could see it coming a mile away.  I think the reason it's getting so much awards buzz is simply because it is 'different' from a conceptual standpoint.  But, compared to typically made films, such as The Imitation Game and Selma and even Into The Woods, this just doesn't reach those heights.  It's touching, I really enjoyed Lorelei Linklater in this and Ethan Hawke was excellent, but just because a director decides to make a movie with an average plot line in an original way - by using the same kids over a 12 year period - doesn't make it truly groundbreaking as a film - at least in my opinion.  The movie is just kind of like a really long after school special.

"Boyhood" tells a story of growing up through the eyes of a young boy named Mason (Ellar Coltrane), as he faces the joys and struggles of childhood, adolescence, and family. This may sound like a typical coming of age story, but what makes Boyhood so unique is the fact it was filmed over 12 years with the exact same cast, so the audience can literally see Mason grow up before their eyes. Although Boyhood is a tad overrated, quite slow, and lacks any real exciting main conflict, the movie as a whole evokes a feeling of nostalgia and fondness in its audience. Boyhood's authenticity is strengthened by outstanding performances by Patricia Arquette, who plays Mason's hardworking single mother, and Ethan Hawke, who plays Mason's carefree father. Unlike the many bland coming-of-age movies out there that have the tendency to be overdramatic and shallow, Boyhood is a simple and intimate look on life's precious moments. You should know what you're getting into with this: it's a simple family drama about a boy, his sister and their (divorced) parents, and it spends nearly three hours following them over the course of twelve years, in a chatty, naturalistic kind of way. Not a whole lot happens, to be frank - you're simply peering through a window as a boy grows into a young man. Its first two hours fly by and the "growing up" gimmick is smartly used; but once our protagonist turns 18, the film slows right down and the final 45 minute stretch kind of drags. Still, a minor quibble for such a unique film - perhaps this would be improved with an intermission. Elegiac and hopeful in equal parts, Boyhood is a remarkable, inimitable little film and an acting masterclass. Recommended.
