I don't think 2014 was a great year for movies, but Boyhood is arguable it's most ambitious and most profound film I've seen.  In a way, I've been trying to make my own "Boyhood" style films from home movies, I bet most people do, and even more so with the Internet and ease of phone cameras to film and capture every moment.  What starts from 2002 to 2013, it's amazing to see how much the story focuses, even changing based on the world around them with almost no effort.  Boyhood isn't the most interesting of movies (and it sits at 2.75h long) but for me what makes it great is the fact that these kids are basically my age.  In a way it's a viewing glass of really how different and the same life was 10 years ago.  From Dragon Ball Z to GBA SP to Harry Potter to Wii to 9/11 to Lady Gaga, Boyhood doesn't emphasize the changes in our lives, but it shows that despite the changes, we still end up falling into similar patterns of behaviour and our lives will continue on this path beyond really our own control.  Honestly, I don't get why Ethan Hawke (the actuary?) is getting more attention as Mason's father.  He's a man you see is complete garbage in 2002, but learns to be the right man and you wish that he stuck around to care for him as he grew up.  Patricia Arquette does great work too as the mom, holding everyone as best she can, despite having her own issues in life.  The more fascinating thing is guessing who everyone is in a time jump and seeing just hoe life progresses, it's not about the explosions.  It's about understanding relationships with our friends and family and that's what makes the movie pop.  I don't think there has been a Best Picture contender (and I'm betting the winner, unless politics get in the way) this ambitious in my "boyhood" so see this movie.  You might hate me to think it's boring, but I mean would you really want to sit through another 2.75h of superhero telling dumb jokes?

In fact, I wanted to know more about the mother (Patricia Arquette)--not the boy--as I think she had the more interesting hidden story. It's not very often that a film is this greatly ambitious and succeeds in such a way. Linklater's Boyhood is a provocative and wholly unique take on the coming-of-age story, one where the audience is able to experience the life of the hero, Mason, over a course of twelve years. Linklater is able to subtly create rounded characters and tells various little stories that encompass the childhood of Mason and mold him over the course of the film. What makes Boyhood a technical marvel is the fact that it was filmed over the course of 12 years. Linklater has made various films in between but the consistency in the style of his direction throughout Boyhood reveals that he is a true master of his craft. Of the microscopic flaws in the film, dialogue is sometimes one of them; and with a running-time of nearly 3 hours, the other is length. Nevertheless Boyhood is a marvelous achievement.

I was wrong about this one. I had heard that it was a bit boring and way too long. While the length was noticeable, I found myself hooked on the story, wanting to see how Mason would turn out, and it was interesting to watch how all of his life events went into making him who he was becoming.

As much a masterpiece as is Birdman, this film does the same thing that benchmark film does, but in a different way.  Like Iñarritu's film, it makes the viewer feel as though he or she is inside the film with the characters, living along side them as they go through their lives.  While Birdman accomplished this rare feat through some of the most amazing cinematography in the history of film, Boyhood does so with superbly subtle camerawork and hyper reailistic performances, until, at the end, we feel as though these are people we know.

An impressive feat in filmmaking, shot using the same actors over a 12 year period. The casting of Ellar Coltrane at the age of 7, while risky at the time, has really paid off, as he brings a great authenticity to the role as he matures and becomes his own person. The soundtrack is a great accompaniment to the film, often using background songs to show roughly when the scene is taking place. A lovely story of family and growing up, this is a rather special film. There won't be another film like it.
This movie was boring, long and without depth. Totally shocked people liked it.

How does Richard Linklater make the ordinary look extraordinary? This simple plot of a boy growing up, filmed over 12 years works extremely well, and it would be a shame if this film went home empty-handed at the Oscars.

While the 100/100 Metacritic score is clearly excessive, this film is still excellent regardless.

Everyone I have interacted with who has seen this movie has loved it.  Critics have loved it.  I must be missing something because I did not love it.  I fully appreciate the cinematic genius behind it along with the sweat and effort that went into it.  All of the ingredients have to be right.  The willingness for a director and cast to see it through has to be there.  I also fully appreciated the fluidity of it.  For a project spanning 12 years, it certainly gets a big "wow" for being the first of its kind.  After the novelty wore off though, I found myself bored with the mundane moments.  Although I saw actors age on the screen, I didn't feel like engaging character development came along for the ride.   There were statements made on a variety of topics, but instead of finding these interjections clever, I found them gratingly heavy-handed.   This is marathon of a project that although unique, is superficially insightful.  Some people think Rothko is a genius.  I think he's just the first dude to slap blocks of colour together and call it art.  Linklater, is my Rothko with this particular film.
A thought provoking, wonderful movie. So glad I watched it!

That was nothing like child hood. No friends, no games, no sports, no fun, NO CHILDHOOD. Just an over important self worth of a director and writer. BORING and a waste of a original idea

The storyline is simple yet it is a masterpiece. It revolves around a single mum, and her two children growing up into young adults. At first I was skeptical, thinking it was another coming-of-age film, but I was pleasantly surprised, and takes the cake as one of my favourite films in this catergory. It takes awhile to reach it's full charm thought. That charm being - it was filmed over the course of 12 years. In a linear timeline, the story jumps from age to age, showing key events in their lives, as a family.The actors are the same, which is amazing and makes the film feel so much more genuine and real. I loved how the film featured elements from the past, which allowed the audience to not only know the years are going by in the film, and as well have a glimpse at the past, eg. The gameboy advanced and Obama election was a nice touch.  What captivated me even further was that over the course of 12 years the actors actually got to input experiences in their life into the script. Nothing really exciting happens if you think about it, but everything that does happen feels like a family unfolding before the audiences eyes as they grow up with the world as we know it. It's relatable, and we find that we can relate to little bits and pieces. Everything about this film, to the acting, writing and scripting feels natural.
An enjoyable film about growing up in a typical disjointed American family.
did I watch the wrong movie because this movie was ok at best. The ending sucked and I watched a kid grow up throughout the movie and turn out to be someone I wouldn't want to be around.

What a brillant feat!  Richard Linklater does an amazing job at making a movie about life!  To be able to take 12 years and keep same cast together is unheard of and it works well.  I now understand why it's getting all the praise as it deserves it! WOW

If there is a better film in 2014 then I haven't seen it. Filmed over a period of 12 years, following our boy protagonist from the age of 6 to 18, 'Boyhood' is a coming-of-age movie as much about boyhood as parenthood. It somehow reminds us that while growing up as a kid could be painfully long, for parents it is often a dream-like flash and before we know it we are contemplating our own funerals. Extraordinarily moving.
Really find it unique and genuine what Linklater achieved with this 12 year chronicle. Scene to scene though, it tends to wear thin in the last hour of the film.
I barely got through this movie.  Besides Ethan Hawke, the acting was terrible.  The story was bloated.  I can't understand how 98% of reviewers liked it.
Truly remarkable feat of film making.
Way too many trivial moments seizing us and our time.

While imperfect, there are moments of great poignancy. Boyhood at times captures the very essence of life itself - its pains, anxieties, fears and joys, through its raw, unpretentious filter. Notwithstanding the baggy 165 minute running time, this is definitely a unique endeavour, and deserves to be seen.

This is a special film, with quality that matches the concept's ambition. Yet, a novel concept executed well doesn't translate the word 'masterpiece'. This authentic, coming-of-age panorama is overlong, and lacks oomph. 8/10.

You know I really really did enjoy this movie everything in this movie was almost perfect up until the ending . . . the dialogue at the end really just felt pretentious and like it was trying to say something profound but instead of pulling it off effortlessly well like the rest of the movie it just comes off as corny. Other than that this movie is great.

What was the point? Nothing happens, it's an endless film showing a kid become a young adult. The only dramatic outburst is Patricia Arquette crying for no explicable reason. The daughter was horrific, I cannot believe this piece of crap got nominated! A complete waste of time!
Really unique, a movie everyone can connect with.

Nailed it!  Loved it and will owned it too.  Talk about thinking outside the box Linklater and his supporters did just that and deserve high praise for a job well done.  Not your typical "tear-jerker" but rather a "real-jerker".  Loved the way everyone aged, the music and time periods were great.  Well worth your effort.
What a wonderful and unique film.I found myself genuinely fearing for Mason as he stumbled into situations. Why? Because I had known him since he was a toddler. Added bonus of a fantastic soundtrack.

This is really a good movie for parents.. Good parenting and stuffs. I would recommend it. I love the dialogue, maybe it's just me, but It's not my kind of thing IMO. I was thinking at some point, maybe this would end when the teenager became a father and have kids and pass on and on.. It's more of a film with values and what's real.

Ambitious in scope, well directed, well acted and boing as hell. Really disappointing that such extraordinary effort would go into such an ordinary story. Yes you get to watch people actually age on screen but you have to endure all of the mundane crap of ordinary lives with no twist nor plot nor conclusion. If this is great film making I'll just stick to books.

I love Richard Linklater. The concept for this film was amazing. The acting was above average but the story meandered and the film was more of a kind-hearted biopic. I am glad he made it but his "Sunrise Series" is far superior to this film. Check this one out but don't expect a deep story and get ready for 3 hours of viewing.

I went to see this given the reviews it was receiving, and walked out 165 minutes later thinking the world was playing some kind of prank on me.  I quite honestly hated almost every minute of this.  I'm going to try to elaborate on why:

It's predictable - as soon as I saw Arquette's character, what ran through my mind was OK, what's the most cliched thing they could do with this?  Oh, have her marry her professor and he'll turn out to be an abussive drunk asshole.  Don't get me wrong, no-one deserves an asshole, but right there any claims of originality I had been hearing went right out the door, especially when her NEXT guy also turned out to be a bit of a jerk.  Ethan Hawke (whom, OK, I kinda loked at first) started as an easy-going pseudo-intellectual -- gee, he hasn't played THAT before :/ -- who aged and became just as boring as everyone else.  Which brings me to...

Nothing of consequence happens - by which I mean, what exactly does Mason learn here?  How does he change over the course of the film, besides physically?  Yeah, the first stepfather was abussive to the mother, but what of him and his sister?  He lets them go with their father even though their chores aren't finished, and tells them they'll finish when they get back -- not unreasonable, and yet it's presented that way -- and he makes Mason get a haircut -- wow, such a mean guy (that's sarcasm).  He misses curfew and the second dad chews him out mildly -- while drinking -- and Mason doesn't seem to care but nothing happens.   Near as I could tell, he's the same from what little actual character he has he doesn't -- he's the same bland person at the start as he is at the beginning, and none of his actions or inactions impacts that.  When his girlfriend dumped him and called HIM an asshole I was agreeing with her and I don't think i was supposed to.

What's with the mixed "drinking is bad" signals -- our first sign that the professor is bad is he buys alcohol.  Then the second father is drinking a beer while very passively chewing out Mason.  The film seems to concentrate on the stepfathers drinking as a sign they're assholes.  Yet EVERYONE in this film drinks and yet only those two are focused on being the bad guys because of it. Why?

The side stories we don't see seem more interesting than the main one -- How and why did Hawke decided to settle down?  The landscaper who went to college at Arquette's suggestion, he seems interesting, why couldn't we follow that?  No, we're just going to watch this kid with no real personality instead?  OK...

The length -- yeah, i get that covering twelve years this would be long, but why 165 minutes?  I was completely checked out after 120 and yet it kept going.  I was getting ready to leave when Mason got into his truck and drove off to college, but then there are TWO MORE SCENES at the college.  WHY?  His boyhood was clearly over when he drove off by himself for the first time (the only symbolism that kinda clicked when it happened -- yay, one point).  There was no reason for those last two scenes -- none.  Oh, wait, I found out later that girl was the same one who gave him a note saying he liked the haircut.  That was 9-10 years before, and we had seen this girl for 30 seconds tops.  We know nothing about her or these other characters he just met.  I also can barely recognize my own younger cousins after 8 years, let alone a girl I barely saw.

The idea is not really that original -- there's a bit of risk involved here, sure, that an actor will get hurt or die in the intervening time period, but really that's kind of it.  There's nothing about growing up that isn't covered in any long running TV series, and it's actually better there because, as I mentioned previously, you get character development which Mason did not get.  Aside from that shooting schedule, there's nothing technically outstanding in the film -- the cinematography and sound is fine, the editing is fine.  I'm not saying they're bad, but they just don't stand out.

So, yes, I unappologetically hate this film.  I get that it's a slice of life type film, and that some will get it and others won't, but usually in these films I can see what others *might* connect to in the film if I don't myself like it.  Here, I honestly don't see it, and every time someone has tried to explain WHY they liked it, it ends up being one of the points I hated about it.

That this is winning the awards this season over, IMO, much more thoughful, better acted, and well put together films such as Birdman, The Grand Budapest Hotel, The Imitation Game, and Whiplash is upsetting me in ways it really shouldn't given that these are just films.
Over-rated movie which plays like a movie form the Hallmark channel or a movie made for TV on ABC Family.
Way too long and extremely boring!
"You know how everyone's always saying seize the moment? I don't know, I'm kind of thinking it's the other way around, you know, like the moment seizes us."

Boring, disconnected, and pointless, this award winning picture is yet another hollywood favorite that was a waste of even the miniscule Redbox $1.30. The given dialog is cliche ridden and the title character has a perpetually stoned-looking gaze. Boyhood is lacking in both imagination and intrigue, except the inherent expectation after each time-shift that something will happen that is at least marginally interesting, dramatic or maybe funny. NOTHING REALLY HAPPENS ON SCREEN. All major plot changes occur OFFSCREEN. Go figure?! Clever? NO. Stupid? YES.

Boyhood, must watch.This was simply mind blowing and awakening. Very Fine movie that breaks the norm. The only movie that I watched till the credit roll end.

I'm not sure I can say anything to add to the plethora of shining reviews. This was a really intimate movie and the technical scale of it is pretty breathtaking.
Amazing editing for this very cool idea, well acted by Arquette in particular.
Was an okay movie and interesting concept, however, I do think it's been overrated because of the length of time to make it.
great accomplishment, okay movie.
Easily the worst movie of 2014.  2 hours and 45 minutes of boring nothingness.

An interesting experiment in filmmaking, but not a great movie. No true conflict, and the performances were only slightly above average. It was cool to see the kids grow up, and the slight trip through time was fun, remembering how things were in the early 2000s, when smart phones didn't exist. Watched on DVD from Redbox, with Sam at her house January 14, 2015.
It's good, but so slow and long! The plot is so simple as life, and we can all relate with. Also, the concept of filming for 12 years is also cool, but it missed something.
slow but a good movie

Technically, it is an ambitious, monumental achievement in the history of cinema. It is magnetizing simply watching the actors age right before your very own eyes, but the film too often wanders aimlessly and its characters offer little intrigue.
Great movie considering it has no plot. Parents are great actors. Long movie but I loved seeing the children grow up. Movie was filmed during the 15 years.

Are we praising the concept here? The director's past work? Cause I don't get it. The first half is just garbage. Hawke and Arquette barely hold it together. The acting was so bad I doubted I was watching the right movie. Some aspects of family life are better portrayed as the kids get older, but by no means is any of it beyond what has been seen before (the acting only getting minimally better). The time jumps are random and offer no real meaning with each age sometimes providing nothing other than showing Coltrane at that particular age. Other than the concept (and Linklater's name on it) there is nothing here that will be remembered in the decades to come.
Holy shit!! I knew nothing about this movie and I'm so glad I didn't! Just. Fucking. Perfect. The movie of the millinnium....literally.

I feel like I just relived my life and the life of so many american boys growing up in this fantastically well done film.  Reminiscent of almost every phase of life up to college, you might not be Mason but you certainly have been where he's been and felt what he's felt.  Raw, sometimes dark, sometimes heartwarming, the movie is long but keeps you hooked with the natural ups and downs that life brings.  The film is made infinitely more powerful due to the characters aging with the film.
A brilliant work of art about the human condition. Profound on so many levels. The acting was superb. Loved this movie.
Still curious  how this movie made it to the Oscars!
First half of the movie was really good then took an extreme nose dive in the second half. This movie is extremely overrated and i really hope this does not win best picture.

This has to be the most overrated film of the year. Critis and audience are being swept up in a concept and nothing more. Take away the 12 years it took to make this film and you are left with a boring lackluster film. This movie pans the lives of these characters but does not go truly deep into who they are and what drives them. The lead actor who this film centers around does nothing but moop around throughout most of the film and it's only until the end he developed a personality though very dry. For the true star was the older sister who for me stole every scence she was in, even at a young age. Patricia Arquett and Ethan Hawks performances are good, but once again who are these people? Why did they split up? Why are they who they are? None of these questions are answerd. What's worst is her character remarrys twice and her husband become severe alcholics without giving a reason to why. Especially when we first meet theses two men they are perfectly nice guys though flawed but still no signs of the bad husband syndrome. The big sin of this film is that there is no plot nor conflict to push this film along. It takes snap shots of there lives and before it goes truly deep into anything we are propelled ahead to a few years leaving much unanswered and most of the time filling in the blanks to what happens in there live since we left them last. This film for me is that weird piece of art or performance art that only those who are pretentious and naive will get, because they don't want to miss out on the new cool thing. This was a boring snap shot of a film that just pans through the live of these people. I think your better off looking through your mothers or grandmothers old photo albums at least that experience will have a better payoff.

This movie has been receiving rave reviews since its release so I thought Id give it a go. To be honest it wasnt one for me it plodded along at a slow pace which made it very difficult for me to get attached to any of the characters or the story as a whole. I however have tons of respect for those who were involved it this project for sticking out the 12 years

I get that the messy, unexplained jumps from events and emotions to others is how an adolescent perceives their lives.  But, from an audience point of view, it is very unsatisfying.  The result is an oversimplification of characters and a boring 2+ hours.  An interesting experiment and amazing commitment, but I was shocked to see the Oscar nomination.  I get it, but didn't like it.  Ethan Hawke's other independent film, Predestination, was more interesting and entertaining.  Saw them both the same week.
I don't know how I feel about this movie, I was very confused.

An epic movie. We've seen kids growing on tv shows, but this is the first time we can see it in a movie. It's really refreshing  watching the same characters growing physically and mentally. Also it's a treasure for showing the pop culture of the year the scene is set. Like Sam singing Britney Spears' "Baby one more time", talking of the new Star Wars movies or people passing their time on Facebook. It will certainly win the Oscar for the best picture of the year.

OK, I must have missed something fundamental.  This was an amazing unexceptional film.  The acting was adequate.  The newcomers (the kids) were actually pretty bad.  The story...well, there wasn't really a story.  More just a series of vignettes.  It is exactly what I thought it would be:  more a devise than a good film.  It might be groundbreaking in it's execution, but it hardly covers new territory in unfolding a family's life.  And it really on became a story about boyhood once the boy was in high school.  Up until then he had maybe a page of dialogue.  I think there are a lot of bandwagoners drooling over Linklater because...they're supposed to.

Very different paced movie and absolutely worth watching. I don't know that it is, in fact, as tremendous as everyone says it is, but it is thoroughly engaging, thoughtful and moving. I especially appreciated that every opportunity they had to choose the cliche plot twist, they didn't take it. Instead, they went for honesty and emotional truth.

With all the big scale biopics coming out this year, with hotshot actors and producers and what not, you come across this amazing piece of cinema. The flow is not perfect, as the movie was filmed over 12 years in bits and pieces. The movie jumps from one time period of Mason's life to another, characters come and go, while others hang around.
 
However, you connect. You connect, even a little bit, with every stage or incident or event of his life. Whether it be lying aimlessly, drawing random shit, bicycling with friends, saying goodbye to those friends when you move to a different city/school, the awkward/cringy teenage years, so on and so forth, I could go on and on. The performance is honest. It is here where Boyhood distinguishes itself, where you can literally put yourself in Mason's place. Stuff like this is rare, and it sticks.
Superb acting, editing and portraying of real life, "Boyhood" srikes viewers as an honest, straigthforward depiction of ordinary people whose lives are extraordinarily rich.

What an over-rated film!.  A major disappointment for me...long and boring!  All the adult males we see are drunks, jerks, or idiots; and then they just disappear with no explanation.  Ethan Hawke desperately trying to be a father is the biggest idiot of them all.

The best thing this has going for it is the unheard of process of filming a movie with the same actors over a 12 year period. There is nothing else new here and I am unclear why it is being praised so highly.

Boyhood is the most ingenious film of this century, of any century. Linklater has created the perfect film, flawless in every way. He has sculpted a masterpiece, flawless and perfect, inf act you can call it a masterpiece of flawlessness.

Boyhood is the greatest thing to happen to cinema since the invention of the camera, and the most important think to happen to mankind since the invention of fire. A one of a kind experience, nothing on Earth compares to this heartwarming, majestic, epic and beautiful work of art. If the greats from the Renaissance were alive today; they would kill themselves for being so shitty compared to Linklater.

Linklater's poetic dialogue about a boring kid mumbling should be compared to the greatest works of literature. In fact if I could, I WOULD TAKE A SHIT ON EVERY BOOK EVER WRITTEN BECAUSE BOYHOOD IS THE BEST FUCKING THING EVER.

That was amazing! Boyhood succeeded being deep and entertaining at the same time. I didn't know this movie was made for years but I had my suspicion while watching that the kids were really growing old and they're not just swapped by another actors. A quick googling taught me they made this movie for twelve effing years!
It was nice, but pointless. The end had nothing to offer but a nice quote.
Not necessarily a film I'll go back to often, but certainly an incredible achievement on nearly every level.

A masterpiece of sorts. Linklater's innovative approach to the 'coming-of-age' genre is something to admire. Many will put it down for its rambling narrative (or lack thereof), but I think not having a coherent plot structure is the whole point of this chronicle of life itself. Certainly a pioneering film in terms of its production. It's also very compelling, well-acted, and consistently engaging despite it nearly 3-hour running time. A landmark in cinematic history, a shoe-in for awards season, and a must-see, surely.

Pretty typical coming-of-age standard 3-star drama... just with a gimmick. The gimmick wasn't enough and after 20 minutes you don't care about it anymore, and what we're left with is a long, drawn out melodrama.

Saw this last night and was close to tears at the end.  Easily the best movie I have ever seen.  For someone my age it is an incredibly nostalgic movie with a number of things that bring childhood memories flooding back throughout the film.

An intense look at the life of a boy from childhood to adulthood. Filming over a 12-year timespan took a great effort from the crew and actors, but the story adds nothing new to all the other coming of age dramas.
Wonderful movie. It depicts real lives facing challenges in families.
Meh. Just a really long time-lapse.

It's a little bit too long. A good edit would've made a great movie a classic. Patricia Aquette is amazing and so is Ellar Coltrane. Every scene of them together was perfect. I wish someone else had played Mason Sr though. Ethan Hawke's words of wisdom speeches became pretty grating, but maybe that was the point. I've watched it three times and it holds up to repeated viewing despite the length.

I feel like the greatest part of this film is the 12 year commitment that the cast and crew made to complete this project. With that being said, I think the best part about this film is the nostalgia (Especially as a 90's kid). It was a simple but good story. The directing was good. The actors pulled it off. Something that's underlooked, but amazing is the continuity of the film overall and how it felt fluent. Boyhood was watching someone's life in a different cinematic way...and it's a lot of fun doing so.

Boyhood was a really well put together film. The fact they decided to go down the root of shooting the same actors for 12 years instead of getting different ones as the kids age is amazing. I really thought this was definitely a film of those who grew up through the 90's and 2000's. It made me feel like I grew up on watching this film. I definitely see why it won the Golden Globe for best film and hopefully it gets nominated for best picture by the Oscars and wins.

I'd like to watch it when I'm "old". fifty or sixty. good for nostalgia. 
otherwise, it was good. nothing spectacular all around. pretty standard, feel-good coming of age story. typical Linklater for the dialogue and script: highschool musings of the philosophic type blended with moderately dark occurrences. 
it is cool that he succeeds with the actors sticking with this for so long, despite it not being a yearly Harry Potter release.

There is a lot one can say about Boyhood. I mean, it's an incredible film that required a lot of patience and, above all, trust. The fact that the picture spanned 12 years is incredible and something that has never been done before. Another great thing is that I believe it would prove difficult to do it again. Taking on a project like this for another director would seem almost like cheating, a direct copy of Richard Linklater.
	Linklater brings us a coming of age drama this year that is like none other. It really is the epitome of the coming of age film as the same actors and actresses were used throughout the 12 years the film took to make. We get to peek inside the lives of an everyday family (living with divorce, visits with dad, mom remarrying a collection of drunken assholes) and watch as they progress through the years. The fact that there is no real climax adds to its exceptional artwork. The climax is the film itself. We root on the mother played by Patricia Arquette (the best supporting actress this year in my opinion) and enjoy the scenes with the father played by Ethan Hawke. What makes this film so great is the chemistry that these characters have. They make acting in this film seem so easy and carefree. I sat down watching this movie thinking are they acting or just being themselves? I think the ladder is the answer and that's what makes the film so fluent and easy to watch.
	In closing, this is my pick for best picture of the year. The directing is undeniably terrific (and, again in my opinion, worthy of the Oscar), the acting is impeccable, and I didn't see a false note anywhere to quote Matthew McConaughey at last year's Academy Awards. I give this film a very easy 5 out of 5 stars. Well done.
A great movie that was 12 years in the making.

A fictional attempt to imitate Michael Apted's brilliant 7 UP series.  Slow, awkward improvisation.  The sequence with Grampa Farmer and his wife, jamming guns and bibles and bib overalls together, was embarrassing.  BOYHOOD shows how badly Hollywood can handle a brilliant British idea.

Another original from the Texan Richard Linklater, who's come a long way from his bizarre, protracted "auspicious" debut, Slacker and post Dazed & Confused misfire, The Newton Boys. It is long, but heartfelt though I doubt many would watch this marathon more than once. It doesn't have a scripted act story, but then again, this isn't that kind of film. It plays more like an experiment, albeit a successful one, which is exactly what it is. A kid grows up over time and it tracks his life. It's unbelievable they used the same kid through 12 years.

In that respect Boyhood is an incredible experience that needs to be seen.  The film is honest, brave, and at times it can be simply stunning. 

FINAL SCORE = 4/5 Bear Paws

Hugely overrated.  Take away the gimmick of filming it over twelve years, and what is there?  Just a series of meaningless events happening to profoundly dull people.  The idea, obviously, is to examine life "as it is," but there is a reason for the old saying: "God writes lousy drama."  It might help if the boy in question grew up to be someone we could invest in, but he is just a self-absorbed, pretentious brat who thinks he invented angst.  And Linklater's writing too often resembles a Lifetime movie or a Danielle Steele novel. Any bets there is another chapter coming in twelve years called: "Manhood?"  Yawn.

"Boyhood" is Richard Linklater's Before trilogy as a coming-of-age story set in America. The vibe is undeniably familiar for all the right reasons. It's a very low-key movie but delivers big on its relatable reality. This is a journey, both cinematic and in authenticity, taken by the cast, crew, and audience, living and observing each defining milestone, good and bad, pass us by. Don't let this be one that slips past you.
Retarded waste of time.
Absolutely beautiful. So breathtakingly real.

Boyhood is the best movie of the year, indeed. It is basically about the story of boy growing up in a repeatedly broken family but if you ask me to be more specific like "what was actually the story", I won't be capable to answer. The story was about a time frame of life, it does not have a start or an ending. It went on...

Richard Linklater has given us this gift, this film was made from such intense love that is indescribable.  This is one of the most beautiful films that I have been lucky enough to witness.  The actors do such a fantastic job, that you feel that you are watching home movies as opposed to a film.

It's difficult to find something wrong with this movie. One easily gets attached to the characters which makes us want to know what is going to happen next as they grow up. Saw this today inflight, What an authentic representation of Life. Set in Texas. A Movie that took place over 12 years! I'm raving! You have got to see this Movie. And if you're from Texas, well, I tell you, they did the Lone Star State justice!
What was the plot of this movie, life itself.

An enjoyable but deeply flawed experiment. While it was an enjoyable experience, the strictly slice of life perspective of the film felt like a wasted opportunity for showing depth of growth of characters in a three hour long movie. The representation of the single mom versus the dead beat father was decidedly unfair and basically sexist. The father has a long extended monologue at the end of the film which all but blames the single mother for a string of abusive alcoholic husbands and absolves him of any blame re: the raising of the children. Then, directly afterwards, the mother's last scene with her son (the main character) is short and bitchy, where the film all but confirms the hypothesis of the father. This is the culmination of a narrative that gives the single father tons of time and space to explore his character, but relegates the single mom to roles and never gives her any dialogue to explain her POV. That and you'd be forgiven for believing America is as white as Sweden with only a single Latino character who exists to be saved by the mother. Worth watching once for the conceit, but not worth revisiting. (Also, the super trite ending didn't help wash down the film either either.)
2 hours and 44 minutes of agony that had a terrible ending. Someone's needs their ass beat for this.

Best Movie of 2014. Everything was done right.
Amazing concept, good script, mediocre acting.

This is a good movie; it's different; it feels like an experimental film.  It's interesting.  But I don't think it is a great movie.  The best thing about the film is how it was made.  It's interesting to have the same actors play the same parts for over 12 years.  It would have been better if there was a compelling story to go with that.  Sure, this is nice, but if this was filmed in the way that most films are made nobody would care.  Also, some of the acting was not good.  I liked this movie, but considering this seems to be the front-runner for the best picture Oscar, I think it is over-rated. Is it better than the Imitation Game?  I would say no.

Brilliantly narrated, I still expected more from this film which took the dedication of at least twelve years. It didn't leave behind a very strong emotional impression in my heart, but it is indeed a great movie. Special applauses for Ellar Coltrane, whom we saw growing.

My Favourite film of 2014
Holy shit. This movie was so painfully boring I nearly commited suicide. Nearly three hours of aimless wondering. Bad script, bad story, bad acting. UGH!!!!!!!!

A fantastic idea that forces you to look at life from an incredibly and tragically ordinary perspective and be captivated by it. It's a subtle reminder of the simple ironies that make modern life so conceptually complicated, and that we're simultaneously doted upon and victimized by circumstance every day of our lives. Some will find it uplifting, some depressing, some completely superfluous, and that's the beauty of it. We see ourselves in between the lines here, and whether you've got a ghost story or a fairy tale to tell you'll find yourself moved.
It's understandable why for some this is an amazing film but for me it was immensely depressing.
Watching this movie is amazing. this film took 12 years with same cast, it's movie you can reflect.

Great character development, but they had 12 years to do it. There is zero plot and the story is a meandering almost 3 hour time suck. Patricia Arquette's final line in the movie: "I just thought there would be more" sums up the movie.
Kudos for an original premise but the story itself is forgettable. Film anyone's childhood and it's probably more entertaining (and shorter) than this movie.

Good movie, but I didn't think it was worthy of the Best Drama Golden Globe. And I wasn't too fond of all the liberal bullshit they were peddling. It's clear that the award was won on account of the fact that it took twelve years of intermittent filming to complete the picture. The content itself seemed very benign; I felt the family unit never faced any true adversity. Sure, they had an alcoholic stepfather who beat their mother, but it felt very watered down. Overall, I enjoyed the film and watching the children grow into young adults, but I was left feeling slightly empty after nearly 3 hours. It seemed to teeter in a limbo between realism and Hollywood fantasy, but never truly found its niche.

I am impressed that Linklater and his cast and crew were able to commit to such a long undertaking, filming this family drama over 12 years.  I am also someone who just happens to be genuinely interested in the aging process, how people grow and change in personality and looks...unfortunately a good chunk of the middle of this film just left me kind of cold.  It isn't all bad, I like the stuff near the beginning, and how things wrapped up...and I liked the idea of seeing the mom's two failed marriages as the begin nicely and fall apart...but the actor playing our lead wasn't nearly as good as some reviews lead me to believe.  Part of that might be the script which has him talking like no teenager I've ever met.  Sure he has ideas and thoughts like a teenager, but they are spoken in a far more eloquent way than the average teenager speaks, and it kind of took me out of the movie.  Still, a fine undertaking with some good performances and some good moments...but the script lacked cohesion and too episodic. If there was a driving force for the story (beyond watching everyone age), or if there was more to the Mason character this might have grabbed me better.
Take away the the actual aging of its stars and this is just a meandering movie with no plot and weak acting.
Great movie, great direction, awesome character that feels like an actual family. This project needed a guy with great determination and great passion, and got it.

I was expecting to be annoyed at this movie. So what - it was filmed in pieces over 12 years. Gimmick. But the thing is this movie is just really well written. Seen from the perspective of a kid, then tween then teen adults are portrayed as confusing, bossy, randomly preachy and then vulnerable. The moments that stick out aren't the graduations and big school projects but the first time someone asks you if you want a beer, or makes you feel like you are good at something.
Watch it ... when you feel like getting lost in a becoming of age story.
fictional documentary takes us back to the 90s. soundtrack is so reminiscent. a bit long, but a nice journey to take.

I don't think this film (from story wise) is out of ordinary, but i must agree with the fact that this film was made for over 12 years with the very same cast from they were very little to a grown up young adult is amazing, they still able to remember the situation, emotion and spirit of this film. Excellent job!

What a great premise for a movie. True dedication to the art and craft of cinema to commit to a twelve year project. 

Yet, it was twelve years of emotions ...without them, and without consequences. It left me disconnected to the characters. There are scenes where you expect critical dialog or depth of emotion and you are left hanging. Why wasn't there any development after leaving her second husband? What happened to those children? Are we left not to care? Why when Mason looks down at an image on a cell phone for what seems like an eternity, was there no accident? There are endless examples of single scene characters and little connection. I think one of the best dialogs is with the photography teacher in the darkroom, yet you never see him again.   

I will say I thought Ethan Hawke does a great job creating a comfortable, believable character. Though, check Ellar Coltrane, Mason for a pulse because I don't think it rose at all through the movie.

An ambitious scale of a film that took twelve years to wrap up it's final reel of film has been praised by critics and users alike. Boyhood Is an excellent depiction of real life and the experiences we may face through our lifetimes. Watching the same boy grow into a man over the years is a magical moment to sit through, scrutinizing the same actor going through these dilemmas in his life. Even with some pacing issues throughout this almost three hour movie, it was an experiment that will change the thought process of filmmaking.
just too fake and too real at the same time
Golden Globes messed up. straight up trash! bad acting. Adam Sandler'esque script! irony. gaining weight. monotone monotony! Do yourself a favor and pass on it please.
The only thing that happens in this movie is the most boring kid on the planet grows up into the most boring teenager on the planet.
The movie you need to watch before leaving home when you are 18 !!!

Boyhood is probably one of the greatest movies I have ever seen in my entire life. The movie took 12 years to make and it follows the same characters and you get to see them age which is something new and original. This movie feels real. The characters don't feel like actors they seem like real people. The soundtrack to this movie is great because every year you get to hear the song that was popular in that year. The acting is phenomenal and the dialogue between the characters are great also. The story to this film is just about growing up to be an adult something simple. I think if this movie was 5 hours long I would still enjoy it. In my opinion I think this is Richard Linklater's best film. Boyhood is probably one of my favorite movies of all time and I think it's the greatest coming of age films ever.
One of the best movies of 2014. Simply brilliant!

What an achievement. Linklater follows the same characters over a 12 year period - a ground breaking concept - only to find that nothing interesting happens.  There is a reason why a compilation of my home videos is not Oscar worthy.  It turns out that people want a story with someone overcoming some type of conflict.  Watching kids evolve from boring to a little less boring is not a story worth paying to see.

The movie is a one trick pony that the critics will love, but will make the audience a bit sleepy.
Richard Linklater does no wrong.
"The Best Picture of the Year, 2014."

Patricia Arquette gives a perfect performance, if not for her this movie would fall flat. I get the movie, I admire the amount of work that went into it but all in all, the boy is so unlikeable that it made me not care for the film as a whole. I think his sister would've been a more compelling subject and I'm sad that story line was barely touched upon. Also, way too long.

I have 20 minutes left of this film that I will only watch so that I can say I viewed the film in its entirety. This is not something I want to do, but I guess I have to.

Let me start off by saying that I don't "hate" the film. I don't really even dislike it. I honestly have no feeling towards it one way or the other. I feel like I've been spying on a very mundane modern, post-new millennium family.

Yes, it's "neat" seeing these people age naturally, much like I've seen everyone in my life do over the course of the years. It's nothing new in my life, and I've been doing it by watching shows in syndication as well. The only thing with real life and syndicated shows... there are actually interesting story-lines going on.

Richard Linklater takes a group of actors and films them what seems like once a year for the course of 12 years. I've no idea why he didn't take the break between shots to come up with an interesting story/script. The acting was NOT very good; and at times I felt as if a friend shot this and I was merely being supportive by viewing it. Due to the concept with filming one cast, I wanted to really love it. It's a silly reason to want to love a film, "The cast, they age for reals, no make up!!! GENIUS!!!" Yeah, that's not a very good reason.

I'm only writing this review because I hear it's up for an Oscar. I lack the mental care and energy to search, "Under which freaking category????" If it's best film, I guess I won't hate the nomination as much as I hated the over dramatic, over hyped, over inflated, false sense of social issue, Hollywood lame attempt at a "deep" film; Crash.

The film starts out with a boy day dreaming and he gets in trouble at school. According to his mother; who is really disinterested in the ordeal, he tormented the teacher. Okay, so he goes from spacing off which apparently they treat as the worse offense, then the secondary offense is destroying school property. The boy argues with his sister and they're always at each others throats. The mom moves them to Houston to start a new life- This is where the story should pick up.

The next year she is in college and you're lead to believe she's going to have a thing with her professor. Ffwd to the next year where she's married to the professor and the boy has a bunch of new step siblings. Ffwd to the next year where the professor is abusive, and the mom with her two kids leave. Screw the step-kids. That was the highlight of the film. The ffwrds that follow are extremely boring, low key, and random. She marries another guy who turns out to be another drunk (yes, the professor was a drunk) and abusive. Then it goes to mundane restaurant conversations with the boy who's now a teen with girls that he's dating and then not dating. No mention of further altercations with him and teachers, no more day dreaming, that whole first scene was really nothing. I felt like I could have been spying on my neighbors, if they were really boring, uninteresting people. The only thing Linklater did was throw in modern fashions and technology of the year into the mix so we know that the world is advancing. Watch this for over two hours... two long hours.

I still have twenty minutes left and all I can think is, "Why am I watching an interesting little boy (for the first ten minutes) turn into a boring emo kid (that lasts over two hours)?" The father could have been an interesting character (who has out of place liberal agenda dialogues), but then he gets married and looks like a used car salesman who has conformed to the masses, and it wasn't done in any sort of way that would appear interesting. The mom turns into a boring professor. Oh yes, I'm so anxious to see how this all turns out. :|

**Update** I saw how it all turned out. The mom acted like it was good he's going off to college. Then she over dramatically cried because her life is over... Did I say over dramatic? It wasn't over dramatic, that would require acting skills. She cried like a five year old does when they're trying to get out of trouble  (I chose five because they don't know a good con cry yet). Then he drives awkwardly and stiffly. He goes to college and immediately goes on a hike with his new roommate and two girls where we watch him stiffly walk and then stiffly deliver an awkward conversation where he has no idea where to look or how to "act".

I guess Linklater didn't want to waste time on actually giving direction, and none of the actors wanted to waste time in figuring out how to actually 'act'. I'm glad the film didn't run much longer, otherwise I might go from indifference to actual hatred. After viewing the entirety of the film, it really could replace 'Crash' as the movie to loathe.

Arquette and Hawke shine for me in a random mess. The film focuses on this boy growing up, who naturally becomes different by stages to the point that he is so different, and from the beginning, as a viewer you know less about him, mainly as the performance was almost empty. It is a brave attempt in one way, but seriously this film is flawed and has lost its way because of its own uniqueness, or a cheap gimmick.

BELIEVE THE HYPE!!! This is the best film since the artist. Creatively and conceptually, it's a piece of genius. It Creepily captures the essence of live from our greatest hopes to the stunning acceptance of actual reality. Including all the nuance of all the transitions. I give boyhood my highest rating. 5.5!!!

What potential! What a concept! And how... unfulfilling. I had high expectations that this movie would jump out as a groundbreaking way to document a child's growth into adolescence. I was looking forward to content that I could relate to - to relive my own childhood through the eyes of little Mason and find something universal in our shared experience that speaks to my heart. But there was nothing there to relate to! With the slight exception of the relationship Mason had with his dad, the other relationships in this film are incredibly under developed. If this is an accurate portrayal of this boy's childhood then I feel so bad that he missed out on so much. There is no chemistry, no attraction, no love, no loss, no anything. And the defining moments of boyhood that Rich Linklater chose to put in the film were mere glimpses of what they (seemingly) should have. SPOILER: A potentially passionate speech of encouragement from Mason's photography teacher is boiled down to one scene in a dark room where Mason mumbles out loud about his work ethic. Mason's love life with his girlfriend amounts to several emotionless scenes of conversation about philosophy... and one moment when they got caught under the covers in his sister's roommate's bed to which Mason mutters in his quiet voice... "so awkwaaaard" *cut scene* That was a defining moment of boyhood? Experimentation with alcohol and drugs: scene drinking beers with "the seniors" kicking through wooden boards. That was it? It's difficult to believe Mason's mother loved him given the lack of chemistry between the two (although maybe this was done on purpose?) and the sister's interaction with Mason is almost non existent especially as he enters high school. The movie just passed, one scene after another, without any development of anything. I can't understand all the high ratings unless Mason's boyhood is a reflection of Linklater's - Devoid of sports, friendships with other neighborhood boys, a longing attraction with multiple women, and maternal relationship where his mother outwardly shows her care and love, and is instead replaced by distant family members and a dry sense of cynicism that leads him to an interest in art and philosophical mumbling - which it probably is. Unfortunately I can see a lot of the other film critics "relating" to this life too.

this is the best film I have seen in recent years. A magnificent film of my life. This film was shot within a time span of 12 years. it is a top class coming of age drama which shows ultimate dedication for the project. no one should miss this movie.

The mom and dad are interesting characters and the first half felt real and had some tense moments. Then the kids grow up, the main character becomes a twerp of a teenager and the cringe-worthy "look at how deep I am" philosophical dialog turns it into a three-hour long film student project.
Imperfect, but there's no film like it, nothing that documents America on such a grand scale.

let me say up front i'm fan of richard linklater movies; in this he explores a young boy's growth into young adulthood. i really enjoyed seeing the cast actually age 12 years (the film was shot over a 12 year period with the same cast). i've always thought linklater is one of the most philosophical filmmakers out there and this certainly is quite a meditation on time and how we  passing thru it.
A pretty good film. Surprisingly chill but probably a film you watch just once.

This movie feels more than just a movie it is someone's life unfolding before our eyes and it is flashing before us. It's just like when parents say that you are growing up so fast, and they mean it! Also the filming locations especially the one in the last minutes were amazing. Will remember this one for a long time.
Long boring and no point! Didn't get it! Sorry I lost 2hours and 45 minutes of my life on it.

People are taking about novelty of 12 year epic. Did they forget Forest Gump? Forrest Gump portrayed such a beautiful love. The lifelong events like Vietnam war were depicted in such a beautiful way. This one .. no emotions or not such any beautiful things. It's just boring as watching paint dry.  And when comparing the acting of Tom Hanks in Forrest Gump to this. Come on.

The whole movie I was waiting to understand the whole point of it; the message that was trying to be conveyed but I concluded that it simply represents a realistic life many people who grew up in at the start of the 21st century. I think it is interesting how the film was made over the course of twelve years, capturing the growth of the main actors. But that is where my interest unfortunately ends; I found the film overall to be empty and the acting mediocre. This is obviously my honest opinion which many, due to its high praise, will disagree. You should watch it so that you can develop your own opinion!

Boring. The movie was excruciatingly long with nothing interesting in Mason's life to deserve my time and attention. There were no major events, just mediocre moments that were more life changing for his mom than him. He wasn't a very interesting person in general.

Impressive on its technical merits alone (it took more than a decade filming with the same actors), this literal coming-of-age film can be cliche and stereotypical at times, but that's what lends it the unique, and generic, childhood that most anyone can associate with. Don't let the 3-hour runtime scare you away: a lot of moments compose the process of growing up.

I watched this movie last night (before it won Best Picture at the Golden Globes this evening) and I have to say I was mesmerized. There has never been a movie of this scope (filmed over 12 years) yet so intimate at the same time. It's a film that celebrates not just the big moments in a child's life (such as high school graduation) but more so the fleeting moments (like being passed a note from the cute girl in school). This film celebrates those moments interweaving and becoming the fabric of a boy's life.  The movie is less "plot-driven" and more "memory-driven". I think anybody (not just boys) who's ever been a child and had a family will find something to relate to. Highly recommended.

Think they lost the direction of the movie. I'm sure it's easy to do when you take 12 year to film something. While having a cast dedicate 12 year's to a film is impressive. That alone can not be the only basis of a movie. And clearly this film is dependent on just that.

This movie was a long, drawn out video scrapbook of a boy. If you like waiting to see the significance of a scene or continuity, this is not the film for you. Sub-par acting and cheesy scenes are throughout this movie. There is no point beyond watching the kid age throughout the film This is more popular for the novelty, rather than the acting skills and the story.

"Boyhood" is a  very special movie that brought to life the constant agony of time and how awfully fast it flies as well as how well it is connected with change.Not a perfect picture still a very important one.

Maybe I didn't get it?  Separating the technological achievement of filming a movie over 12 years from the story it portrays leaves a fairly straight forward coming of age story.  It's the kind of movie that's done frequently - just with different actors in the lead role.  This time around, the nature of the movie's construction actually makes it a little harder to follow - even if what is seen is more intimate and real than what is normally seen.  It's good.  I just didn't think it was "best of the year" good.

I enjoyed it overall, but I felt the ending was very abrupt and I really wanted a little more resolution than they gave.  I also wasn't floored by the performance of Ellar Coltrane, who plays the main kid, Mason.  He breaks out of his shell in the 2nd half in the movie, and that's when he starts to shine.  The nature of the way they shot this (1 week a year for the past 12 years) really made it interesting to see the kids grow up as the movie progressed, though since they cover so much time, it almost felt disjointed at times, because storylines are abruptly resolved and/or dropped at a moment's notice.  It's not the worst thing in the world, I just think it made me realize how I like a fully contained story and not an open-ended story.  It works sometimes (like the ending of 'Inception'), but in this case, I really wanted to know how things ended up with all the characters stories, though, as my wife points out. that would make for a very long movie unless they made it a montage. I'll be interested to see how it stands up against the other Best Picture nominees in the coming weeks.

So much nostalgia. I thought it was a beautiful set up and such an intriguing concept. It was quite long and yet I was left feeling both empty and fill knowing I'd watched the beginning of a life go by. 
(In many ways a mirror of my own.) 
Strange to watch as I approach my graduation (albeit of my undergraduate degree).

"You know how everyone's always saying seize the moment? I don't know, I'm kind of thinking it's the other way around, you know, like the moment seizes us."

"Boyhood" is a rare example of  a director taking on a very ambitious project and succeeding. The sheer scope of the film is like nothing I have ever seen before, 12 years is a long time to complete a film. Richard Linklater's script is extremely personal and dialogue was very intimate. There was evidently great chemistry between the cast and each actor seemingly pulled off one of their best performances. In addition to the writing and acting, one of the most fascinating concepts about the film was its use of pop culture. As the years went by, music, new stories, video games, and clothing, all changed. The intimacy of the relationships (through great acting), pop culture references, and Richard Linklater's excellent screenwriting make this one of the best films of 2014 and a film that is definitely worth watching.
Enjoyed following this family as they grew. Lengthy.

Boyhood is life itself. Filmed over a 12 year span, using the same central cast during that period, Boyhood is the closest thing to life itself. But even after the groundbreaking filmmaking technique, Boyhood is much more than that. Not much really happens in this film, but that's the point. This film isn't supposed to have some spectacular plot with many twists. This film only shows the little things that happen in life that end up being important. The performances from the cast range from great to not so great, but that's okay. Ellar Coltrane is our vehicle through this lifespan, and he gives a remarkable performance considering he was hired at such a young age. Boyhood is such a wonderful experience to sit through. It makes us reflect on our own past experiences in life, what helped shaped who we are. So all in all, Boyhood is a masterpiece. A groundbreaking look at life, with great writing and great performances from Ellar Coltrane, Ethan Hawke, and especially Patricia Arquette. We don't seize the moment, the moment seizes us, just like this film seizes you from start to finish.
Amazing, beautiful, and joyful boyhood is a one-in-a-lifetime
Sofa king awesome. Maybe the best coming of age films I've ever seen. It's definitely making me think about myself as a father.
not just an amazing accomplishment, but an amazing movie.

Yes.. it's innovative. Too bad there wasn't a story that entertains or educates us along the way. Dysfunctional family, divorce, remarry, divorce, remarry and then divorce again. That's the mother and the father is half way stable with some good advice to his son but he's in and out of his life on weekends. There isn't much to take away from the story or the acting .. the only take away is how novel it was to film the movie over 12 years.
Pretty good...not great

I've always loved everything Linklater's involved with, esp Waking Life, Scanner Darkly n School of Rock. this movie however....is amazing! the fact that it was preconceived n filmed over 45 days across 12+ years....is mind boggling! A pure display of time lapse, change and coping within the "American Dream". long...but, I enjoyed it
A revolutionary movie that pushes the boundaries of realism and breaks all of the rules.

Boyhood is definitely up for a couple of academy awards this season with his portrayal of raising children of the millennial generation. From Harry Potter to smartphones, this film covers major milestones of a boy from 1st grade to college. It embraces life.
"You know how everyone's always saying seize the moment? I don't know, I'm kind of thinking it's the other way around, you know, like the moment seizes us"
Aleppo - Jan - 2015.

I'm glad to see I'm not the only reviewer left wondering what this film is about... if it was a documentary, it might make more sense, but somebody actually scripted a basically normal boring family doing basically normal stuff over a 12 yr period.  Why?  Why call it Boyhood?  Each character was followed, the weirdest being the narcissistic low self esteem mom.  Should have been titled S.S.D.D.

I was reluctant to see this movie. I felt that the shot-in-real-time aspect was just a gimmick Linklater was using to disguise the fact that he wanted to make a movie that was thoroughly unremarkable in every other way. After finally seeing Boyhood last night, I feel that I was right. I seriously wonder if this movie would get the kind of attention and awards-buzz it has been getting if nobody knew about the unique shooting schedule. Without that, Boyhood is a long, largely uneventful, wholly unoriginal coming of age story, spiced up with some cliches about adolescence and poor acting from its younger cast members. Definitely not one of the movies that really resonated with me this awards season, though, judging by the glowing reviews from practically everyone else who has seen it, I fear it will take home the gold over other and (in my opinion) better movies.

Boyhood is a unique film that is intended to take you on a journey of growth and life and it does just that. It's realistic and honest portrayal of its characters their many flaws as they navigate the complexities of growing up, growing close and growing apart parallels many of our own struggles, thoughts and actions and the consequences for our choices.
One of the best movies I have ever seen. An absolute must-see for everybody. B R I L L I A N T.

An undoubtadely unique film as you actually see the cast grow older over the 12 years it was filmed. An ambitious project but was it worth it in the end? Sadly not. The storyline simply wasn't as ambitious as the project itself. I wonder how many other projects like this Linklater has in progress, it seems to be his niche. I didn't know what else he'd done before watching this but as I realised what was going on I instantly recognised he must be the same bloke who did Before Sunrise etc.
Fascinating trip through time but hated the main character. Not a role model at all.

Amazingly well done. I think almost if not every boy has experienced some of these things in this movie. Nothing like this has been done in the history of cinema. Very unique, very interesting, very relatable, a masterpiece.

Honestly, this movie is boring. I think critics like it because they like the liberal values portrayed. I didn't care much for any of the "Before" movies either. Too talky. This isn't Tennessee Williams-level of writing here. It's a lot of navel-gazing and blathering. Skip it.

What was the point?  About the only thing that was impressive was they were able to keep the same actors throughout the 12 years of filming.  Big deal.  Otherwise it was about the effects of a young woman's poor decisions on her kids.  Oh yes, and a vehicle for Ethan Hawke's political views.  And by the way Mr. Hawke, a bible-believing Christian  a gun-toting, intolerant bigot!
Interesting concept with a boring plot. If only this film meant something more than "the one where they used the same actors over 12 years"

The most over-rated home movie EVER. 
Take away the gimmick of seeing a kid grow up on film- it is a film replete with GAWD AWFUL performances. Led by the director's daughter, who apparently begged wisely to be killed out of the project.
Any scene with Ethan Hawke is totally worth watching but he is only in about a quarter of the movie. 
I can not understand why anyone thinks this is awards worthy movie except for overly impressed film makers

Unlike Linklater's masterpieces Before Sunrise and Before Sunset, this is just a boring exercise in watching grass grow.  Hugely disappointing. Why all the hype?  The boy is uninteresting and uninvolved. The only interesting character was the self absorbed mother who makes one bad choice after another in men.

A movie about life. The characters grow before your eyes and you begin to care for them as they evolve. Their interactions are so interesting they might as well be family, and you're confused yourself why it's so damned interesting. It's merely a movie about life. If you love life, you'll love this movie. The care and craft that was surely placed into this movie amount to 3 hours of my life I would never give back.
One of the best movies I've seen in a long time. Imaginative and extremely creative.

Richard Linklater's Boyhood is a masterpiece. Pure simple and deep. It tells a story of growing up and the difficulties along the way. 

LIke any movie about life, Boyhood is practically plott-less. With large scale events taking place of many years. 

Being filmed over 12 years, you literally see the characters grow up right before your eyes. As they get older their personalities change and their view on the world changes.

Linklater's outstanding achievement is not only the best movie of the year, it is one of the best movies to come out this century.
One of the most boring, over-appreciated films I've seen.  No real plot and at least 90 minutes too long.  It was filmed in and around Austin, so that's cool.

Years ago I rented a movie called The Slaughterhouse Massacre and said it was the worst movie I had ever seen. Well, I just spent 2 hours and 45 minutes watching the new shittiest movie ever. God, what a waste of time.
This really stunk.  Something is really wrong with the reviews on Rotten Tomatoes.
I forgot myself and my own life. I was afraid to return to it after this movie's end.

A movie 12 years in the making. Same kids and cast. You're basically observing the progression of the human character from young to adult with notes similar to our lives. Not perfect, but an excellent film and Best Picture contender here. And all that nostalgia!

Amazing movie, is incredible how fast time goes by... I already feel old after watching this movie, but it also makes me think about what am I doing with my own life. And the music is awesome. Loved it.
This is my top movie of 2014.
An impressive feat of film-making....
Watched this with my brother and sister-in-law.

Disappointed in Linklater's Boyhood mainly because the narrative is so common, situations fairly mundane, and there's no true climax and resolution. In fact, there really are very few momentous dramatic scenes here, although I was always ready to welcome one.  After all, this isn't documentary film-making, but a 12-year character study where we enjoy the unique privilege of seeing performances actually filmed over the years.  Linklater merely glosses over key phases of lead character Mason's child and teen years and keeps everything rather sanitized. We rarely see Mason behind closed doors and instead accompany him in frequent family car trips, restaurant work, hanging with friends, and very unwild parties. The only character expressing natural angst is Mason's mother Olivia portrayed deftly but not Oscar-worthy by Patricia Arquette and that's really only in two particularly notable scenes. Ethan Hawke is a welcome energetic ingredient whenever he appears which isn't often enough. Unless another filmmaker can incorporate all the important cinematic story  elements in a time narrative shot in actual time over years, this effort may not merit repeating.

This movie bored me to sleep
I can't believe I watch almost all of it skipping the last painful dreadfully boring making a person wanting to commit Suicide .
1 star is too much for this piece of crap .
Fascinating to watch people grow up on film over 12 years. Ended on a vague but positive note.
Inexplicable in its premise but sublime in its execution, Richard Linklater's "Boyhood" is a coming of age film like we've never seen before and, quite possibly, never will again.

This movie sucks. I just don't care. The only thing this movie has going for it is the concept. I respect that. I respect that no other movie has really done something like this. I just don't give a crap. The story just has no pull and no punch for me. I got nothing out of it. You know what the problem about showing someone's life is? Life. Is. Boring. This kid has a pretty normal life, no better or worse than the average American. So...do something. Say something. This movie was just a study and presentation of this kid's life from boyhood to college. Great. So what? Why should I care? I feel like if you're going to do something like shooting a movie as your actors age over many years, why do something so mundane? I know not every movie has to have some big profound point or message. Just, make me care. Let me enjoy the journey. Here's the couple things I did like. I kind of liked how the pop music let you know when you were exactly. And I liked that scene at the end where the mom broke down and gave this profound speech about life and feeling like she always thought there would be more. Maybe that's the point? I dunno. Once again, Linklater proves his great observational powers in this excellent, sensitive contemporary coming of age story. At first, the begins, as most of his do, in a very banal manner. Then, the characters grow, literally in this case, as they actors themselves are aging. I cried started crying near the end, when the Mother sadly admits, head down, "I thought there would be more!" This is such heartwarming story, perhaps all of us can identify in some way, especially parents, but I also identified strongly with Mason, as I am a lot like him. This is a must-see for every teenager, especially. So real! So honest.
12 years to make to tell a story about family and growing up, Boyhood is a true masterpiece.

Boyhood is obviously a great film with great acting and a great story, however the lead is too generic and practically has no identity. The supporting characters and dilemmas make the film shine, not the lead. It may be great, but not film of the year,

Although the idea of a movie directed over 12 years so that we can watch as the actors, and thus their characters, mature in front of our very eyes sounds like a good idea, it seems the concept was produced by the wrong hands.  

Other than the fact there was no story arc, the portrayal of the characters political viewpoint and the directors stereotyping of the personas and issues they biasedly framed showed the childishly flat thinking of the director  tended to ostracize tat least some of us who had came to see a coming of age story only to come into contact with propaganda.

We're not masochists who enjoy paying to be insulted.

I've been watching films for a very long time, and I must say I don't get why this film is getting rave reviews.

The film is called Boyhood, but after 3 hours of watching I haven't got the slightest clue about what makes Mason tick. He likes to take pictures. That's it! Hopes, dreams, thoughts? Nope. He's a blank.

The mother, on the other hand, is a complete narcissist. She doesn't seem to give a flying crap about the happiness of her children. It's all about what she wants at any given point of her life. I mean, jesus, she abandons her 2 step children that her own kids have bonded with to an abusive drunk without ever looking back once!

Ethan Hawke was a good dad. He actually talked to his kids and seemed to care about their well being. You don't get to see why he left, but I got the impression that he was driven away by the psychotic mother.

It's a film that you think about afterwards, but for me I just seem to get more irritated about the characters the more I think,

Great job staying in the character for all those years. I found the movie depressing at some points, but I guess it is the life (?) Definitely interesting way of filming, felt like watching someone's private footage.

This movie was boring from beginning to end.  I'm sorry that I wasted two and a half hours of my life watching it.  Although it was an interesting concept to use the same cast over the 12 years of filming,  there was no plot, no story really but following a boy, with no charisma and no personality supposedly growing up in a broken family.  The movie contained nothing that was thought provoking. I thought they would at least throw in some teenage dilemmas.  I want a movie that is witty or clever or gives me something to think about.
