most overrated movie this year.  really a gimmick movie.

Audiences love boyhood because apparently they've never sat through hours and hours of directionless student films.  Long, self-indulgent, low stakes, meandering tomes, tripping over the barren landscape of anti-establishment views.  Hours and hours and hours of them.  They're as common as cat hairballs.  

So when a movie comes along like Boyhood that has mainstream exposure and an underdog indie feel, suddenly every hipster who's been weaned on Transformers and Captain America is just gaga over the slow-paced anti-establishment setting in Boyhood.  Underneath the crunchy coating of the age progression device, and the intentionally deadly lack of pacing, there's nothing here.  And by nothing, I mean nothing.  No stakes, no emotion, no strong character, no gorgeous stage pictures, no action.

The device of age progression is a gimmick, and could have made this film profound.  But instead, we're met with a lead character who lacks ambition, and lacks any solid point of view that spurs him to action or self discovery or inner battle. The character has no special language, no unique diction.  His vocabulary is that of a hamburger.   It's like watching paint dry-- a paint that doesn't care if it dries or not.  And who wants to pay 16 bucks to see that?

When the acting is wooden and self-conscious, it's lifeless and without emotion.  Hours of it.  Hours and hours and hours of just sitting around watching a kid make observations about the world.  That's not film.  Film is the culled essence of human drama.  If you want to see real time age progression, look up a live cemetery cam.

The first lesson in student film-making is stakes.  The stakes have to be high, or else why are we watching this art rather than experiencing our own lives? What is special about our watching this film that is a profoundly universal experience?  Age progression?  And why does that have to take two and a half hours?

A confused, plodding, drama-free student film at best.  Avoid.
Great coming of age film.  It reminded me of a lot of stuff that happened when I grew up.
one of the best '14 films a little longer but totally engaging

Boyhood follows a young boy from Texas and his family over the course of 12 years. The plotline can be summed up in the popular phrase and becomes this simple thesis of: "Remember the small things in life, they are, in fact, the big things." There are a couple moments in this film where people are driving, especially where Mason took a short glance at an iPhone screen that I started to clutch at a little. Like, "Oh my gosh is he gonna have an accident? Is he gonna veer off the road?" But this isn't a car-crash movie. Nothing necessarily "big" ever happens in this movie. In the 3 hour-running time. Nothing convulsive or earth-shattering. Yet I related to almost everything that happened in this movie because I either knew Mason or I was Mason. Because it's about real life and it feels like real life. You are experiencing the growth and formation of this kid from a firsthand account. We see the day-to-day crises and annoyances and even the dynamics of self-discovery and satisfaction. We see his family continually having bolts break loose, boards pried off, and ultimately fail to keep the structure from collapsing, which, my gosh, was so well-directed, especially the 2nd husband sequence. We see Mason and are fascinated by the fast-flow of him taking his first slice of life from the pan and him struggling to forge ahead in this world and settle into a groove. We see the sands of time trickling through the hourglass. Also the dangling plot threads were brilliant. Showing how some things in life don't get resolutions, and how loose ends don't always get tied up. It's a stomach-hollowing soul-stirring heartwarming narrative. This earns a spot in my pantheon of films. Amazing piece of artwork and amazing that it was able to be pulled off and pulled together. The making and composition of this film is to worthy of all praise. The rock-solid casting, the cut and dry editing, the overall production value. All the stars aligned literally and this holy trinity of actors, Coltrain, Hawke, and Arquette, really springs the movie to life as it really were.
this movie was awful!  I rented it based on the reviews. nothing happened in this movie. I was waiting. but nothing. I was very disappointed.

Was hoping to write up a longer review, but never found the time back when I watched it. Honestly it's a hard film to sort out my opinion toward, much of what resonated about it with me came from personal familiarity with the period the story depicts growing up in. There were some hints at broader questions of patenting styles impacting children, and gender socialization. I found the boy at the center of the story fairly unlikeable, not sure if it's something I'd count against the film, perhaps I saw some of my worst tendencies at those ages taken further in him. I absolutely despised the soundtrack, but maybe it fit with that part of America? Some of the characters' overt philosophizing felt shallow and pompous, but in a way might play as how some would approach life in their own way. The use of the same actors over the decade of filming could play as a needless gimmick, I found it weirdly effective at creating a sense of the characters at the mercy of time.

I guess all reviews are based on our subjective opinions in regards to movies and like media. All the men in the mothers life were conservative men who provided but who were drunks or abusive to her and her kids. Even the neighbor who the boy solicited an Obama vote from threatened to shoot the kid if he came back on the property...I mean really? How incredibly stupid
! You didn't have to be socio-politically in tune to realize the irony or the negative slant. The movie just sucked and was a waste of three and a half hours of my life. In the end he grew up well loved by his sister and his Mom... But he also ended up a looser! Pointed out by his last step father...who more or less called him an ardent mumbling, soft spoken directionless liberal who could come and go anytime he pleased at his mother's blessing. I guess it's a testament on how to bring your kids up these days. 
It was just aweful your going to love it otherwise I recommend you stay away and keep your money.

A warm, poignant coming-of-age film, remarkable for its fluidity and embrace of the viewer.  Director Richard Linklater does something amazing in filming the same cast (under no contract!) for 12 years.  That feat alone is interesting, but he also gives us an indelible film in the process.  Following a young boy's life as he endures streams of advice from adults and the gentle annoyance of his sister, the movie serves us relatable situations at every turn.  Even something as mundane as putting mustard on a hot dog takes on deeper meaning in Linklater's capable hands.  He elicits natural, deeply affecting performances from his actors (Patricia Arquette alone should win awards for aging gracefully). It's often said that Linklater films aren't about anything, but I left with the sense that I'd seen something transcendent; a film not about any one thing, but about all the things we've experienced as we transition to adulthood, and how rooted in love and loss that journey can be, on our way to boundless opportunity.
Loved this movie. Pretty long, but very well worth it.

An absolute masterpiece. Wonderful talented cast.A movie like life itself: a string of happenings and incidents. Of love, hurt and loss. Of new beginnings and endings. Of dreams not come true and dreams come true.

I can certainly appreciate the technical aspect of the filmmaking and can appreciate the power of devotion necessary to work on the same project for such an extended period of time. Groundbreaking indeed and a wonderful coming of age story but Boyhood is ultimately successful because it is a story about life. The largely ordinary and common life of a boy and his family struggling through the things we all struggle through. In capturing this story, we are reminded of just how extraordinary our ordinary lives really are.
Not surprisingly, I loved this--but there could have been a few cuts.

It really feels that everyone's opinions are completely overshadowed by the pretty incredible achievement of being filmed over 12 years with the same principle cast.Â 


The reality is that the story really isn't that interesting nor profound. Linklater himself admitted he didn't really have an end goal, and instead treated it as a making a short film every year and stitching them together In post, and it's completely obvious with themes brought up and dropped
, characters with no resolution (his own daughter wanted out after 5 years) and no real point or message, except that "life happens".Â 

It's by no means a bad movie... It definitely has a certain charm to it. But it's really not that good either, if you don't consider the circumstances as to how it was made.Â
If you've been part of any family unit in the last 2 decades, no matter what age or gender, there is something you can take away from Boyhood that will stick with you forever.

What went into this film is astounding. 12 years following and filming the same actors, by one of my favorite directors, Richard Linklater. The movie's length does make it feel like a life being lived, even if sometimes it seems like Mason, the lead character, is growing up a little too fast. But that's probably what his parents are seeing: their little boy going from age 6 to 18 in seemingly under 3 hours. It's a good way of showing the passing of time. The soundtrack is incredible, featuring songs from Coldplay, Wilco, Arcade Fire, The Black Keys, The Flaming Lips, and more. Linklater uses these songs to let you know what year it is in the movie, which I thought was really clever. The film is beautifully shot, and there's nostalgia everywhere, like that little digital 20 Questions game, and the brother and sister peeking out to watch their parents fight (who hasn't done that as a kid?). Like most Linklater movies, the plot is pretty simple. It's just this family, living their lives, Mason and his sister growing up, their mother going through husband after husband, Mason and his sister visiting their father on weekends, etc. Because of this, it may underwhelm you with the amazing reviews it has been getting. And I must admit, when it ended, I said, "That's it?" But honestly, this film is an experience like that. It's just lives being lived, and for that, I commend it. I also commend it for all the work and love put into it. There truly has never been a film out there like this one, even though I feel like the concept behind it is more interesting than the execution. Overall, I definitely recommend it because you'll get a great soundtrack, good characters, some conflict, and some nostalgia. Just don't expect it to blow you away.

Boyhood maybe one of the most captivating films I have seen all year. It is very interesting because you watch a family grow up right before your eyes. I have never seen anything like this before. 

As I mentioned above I was fascinated with the way this film was shot. The film never tells you what the current year is in the story so you have to judge based on the families appearance and what is going on. Even though no one spelled it out for me, based on the way the boy looked I could tell when a year had passed. It 's so funny that I was sucked into this film because there really wasn't an overall plot. It is just about life. Normal human actions and reactions. That is it. I loved the story and the way it progressed until the last 20 minutes but then it started to drag. That says a lot for this movie because it is almost 3 hours long and I never felt the time till the last 20 minutes. The acting in the film isn't amazing by any standards but that didn't matter. I applaud Richard Linklater (director) on his ability and perseverance to film this over 12 years. After 12 years of hard work going into this film, I can honestly say watching this movie was a very unique experience. I would recommend watching this movie if you want to see something different.

I take a big gulp as I move up the staircase to a large platform. A bead of sweat descends from my forehead. With a dry mouth I attempt to speak. The crowd finally quieten to a deadly silence. I'm being stared at by piercing eyes.

Finally a noise...

"I didn't like Boyhood", I croak. 

An audible intake of breath emanates from the throng. Then a pause as I stare at the open mouthed pack.

There. I said it.

I'm not taking this solitary position lightly. It's not an intentional contrarian view. Going against the grain for the sake of exposure. I genuinely did not enjoy Linklater's much lauded latest release and I'll tell you why.

I'm sure you know the story by now. The film follows the childhood of one particular American boy called Mason and although fictional, the director spaced out his shooting so that the film actually spans 12 years of the actor's life and subsequently we see him physically changing and growing on screen from sequence to sequence.

From the opening spiralling shot of a young boy on grass to the final teenager at college, Linklater follows the whole family - Mason himself (played by Ellar Coltrane), his sister Olivia Patricia (the director's daughter Lorelei Linklater) and the estranged parents Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke - all of whom grow old along with the protagonist. And that's essentially it.

"Boyhood began filming without a completed script". That fact alone tells you everything about this film. As Mason grew up, my interest faded as the film slowly descending into an absolute entertainment vacuum. The conflict and clashing needed to build the tension that is so crucial to drama was absent and without it, the film is just a documentary. And what a boring one at that.

I began to ask myself why there was so much absent - the adventure, the unknown, friends (where the fuck are those important relationships made during these years?), excitement, laughter, games and most important fun - before adult foibles become an inevitable necessity.  We end up just looking at the life of a child almost through an adult prism - all the seriousness of it and that alone.

As Mason grows, the child actor slowly becomes a new Hayden Christensen - a charisma void of a lead and too much of "I did this thing the other day" telling rather than showing the audience what has happened in his life. Like George Lucas, who simply placed people in rooms to talk about (the more exciting) things they had done, Linklater mismanages the balancing act of visuals, narrative, construction, plot and drama. For me, it's all construction here which takes you from the film completely. I found myself thinking I wonder if they kept the car all these years between takes. If I was worrying about that then I feel that the moviemaker had not captivated this audience member at all.

I'm not heartless but sadly felt no emotional connection with the characters (the sister is clearly the character we should be following) and although it is a controversial position, I suppose there was always going to be one great film I was going to stand in contrast with.

From  Russell Maloney (New Yorker) who said The Wizard of Oz was "a stinkeroo", to Pauline Kael's (Harper's) scathing attack on The Graduate: "Mike Nichols' 'gift' is that be lets the audience direct him; this is demagoguery in the arts," there are lauded movies that will always not connect for one reason or another with critics. Infamous contrarian Armond White said that Spike Lee's Malcolm X had "no formal innovations or controversial content....Let the mourning begin" and I guess this film was not the one for me.

Aside from the unique conceit of being filmed over 12 years, I really got the sense that there's not much here. I'd argue if this film was simply recast at ages 8, 12 and 16 I doubt I would have given the whole thing a second glance and not have noticed much of a difference too.

A bold and daring experiment but so is the documentary "7 Up" which has followed people every 7 years for over 50 years and whose protagonists, again, have much more interesting lives.

And nostalgia? The film presents precisely the opposite. No warmly (and maybe falsely) remembered childhood events. Almost no events at all. Linklater removes the nostalgia factor but also removes anything memorable at all. Did Mason have any part of his life worth remembering? Looking back on my own boyhood, I had a "regular" upbringing but I don't recall it being anything like this. I know the eras are different but for a film about time I felt that the characters barely moved on at all in their lives and it certainly wasn't fun in the sense I know the word. 12 years worth of footage and this was the most interesting cut they could put together?

If I was this kid I'd be as depressed as he is towards the end. His life is dull. Duller than most peoples' actual lives. And that's the problem. Turn it off and go and spend some time with your kids. Or with your family. Or with someone else's kids. 

Maybe I'll be accused of missing the subtleness. This is a gentler affair with an unobtrusive camera they'll say. Far from subtle, these shots of technology are heavy handed (we can already see the passing of time on the casts faces) so every shot of different technology wasn't needed. It should have been background. In addition, I'm not against Linklater or his experiments either. The rotoscoping in the strange sci-fi A Scanner Darkly is a brilliantly weird interpretation of the Phillip K Dick novella whilst his "Before..." series is a stunning look at relationships over time as well as trying his hand at commercial comedies ("School of Rock") and interesting adaptations ("Fast Food Nation") which all show his vast array of talents.

But this didn't work for me. It was just so mind-numbingly dull. They say some films reflect what you yourself bring to it. I brought an exciting childhood with me and left with the memory of a dreary and tedious one. I enjoyed my boyhood, I didn't enjoy this.

6/10

Interesting, if for no other reason than the scope and patience of its making.  A tale of family that's so real it feels as though you're glimpsing past the filmmaking industry and into a real American dinner table.

Simply, just a story of a boy's childhood; told in visual snapshots as he grows into young adulthood.

Simply, a master class in cinematic storytelling.  A masterpiece in its own right.
Completely new and amazing experience watching characters age and develop over 12 years. Must have been a real challenge to film this.

Nomadic. Broken home childhood carved into the young's mind makes way who he is. An artist, exceptional in sights and perception earning his scholarship excelling his fellow class mates. Hence which comes to more exceptional technique of this 12 years filming of the same actor and actress. 

To the soundtrack comes the 90's hit of Coldplay's "Yellow" to the more recent Charlie Sexton's "The Dog Song", setting up ambience appropriate to the era the boy lived. Not as good as the filming technique, but adequate to fill the mood.

Family is what paint us in early years, that engraved in our mind up until the moment we depart this world. Cherish it how awful they are, for we can't choose to whom we are borned into but evidently we can choose to love them.
A movie made in real time as you watch the actors aging. Amazing.

Such an epic movie! Boyhood takes us through Mason's life as a child, the struggles of a teenager and the decisions of a college student. Never felt  so attached to a performance. To watch the cast grow before our eyes in 11 years is truly phenomal in any cinematic technique.

This slice-of-life narrative is more like the whole pie, spanning 12 years in the life of Mason, a thoughtful, and intriguing young man.  Director Linklater has really out done himself here, with the help of a realistic lead, supported by Hawke and Arquette, giving honest performances all around.  It truly is a sweeping and intimate epic that feels so relate-able, so personal, the fact that nothing really happens is the most insignificant of quibbles. It's honest acknowledgement of life, childhood, family, and all the moments that bind it together, allows the film to not be a slave to its own technical gimmick.

Bravo, Linklater. Another amazing experiment works wonderful cinematically. Probably the director that speaks most personally to me (with the "Before" series above all), Linklater has crafted a beautiful and great coming-of-age movie. It reminds me of a more grounded The Tree of Life. Linklater turned out to be so lucky in casting Ellar Coltrane, he grows up before our eyes, and in his growing up reveals at the very least a competent actor and not a disaster this movie could have been. Ethan Hawke gives a very natural performance as well, but it's Patricia Arquette and her character that really gets to take hold of the film here. Her, Hawke, and Coltran all feel remarkably like real people; the dialogue flows so well you'd think most of it was improved conversations (apparently the vast majority was scripted). Also, the editing is seamless, really well done. Some really wonderful and memorable moments/scenes within as well. I hope Boyhood helps to cement Linklater's reputation as one of America's best directors.

It's a cool film. It kind of just coasts along on it's fascinating concept. There's no real plot, or twists or turns (it's not even really a movie, maybe the word would be experimental film). We just sit and watch this one boy grow up all while he tries to figure out who he is. It's an interesting film, but it's incredibly long (exactly as long as Transformers 4) and it definitely drags a good deal. It's worth at least one watch if you're curious, and it's crazy to look at this kid at the end of the film and think that it's been the same actor since second one (we literally watch him grow up, pretty crazy). Boyhood is a unique film, I'm glad I got to watch it and it's certainly one of the better films of 2014 (although there are some films I can think of that are definitely better than this). I definitely liked it, I just didn't love it.

I can certainly appreciate that Boyhood was a tremendous undertaking, and that writer/ director Richard Linklater dedicated a large portion of the last decade to it's being made. Never before have we been able to follow the lives of a small cast of characters like this.  Yet somehow... this feels like a been there and done that affair. There's no question that these people feel lived in, but they're also mostly conventional cutouts. The single mom who struggles with the drunk and abusive husbands, the siblings who are forced to deal with the multiple changes of scenery, and the father who can't fess up to his shortcomings. Don't get me wrong, these actors are good here (and quite convincing), but there's nothing in the writing that makes them stand out as unique individuals. I can relate to a lot of what Mason (Ellar Coltrane) goes through, and I have a hunch that most of us can. The story is a familiar one, albeit expanded upon, and it forgoes inventiveness for plain old cliche. Conveniently, the moment Mason arrives at college- he is immediately thrust into eating acid laced candies and meeting the girl of his dreams.. or at least the girl of the semester. Boyhood is a nifty achievement, I only wish that the characters had more interesting lives.

Boyhood is a remarkable and special film that breaks cinema convention not only thanks to its unorthodox shooting schedule but because of its incredibly accurate depiction of life. It uses the same actors to shape about a 12-year stretch in the life of a young boy who grows into maturity through a collection of what amounts to snapshots of his life, from elementary school to the beginning of his college career and life as an adult. It's incredibly consistent in tone and performance, an amazing accomplishment considering the on-and-off approach to the shoot. The film proves that there's still room for the cinema medium to grow beyond the tired constraints to which the industry far too often, and far too closely, adheres. If all is right in the world, Boyhood should walk away from the 87th Academy Awards as the night's big winner.
An amazing cinematic achievement filled with a rich, nostalgic story. My generation was allowed to grow up immediately at the end credits.

"Boyhood" has to be the most realistic movie ever made. Granted the movie is nearly 3 hours in run time and drags a bit in the first half, nothing has ever been done like this before. From domestic family issues, first relationships, and first discovering alcohol and drugs as a teen, there is something everyone can relate to. The soundtrack ranges from when the film first started filming 12 years ago to now which is nostalgic and clues the audience to which year the film is in at the time. If you think about it, Richard Linklater is one of the great innovators of film. And it's 2014's Boyhood, a film merely about a young man's life from age 5 to 18, that is the pinnacle of his career, and a stark reminder of the limit-shattering effect the medium of cinema is capable of. Filmed a couple days a year over the course of 12 years, Boyhood both molds together the years with seamless flow and scripts the story so deeply that the "ordinary" content sucks you completely into the story. The content is such that the harder you concentrate and the deeper you dig, the more ability you release from the film, which in turn allows you to get more from yourself. It's a hugely addictive and thoroughly enjoyable process. Epic in technical scale but breathlessly intimate in narrative scope, Boyhood's ambition is matched by its emotional resonance and relatablity. This isn't just one of the greatest films ever. This is us.

That being said I still think the first half is strong enough to recommend this movie as a whole and while I won't watch it a second time, I will still be talking about this movie for years to come.

The issue with Boyhood is that it has nothing interesting to say. Linklater presents us with the average American childhood that we are all familiar with. There's nothing fresh here. A remarkable coming of age story that is shot through the 12 years span. Yes, director Richard Linklater shot the same actors over the several years, as we see them progress and age. The story felt like an experimental of watching a six year old Mason (Ellar Coltrane) and his older sister Samantha (Lorelei Linklater) and their single mother Olivia (Patricia Arquette). Every now and then, there father comes to visit Mason Sr. (Ethan Hawke). The movie follows this young boy, as we watch him through these realistic events that occurs as a family. The movie had realistic thematic materials from Masons mother and her kids moving frequently as she goes back to school and locating a job. Evantually, Olivia gets remarried to her former professor as the two blend their families together. Olivias husband falls back to his alcoholism and abusiveness. All these situations are realistic enough that some are able to relate or notice people in these life situations. The movie follows Mason from his childhood to his adolescence. These transitions all have that nostalgic feel. The best thing about the movie is Richard Linklater kept the same casts. Yes, we see Ellar Coltrane, Patricia Arquette, Lorelei Linklater, and Ethan Hawke all age through the years. They all give outstanding performances. 

The movie is lengthy but flows smoothly and has that emotional impact with the characters. We see Mason as he grows and tries to discover himself in his teen years. Boyhood is a very impressive coming of age drama film that is well put together.
Warm, comfortable, passionate. All that you would expect from a Linklater long-term project. Sublime.

With the combined powers of superb acting, genius writing, and masterful directing, Richard Linklater delivers to the screen the best movie of his career. The story follows the life of Mason (Ellar Coltrane), your average American boy, and his family. The concept of watching this kid and his family literally grow up before our eyes has truly captivated myself and others who have had the privilege of watching this film. The acting talent of Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke is unparalleled. Playing the divorced mother and father of Mason and his sister, Samantha, (played by newcomer Lorelei Linklater), Patricia and Ethan played their roles so well, I was convinced that these were their children, and that they were a divorced couple in real life. From losing and gaining jobs, to new girlfriends and getting remarried, they both perform with an effortless drive. This film draws the line between a fictional drama and reality. Almost every family in America has endured at least one moment that this movie projects. This film is nothing short of a masterpiece; it reminds us all of the times of growing up. Every emotion is touched with a profound grace, and is by far, the best drama of 2014.

At the risk this review turning into an angry rant, I'll keep it as brief as I can.  On one level - an experimental level - BOYHOOD is a fascinating film well worth experiencing... but on any other objective level, it is (at best) a mediocre examination of a family over a period of twelve years.  The script is (particularly in the second act) filled with the kind of navel gazing philosophizing that gets really grating really fast, and we're unfortunately saddled with a lead character (well, kinda; the movie's really more about the kid's parents, even if he's the centerpiece of it all) who grows to become the kind of pretentious, aimless, thinks-he's-cool-and-bucking-the-system, smug, drug-using teen jerk that I couldn't stand even when I was that age myself.  Now that's obviously me bringing my own baggage to the film, which I guess is partly unfair, but it's not helped by young Ellar Coltrane's performance; he actually becomes a worse actor as he gets older, which is kind of amazing, though some of that might be because the character himself gets more and more cipher-like and unlikable.  Indeed, I started the movie indifferent to the kid, and by the end I actively disliked him in a major way; I'd wager that's not the trajectory Linklater was intending an audience member would take away from the the film (if, on the very off-chance it was, then hat's off!).  Having said all that, the performances from Ethan Hawke and Patricia Arquette are both very good (Arquette, in particular, feels like the true heart of the movie), and there are a few individual moments that actually provoke emotion (there's a semi-lengthy sequence where the movie almost transforms into THE STEPFATHER for a bit), but in the final analysis the movie IS the gimmick.  It's a great gimmick, to be sure, but it never rises above that (for me, anyway); I wasn't on the film's wavelength from the start, and I didn't connect by the end, either.

Overrated movie to say the least. One star is for Ethan Hawke's performance because he saved this movie from being absolute trash, the other half star is for the beginning of this movie, because from the 45 minute mark on, the screenplay and the acting became less and less tolerable for me to watch. I was actually groaning and sighing in the theater from the pain I was feeling trying to watch these actors sell their roles like children selling candy bars to me for their class fundraiser! Coltrane is a cute kid actor but once he reaches his teens, you realize that he's awful at acting. Same thing goes for his sister in the movie. The dialogue gets cheesier as time goes on and before you know it, the last scene makes you want to burn your eyes out from how bad it was. "We don't seize the moment, the moment seizes us"-- what a try-hard-to-sound-deep-and-intellectual line! Cool idea for a movie, the 12-year thing, but that didn't save it.

Why did Linklater set his story in Texas when not one of the main cast had even a hint of a Texas accent?  They all sounded like actors trained in mid-Atlantic speech, coming off a Hollywood sound stage. These are supposed to be native Texans. Only Ethan Hawke's second wife's family have Texas accents and they are presented as gun-toting Bible-thumper stereotypes.

Boyhood is the cinematic achievement of the generation. Filmed over the course 12 years, it captures life through a lens, one of the simplest yet challenging things a filmmaker can accomplish. Every frame of this film held my eyes, and I instantly knew I was watching a classic. Many of you may oversee this post as just some guy flipping out about a flick. But I can't help but express this excitement. I love movies, they are my world into which I can escape into. And when I come across a film like Boyhood, I want to share that experience with others.

As amazing as it is to watch a family grow together over a 12 year period, this film serves only that as spectacle. Characters are bland, dialogue is uninspired (not to mention pretentious and nonsensical), and it panders to my generation harder than a "90's kid" Facebook post.
One of the best films that I have ever seen, nothing quite like it! Beautiful moments in the film that just gave me nostalgic feels!

I liked it, a lot, but I didn't love it.

Boyhood is a huge undertaking from Linklater that really has tiny scope, or even much depth. The acting is very good, especially from Coltrane, Arquette and Hawke but the moments in which they get to truly shine and be powerful are limited and fleeting.

I think casual cinema goers used to Transformers etc could view this whole experience as pretentious, and there's an argument in that. I viewed it as an interesting experiment in filmmaking and storytelling, but one that never quite achieves any profound results on either front.

All the hype and buzz led me to believe this could be a Best Picture winner, but I just don't see it happening. See it once, enjoy it's uplifting warmth and reference it in conversations about film-making.
Overrated, gimmicky, and understated all at once; unbelievably poignant in places if you can personally relate - I got chills.  Will be watching this one again.

We follow a boy (and his family) from age 6 to 18. The schools he attend, the houses, the people. The film, and the other characters, develops just as he does, naturally. There are loads of smaller moments here that will be remembered. Some amazing trivia behind this huge film as well. The fact that they filmed it for 11 years, with the same cast is exceptional - you can't get a better starting-point for a relistic growing up-tale, can you? Only 45 days of shooting did the trick though. Amazing.

The novelty of following the same characters over 12 years is really interesting and fun to watch. The story is pretty bare bones and therefore feels more real. I was entertained and it really makes you think about life.

I'm docking it points for opening with Coldplay's "Yellow" (I just hate that song) and the disorienting, music-way-too-in-the-foreground 10-minute wander that immediately follows, as well as the way that the ultra-realistic scenes occasionally linger too long in their reality; sometimes we could do with a less, and in all the movie gets a bit long. Otherwise, though: believe the hype. This is an ambitious film, over a decade in the making... and if you like anything Linklater, rest assured that this one's everything Linklater: the 90s, Austin, adolescence, what remains of the American dream, authentic conversations, the attempt to dispense with the BS of contemporary existence, and of course, romantic maturation. I'd call it a chef d'oeuvre from this film-maker, quite possibly the best film he'll ever make... though for our sake, and of course, his too, here's hoping he tops it next time out.

A really great film. But way too many people let the grand scope of the project overshadow an objective view of the film. There is some good and bad acting and various flaws to boot. Deserves nominations? Yes. Best pic of the year? Heck no.
Patricia Arquette definitely adds flavor to an overly simple, kind of slow, script.

The overall concepts within the story are plenty of things we've seen before, but it's to serve as a familiar as we enter this time-jumping realm. It's marvelous to see how this crazy project comes together, being a truly remarkable film...that falls a bit short due to a very abrupt end.
He did new things which people think to be impossible.  As a art, the new things did not deepen the meaning or value.

I don't even know how else to say it... It blows. Terrible movie. Yes cool they spent 12 years and used the same actors. That's what makes it worse. The most exciting part of the movie is a couple of drinken glass throws. That's really it. This movie sucks my ass.

OUTSTANDING!!!!! Richard Linklater is genius. In this poignant and thought provoking drama, Linklater uses the same actors over a 12 year period to show us the raw truth about our lives.  Exceptional performances from Patricia Arquette, Ethan Hawke and Ellar Coultrine, truly drive this film. This groundbreaking masterpiece is all summed up in one line... "You know how everyone's always saying seize the moment? I don't know, I'm kind of thinking it's the other way around, you know, like the moment seizes us".
Amazing on a technical scale.  Down to earth "real" story about ordinary people doing the best they can in life.  Patricia Arquette, Ethan Hawke were amazing.  Awesome directing.
Long. Somewhat boring. Ok

Boyhood, a coming-of-age story about a boy growing up from a young child to a college freshman, was a film I've been meaning to see for a long time (since it came out in 2014), and I'd figured I should see it now that I've graduated from polytechnic in May 2018. Now that I've seen it, I can understand why it's such. This is an excellent film. Maybe not the best picture of 2014, (from what I have seen, that'd be "Whiplash", followed by either "Birdman" or "The Grand Budapest Hotel") but it's still really good. No movies made me cry for a while until this. (although it was not on the part which Richard Linklater intended, as I was crying during the first act of the film when the protagonist was a child, rather than the ending) Similar to "Lady Bird", this is a very relatable film, detailing the struggles of a single-parented family and of a teenager's growing needs and wants. The acting is great too, particularly Patricia Arquette's, who won an Oscar for portraying the mother. However, it is a bit too long. (some of the high school sections could have been cut off, although it might be there to detail the story even further) All in all, Boyhood is a great film worthy of it's 100 Metacritic score, especially if you want to relieve your childhood and secondary school days. Light 9/10.
Great movie!!!  Incredible idea.
Incredible film. Not only for its acting and directing, but for seeing a film 12 years in the making make such a big impact in cinematic history.

A ground breaking concept executed to sheer perfection. 12 years in the making, this is the best movie of 2014: a reflection of family and friendship through the eyes of a boy who becomes an adult in front of our eyes. It will leave you speechless and filled with joy.
I Loved the concept of this film and I think people should check it out. It is a little long and at certain points slow but still something you should experience.

Boyhood....  Or is this real Lifehood?  The primary focus was indeed on Mason... But there are plenty of other characters at various stages of their life.  We watch a voyage over time and see the way life progresses around the son of a recently divorced mother.  We see the joys and sadness that many of us go through in our own lives.  Mind you 2 1/2 stars may seem low... But it is just a little plain and average movie...  Which I also believe is quite good given the high standards of Hollywood films.

Good - but not great. This will make an excellent film school movie, rife for debate, discussion & dissection. 
Sure, it got lots of hype for the technical and completely unorthodox attempt to tell a 12-year long story literally chronologically. . . but too many people who saw it couldn't relate to the characters or their lives. This won't be a movie up for general discussion by the movie-going public 20 years from now. 
That said, Patricia Arquette *was* THE heart & soul of that boy's life & story - and her Oscar win was so well-deserved!
Boyhood is a well-crafted and organized project that was cleverly directed, and with a help of its charismatic protagonist can raise the level of the interesting, powerful and realistic story.
Superb acting, and it's very interesting watching him grow up in front of you, yet this movie is nearly 3 hours long, and essentially you're just watching normal life, so it becomes a snoozer.

Such a great film. I've seen it three times and have loved every minute of it, all three times. The fact that the director started with a cast 12 years ago and continued with them throughout the whole film really makes the movie seem as if we're following the lives of a real family. Touches upon so many topics of adolescence and is incredibly relatable. A must see.

Long long long horribly boring movie. I had to watch it over three days because I could barely muster the energy to watch it. You couldn't pay me to watch this again. A big pass.
Absolutely fantastic, takes you through the life of Mason in a 12 year process, it feels as if you grow along with the characters and see the similarities of how many people have grown up.

This movie is a one-trick pony hungry for a plot. The trick is the obvious -- filming over a 12-year period. But other than watching an under-utilized cast of characters grow older, it's hard to find a reason to see it. The purported story line is so weak it's hard to state. This is basically about a young, directionless (surprise, surprise) boy grow into his later teen years, gaining some sense of what he wants to pursue in life. His parents, even more directionless, supposedly gain a bit of insight into what they want to make of themselves. And it's all a big, directionless yawn. An Oscar nominee for best movie? That's no more than a tip of the hat for the patience shown by director  and all key players to stick with a morass than many probably couldn't see coming, at leat not until it was too late. There was even some alarming talk that it would win. Thank Goodness the Academy didn't totally embarass itself. It's a shame that the most of the cast and crew couldn't save themselves.
This is like a very very long after school movie special.
an epic movie by linklater ... a mastepiece about life and growing up ... so moving and realistic ...

If the production history of this one-of-a-kind film seems at first like a gimmick, any concern fades as the experience of this coming-of-age-in-a-dysfunctional-family tale takes hold and never lets go. We marvel at the performance of a child who, before our very eyes becomes a young man. Yes, we wonder how much of this is "acting" and how much of the story is "scripted". I for one also found myself surprised over and over again at the transitions between years, which were seamless and often undetectable. None of this would matter, of course, if the story weren't touching, and as the response indicates, universal. These feel like real people in my life, people I want to know forever.

Tell me that over 12 years we could not come up with one interesting storyline.

-- Don't Waste Your Time

The film and story are so simple but watching these characters grow up on screen is something so magical you can't describe its beauty without witnessing it for yourself. At the end of the movie i felt like i had been with these characters far longer than the 2hrs and 45 mins this movie runs. The powerful bonds you create with these characters and truly outstanding and is unmatched by any movie i have seen in ages. Linklater has created a true masterpiece!

Well....I really loved this movie.  The cast was well picked....esp to last 12 years!  It was also pretty sad to watch these people's lives speed by....:(.  Really hits home if you're a parent of grown kids.

Sometimes when we watch a movie or see selected scenes in movies we can't help but relate them into our own reality, whether it be the good the bad or the ugly there are always some moments. These moments in film don't have to be the stand out scenes either they can be that little piece needed so the director could tie in an earlier scene or bit of dialogue. I know for myself these moments are what I love about film, I love when I can relate and replace myself with the actor or vice versa, replace the actor with myself in this reality.
Mason Jr Evans Played by Ellar Coltrane (no film history) is a six year old in 2002 he over hears his mother Olivia played by Patricia Arquette (Medium) saying she needs more space and wants to complete her study and find a professional career. Next scene Mason, Olivia and his sister Samantha played by Lorelei Linklater (daughter of the director and her first role also) are travelling to a new town in the car. The next few scenes Mason Jr and Samantha's father Mason Snr played by Ethan Hawke (Gattaca, Daybreakers) shows up and takes the kids bowling, apologising for being away for the last 18 months in Alaska. Both Mason Jr and Samantha have dreams their parents will get back together but once Olivia gets home and finds Mason Snr in her home an argument ensues and he quickly leaves without saying goodbye to the two kids, who have watched their parent disagreement from an upstairs window.... 12 years pass over the next 2 hrs and 45 minutes, in that time we get to see the kids grow, we hurt when they hurt, we love when they love and best of all it is always the same people. There is so much I can write here but I won't not in fear of giving anything away more in the hope your expectations remain level headed.
Boyhood is more than a film, it's an experiment done right, it's a story told so well you'd be forgiven in thinking there was no script that it was all reality, that the director Richard Linklater just started following around this family, sure the family has some very familiar faces and names but still that should just tell you how good the acting and characters actually are. How good the acting, storytelling, music and cinematography actually is. Told over 12 years Boyhood is in a league of its own, a ground breaking masterpiece. Using all the same actors over 12 years it is nothing less than a masterpiece. Linklater also directed one of my all-time favourite comedies; School of rock and is now ready to direct the TV series of the same name (which I personally cannot wait to see) The idea itself has blown me away and I for one take my hat off to this genius.
Boyhood is a very long film and in places was a little boring, sometimes thought if they just added a few more scenes to this specific timeline it would make all the difference, but then this is a film based on life and sometimes life doesn't have that climax we get from films. It's a film you can slot yourself into, exactly the way you should be able. Enjoy this for the ride it takes you on and the amazing little actors it has brought into the world of cinema.
I totally recommend this film for everyone, don't expect anything other than life though because if you want more you may be better off turning on and watching Die Hard for the 15th time.

The 3 critics and a majority of the audience that gave this movie a bad review are terribly mistaken. Boyhood is an inspiring film all the way through. The story follows a young boy named Mason with his sister and mother growing up over the course of 12 years. Using he same cast over 12 years, Richard Linklater made a movie with amazing acting, and a moving story about a kid going through boyhood. The film continued to amaze me throughout. This breakout movie deserves more that a 5 out of 5.

Incredible movie; the kind that comes along once in a lifetime. In fact, the effort may never again be duplicated. One of the most realistic films about life ever put to screen, there are no false moments or conflicts created out of thin air. Life on its own is quite complicated, and it's incredible to watch it play out with actors who age on screen. Due to the lateness of the hour, we meant to watch only 1 hour of this and finish it at a later date. Instead, we watched all 3 hours and were fully engaged the entire time. Bravo!
An epic project led by one inspiring filmmaker, Boyhood is an example of a vision expertly coming true.

Outstanding film making by director, Richard Linklater. The cinematography and central premise itself is definitely worth a spot in motion picture history with it's 12 year story of a young boy growing up right before our eyes. Watching this picture will make any audience member relive some of their most groundbreaking moments in life through Ellar Coltrane's portrayal of protagonist, "Mason" and his journey from boyhood to (young) adulthood.
Really good. I think it's possible the movie is even better than the director intended, but man, I just don't care for that ending.
the fact that this took 12 years in making combined with the natural progression of the story, it almost feels like a documentary on life.

This movie starts off like a stripped down high brow indie film, a bit disjointed, lacking narrative.  But as the movie goes on and you see the characters literally grow up before your eyes and go through life situations, you grow to know these characters and really invest yourself in them.  The moments are so small, but they speak loudly about how life is not lived between moments - life is the constant moment that we all live.  There is no narrative because so much of life has no narrative.  No matter how much we plan and have expectations for how our our futures are going to turn out, life happens and our initial hopes and dreams whether juvenile or adult do not happen.  But the point (at least for me) is to love your life whatever it is - don't waste time waxing about the past or worrying overly about the future.  Your time hasn't past, and it isn't coming.  Your time is now.

I have to admit, this movie really got to me, especially the last half hour.  These days I guess I've just become more sentimental :)

If you want to bore yourself to sleep then this is the perfect film. Literally nothing happens, no conflict, no story, nothing. Wow! He grows up right before our eyes! Waking Life was so terrible he had to disguise every frame by painting it to make it even interesting, this film unfortunately doesn't get that treatment.
